    If anyone having an interest in any lot or grave space in the cemetery desires to have any special or extraordinary service performed within the cemetery, such person may have the service performed, if it is reasonable and conforms to the rules of the cemetery. Application shall be made to the cemetery sexton for such special service and a permit therefor shall be issued upon the approval of the cemetery sexton. The cost of the special service shall be based upon the actual cost of labor and materials required therefor, plus 15 percent of the costs to be added for supervision and administrative costs, and the same shall be paid by the permit holder to the cemetery sexton. 
(Code 1968, § 6-46; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 4, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-40. - Weekend, holiday funerals. 
    No burial shall be made after 3:30 p.m. Saturday, on Sunday or on any city observed holidays except in unusual or extraordinary cases where immediate burial shall be required by public authorities. For any funeral arriving after 3:30 p.m. on Monday through Friday, a charge in the amount established in section 42-209 shall be paid to the city, in addition to any other charges authorized. For any weekend or holiday funeral a charge in the amount established in section 42-206 shall be paid to the city, in addition to any other charges authorized. 
(Code 1968, § 6-47; Ord. No. 2566-2012, § 1, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 30-41. - Placing and depth of graves. 
    Unless a grave opening permit shall specify otherwise, all graves shall be not less than 18 inches within the front boundary line of the lot, and not less than four feet 11 inches deep for an adult grave. The depth of all other graves shall be determined by the cemetery sexton. 
(Code 1968, § 6-48; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 5, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-42. - Enclosing lot and cover of graves. 
    Any fence, hedge, coping, curb, or other means of enclosure of a lot is prohibited. Any cover for a lot or grave except sod is prohibited; provided, that the superintendent of the cemetery may cause any means of enclosure or any lot cover except sod now existing within the cemetery to be removed at such superintendent's discretion. 
(Code 1968, § 6-49) 
Sec. 30-43. - Grave decorations. 
(a)  Artificial or cut flowers in approved permanent monument vases are permitted year-round in Valley View Cemetery and Sunset Memorial Gardens. On graves that have no monument, flowers may be placed in spaces provided for a monument at the head or foot of the grave until a monument is set. At no time shall flowers not in permanent monument vases, solar lights or other decorations be placed on a grave or in the grass area around monuments from April 1 to October 31. Winter decorations from November 1 to March 31 shall be placed around monuments as to not interfere with equipment in process of digging graves. All winter decorations and artificial flowers placed in the ground will be removed and disposed of by cemetery personnel after March 31 of each year. Memorial Day decorations are permitted one week before and two weeks after Memorial Day. If not removed by owners, cemetery personnel shall be authorized to remove and dispose of all decorations. Persons wanting to leave temporary decorations on a grave for a period not to exceed one week must get prior permission by calling the cemetery sexton's office. Dates to be approved for temporary decorations are the deceased person's birth date, death date anniversary, wedding anniversary, Mother's Day, Father's Day and national or religious holidays. 
(b)  Nothing shall be placed on any grave or lot except monuments and markers without the special written permit of the cemetery sexton, except flowers in permanent monument vases, wreaths, flags and other temporary decorations which shall be removed by the cemetery sexton at the cemetery sexton's discretion. All decorations shall be placed within the boundaries of a lot. Any decoration placed outside the boundaries of a lot shall be removed by the cemetery sexton, without notice to the owner or person placing the decoration at the location. The cemetery sexton shall be authorized to use the sexton's discretion to remove and dispose of noncomplying decorations. Unless an agreement has been made beforehand with the cemetery sexton, no articles mentioned in this section will be returned to the owner or person placing the same. The disposition or sale of personal property accumulated or salvaged by, or coming into the possession of the city shall have the prior approval of the city manager, or cemetery sexton, before such disposition or sale. A report thereof with an accounting of the articles sold and the total sale shall be made by the cemetery sexton. 
(Code 1968, § 6-50; Ord. No. 2473-2010, § 1, 5-4-10; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 6, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-44. - Corner markers. 
    At Valley View Cemetery, the corners of any lot may be marked by the owner thereof by markers not larger than six inches square which shall be of such material and of such design as the cemetery sexton may permit. No marker shall extend above the surface of the ground. Any markers not conforming to this rule may be removed by the cemetery sexton or brought into conformity with the rule as may be directed by the cemetery sexton. Corner markers are not allowed at Sunset Memorial Gardens. 
(Code 1968, § 6-51) 
Sec. 30-45. - Cemetery hours; entry when gates closed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to enter into or upon the grounds of the cemeteries between the hours of one hour after sunset and one hour before sunrise of any day, or for any person to enter or leave the cemeteries except by the established entrances or gateways. It shall be further unlawful for any person to be in or upon the cemetery grounds when the gates or entrances thereto provided for ingress or egress are barricaded, closed or locked, without first obtaining the permission of the cemetery sexton or other person in charge of the cemeteries. 
(Code 1968, § 6-11) 
Sec. 30-46. - Driving and parking; sexton to direct traffic. 
    It shall be unlawful to drive or move any vehicle within said cemetery except over a roadway open for vehicular traffic or to obstruct any path or driveway within the cemetery open to vehicular traffic. No person shall use the cemetery grounds or any driveway therein as a public thoroughfare nor drive any vehicle through said grounds except for purpose of making deliveries in connection with cemetery work or other lawful purposes. It shall be the duty of the cemetery sexton and the cemetery sexton's assistants to direct all vehicular traffic and the cemetery sexton is authorized to direct the parking or standing of all vehicles in the cemetery. It shall be unlawful for any person to disobey or disregard the directions of the cemetery sexton relating to the movement or standing of all vehicles within the cemetery. 
(Code 1968, § 6-14) 
Sec. 30-47. - Monuments, plantings; permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to erect monumental work, burial structures or buildings without a permit therefor, or to erect any fence, coping, curbing or enclosure of any kind, or to plant or remove any tree, shrub, flower or other decorative plant in the cemetery contrary to the rules and regulations therefor established by this article. 
(Code 1968, § 6-16) 
Sec. 30-48. - Animals. 
    Except for seeing dogs, hearing hear dogs and guide dogs for the disabled, it shall be unlawful for any person to bring or cause to be placed within the confines of any cemetery a dog, horse, or any other livestock, either attended or unattended, for any purpose. 
(Code 1968, § 6-20) 
Sec. 30-49. - Trees and plants. 
    The planting and care of trees, shrubs and other plants will be done by the cemetery sexton and the city public grounds department, and as may be authorized by the governing body; provided that the planting of flowers only in addition to that done by the city may be permitted to be done by the owners of lots or by others interested in the beautification of Valley View Cemetery upon obtaining written permission from the cemetery sexton. No plantings of any type or kind are permitted at Sunset Memorial Gardens. If any tree, shrub or other plant within the cemeteries becomes detrimental to adjacent lots, walks or streets or is not in keeping with the general design and the planning of the cemetery, it may be removed at the discretion of the cemetery sexton. 
(Code 1968, § 6-53; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 7, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-50. - Removal of plants. 
    No person shall disturb or remove any sod, tree, shrub, plant or any growing flower from a lot owned by such person or from any other part of the cemetery without first having obtained the permission of the cemetery sexton. 
(Code 1968, § 6-54) 
Sec. 30-51. - Burial vaults, crypts, vaults, other structures-Approval required. 
    Only concrete or steel burial boxes and/or vaults as approved by the cemetery sexton will be permitted to be used for interments made in the cemeteries. Provided, fiberglass vaults purchased on contract before June 1982, for use at Sunset Memorial Gardens will be allowed. Further provided, that for interments where the casket is three feet or less, a wood, concrete, or steel vault is required as an outside container at both cemeteries. No crypt or vault or other structure shall be built until complete plans and specifications of the same have been approved by the cemetery sexton, and the governing body, and a permit therefor has been issued in writing by the city clerk in connection with a grave opening permit. 
(Code 1968, § 6-55) 
Sec. 30-52. - Same-Construction. 
    All vaults, monuments, and other like structures shall be constructed under the general supervision and direction of the cemetery sexton. All materials used in the construction of any such structure must be brought into the cemetery as nearly as possible ready to set in place. The construction must be finished as rapidly as practicable. All chips, waste materials and debris of every kind must be removed at once upon completion of the structure. The builder of any such structure must take every precaution not to trespass on any other part of the cemetery and to keep from damaging any tree, shrub, monument, marker, sod, street or alley or other object in the cemetery. 
(Code 1968, § 6-56) 
Sec. 30-53. - Construction project-Permits. 
    No building, wall, monument work, or permanent structure shall be constructed in the cemetery until a permit therefor shall have been obtained from the cemetery sexton or any other city department responsible for issuing building permits. The application for such work shall be made by a member of the family, its authorized agent, or the person doing the work. The application shall describe the work proposed to be done and when the cemetery sexton shall be satisfied that the same can be done in accordance with the rules of the cemetery, the cemetery sexton shall issue a permit for such purpose shall upon payment of the service charges required by the city. 
(Code 1968, § 6-57; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 8, 8-16-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2736-2016, § 8, adopted Aug. 16, 2016, amended the catchline of § 30-53 from "Monumental work-Permits" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 30-54. - Same-Service charges. 
    All foundations or bases in the cemeteries shall be installed by the monument dealer and work shall be executed without unnecessary delay, under the supervision of the cemetery sexton and in conformance with the provisions of this article for which the monument dealer shall pay to the city clerk the supervision or inspection fee established in section 42-207. Monuments shall not be set by the city, but shall be set under the supervision of the cemetery sexton. Government markers may be set under the direction of the cemetery sexton in compliance with rules set out in section 30-55. 
(Code 1968, § 6-58) 
Sec. 30-55. - Materials for monuments or markers. 
    No monument or marker shall be located or placed in Valley View Cemetery unless it is of granite, marble, bronze, or granite flush-type grassers. No other materials will be permitted. No monument or marker shall be located or placed in Sunset Memorial Gardens unless it is bronze (mounted on concrete or granite flush-type foundation) or granite (flush-type grassers). Temporary markers (provided by funeral homes) may be placed at the direction of the cemetery sexton and shall be subject to removal at the discretion of the cemetery sexton at both cemeteries. Temporary markers will be removed once a monument has been placed. No monuments of wood, iron, tin, plaster of Paris, cement, limestone, sandstone, artificial stone or salt projecting above the surface of the ground, shall be permitted in the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 2346, § 1, 10-13-06) 
Sec. 30-56. - Location and construction of monuments and markers. 
(a)  The cemetery sexton shall be authorized to direct the placing of any monument in a specified location and, in general, the location of monuments must conform to the general plan of placement of monuments in the part of the cemetery in which it is placed. The specifications and materials for the construction of foundations of monuments shall be governed by the rules and regulations of the governing body pertaining to monument work and beautification of the cemetery as follows: 
(1)  At Valley View Cemetery all foundations shall comply with the following: only concrete or granite foundations will be permitted. Foundations shall be of sufficient depth and strength to support the weight of the monuments, with a minimum depth of six inches required. No foundation is to exceed 24 inches in width. All foundations shall have a margin of not less than three inches showing on all four side of the monument or marker, unless a deviation from this requirement is approved by the cemetery sexton. Concrete foundations are allowed to be poured on-site or brought in as a prefabricated precast. Additional concrete or sackcrete shall be placed under precast to meet the six-inch requirement. 
Granite foundations shall be a minimum of three inches thick with a compressive rating of not less than 19,000 psi to 22,500 psi. Additional concrete or sackcrete shall be placed under foundation to meet the six-inch requirement. All granite foundations shall be set with top of foundation flush with ground level. 
Granite flush-type grassers shall follow the same specifications of granite foundations. Additional concrete or sackcrete shall be placed under foundation to meet the six-inch requirement. All granite flush-type grassers shall require all inscriptions, lettering, and vases to be placed within the stone to allow a margin of not less than three inches from the edge of the grasser on all four sides. No marker shall rise above ground level of a lot except at the end of the grave space at which monuments, markers, or granite flush-type grassers are permitted. 
(2)  At Sunset Memorial Gardens all foundations shall comply with the following: only bronze plaque (mounted on concrete or granite flush-type) or granite flush-type grassers will be permitted. Foundations shall be of sufficient depth to support the weight of the monuments, with a minimum depth of three inches required. No foundation is to exceed 24 inches in width. All foundations shall have a margin of not less than three inches showing on all four sides of the monument or marker. Concrete foundations are allowed to be poured on-site or brought in as a prefabricated precast. Granite foundations shall be a minimum of three inches thick with a compressive rating of not less than 19,000 psi to 22,500 psi. All granite foundations shall be set with top of foundation flush with ground level. 
Granite flush-type grassers shall have a minimum of three inches thickness with a compressive rating of not less than 19,000 psi to 22,500 psi, and not exceed 24 inches in width. All granite flush-type grassers shall require all inscriptions, lettering, and vases to be placed within the stone to allow a margin of not less than three inches from the edge of the flush-type grasser on all four sides. All granite flush-type grassers shall be set with the top of stone flush with ground level. No marker shall rise above ground level of a lot except at the end of the grave space at which monuments, markers, or granite flush-type grassers are permitted. 
(b)  All monuments, plaques, granite flush-type grassers, including the foundations and apron, shall be placed in such a manner so that the combined width of the monument, foundation and apron will not exceed the width of the grave space on which it is to be placed, in order to prevent encroachment upon adjacent property. The cemetery sexton shall have the authority to cause to be removed and replaced such monuments and foundations that do so encroach upon other property. Standard specifications may be prepared by the cemetery sexton for the construction of monument foundations to cover the various kinds and sizes of monuments to be placed. 
(Ord. No. 2346, § 1, 10-13-06; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 1, 9-18-12) 
Sec. 30-57. - Mausoleums. 
    No mausoleum shall house more than two persons, and no mausoleum shall be more than four feet in height. Mausoleums shall only be allowed in the mausoleum section of a cemetery, and shall conform with the height and size restrictions, unless otherwise authorized by the cemetery sexton. Lots for mausoleums may only be purchased by family members directly, or through a funeral director. Lots for mausoleums may not be purchased by any person or business for resale. All mausoleums erected or placed in a cemetery shall conform to all applicable rules and regulations of the cemetery sexton and this article. All plans and specifications for a mausoleum shall be approved by the cemetery sexton prior to placement in areas specifically designated for mausoleums in the cemetery. 
(Ord. No. 2287, § 1, 9-28-04; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 2, 9-18-12) 
Sec. 30-58. - Valley View Cemetery columbarium fees. 
    The fees associated with purchase and services related to the columbariums at Valley View Cemetery shall be as established in section 42-211. 
(Ord. No. 2736-2016, § 1, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-59. - Columbarium regulations. 
    The following regulations shall be applicable to the columbariums at Valley View Cemetery: 
(1)  Decorations shall only be allowed in the vase provided on the vase rail. 
(2)  No decorations shall be allowed on or below the vase rail, other than fresh flowers or other decorations at the time of inurnment, for a period of time not exceeding 48 hours after the inurnment. 
(3)  No decorations shall be allowed on or at the base of the columbarium unit, other than fresh flowers or other decorations at the time of inurnment, for a period of time not exceeding 48 hours after the inurnment. 
(4)  No decals, engravings, or any other defacing of niche panels or vases. 
(Ord. No. 2736-2016, § 2, 8-16-16) 
Secs. 30-60-30-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOT CONVEYANCES, GRAVE OPENINGS, AND DISINTERMENTS 

Sec. 30-76. - Grave opening permit; application. 
    For a grave to be opened or dug, the cemetery sexton shall be notified not less than 24 hours before the time of interment. Applications for a grave opening permit shall be made to the cemetery sexton in accordance with the following provisions: 
(1)  The application for permit may be made by: 
a.  The owner of the lot or a duly authorized agent or representative; 
b.  By the funeral director or person in charge of the interment; or 
c.  Some other authorized person. 
The application shall contain a stipulation that the permit holder agrees to indemnify the city for any expense incurred by it if the burial proves to be unauthorized or on the wrong grave space or the wrong lot. 
(2)  The application must give the following information: 
a.  Name of lot owner or owners; 
b.  Legal description of the lot and grave space in which burial is to be made; 
c.  Name of person to be buried; 
d.  Time and date of burial; 
e.  Name of funeral director, if any; 
f.  Size and kind of box or vault; and 
g.  Signature of applicant for permit. 
(3)  The cemetery sexton shall, upon the approval of an application and upon receipt of all fees and charges fixed for such permits and the opening of a grave (as may be established) and upon the payment of the full purchase price of a lot or grave space (if the same belongs to the city) at the time of the application, issue a permit giving the above information and permission to dig or open the grave on the lot or grave space described. No permit shall be issued nor permit fees collected by the cemetery sexton, until after the death of the person to be buried. 
(4)  No grave shall be opened in any lot or space until the cemetery sexton shall have the permit herein required. Any person requesting a grave opening shall be liable to the city for any charges or fees required for opening any grave or marking any interment when any work or interment preparations shall be commenced without a permit or without the payment of the fees or charges required therefor. 
(5)  The cemetery sexton shall keep a record of all interments made in the cemeteries, stating the name of the deceased, date of burial, and the name and address of the funeral director. Such records shall be at all times open to public inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1962, § 1, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 9, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-77. - Burial in endowed lots only; exception for county. 
    The city will grant burial rights only in endowed lots; provided, however the governing body may otherwise authorize the sale of lots or grave space to the county for interment of those buried or to be buried, at expense of the county. 
(Code 1968, § 6-33) 
Sec. 30-78. - Payment of purchase price prerequisite to conveyance of burial rights. 
    No grant or conveyance of burial rights in any lot or grave space shall be made by the city until the full purchase price of the lot, lots or space to be granted shall have been paid to the city in accordance to the rules for making such purchases. 
(Code 1968, § 6-34) 
Sec. 30-79. - Cemetery zones. 
    The governing body may designate by zones particular areas of the cemetery where burial rights may only be granted by the sale of full lots, half-lots or by single or double grave spaces, and wherein burial rights will be granted only upon the endowment of the lot or portions thereof. The master plat of the cemetery grounds or a copy thereof shall show the particular zones and the purposes for which each may be used in accordance with the above zoning regulations. The governing body may establish the sale price of lots, or portions thereof, with reference to the zones or lot numbers by which the same are described. The price of all lots in the endowed zones of the cemetery shall include the amount of the endowment as provided by this article. 
(Code 1968, § 6-35) 
Sec. 30-80. - Sale of lots. 
(a)  The price of lots, or portions thereof, shall be as set out in section 42-208(a) and (b). The current schedule of lot prices shall be kept on file by the cemetery sexton and the city clerk. All lots, or portions thereof, shall be sold only for cash and no lots or grave space may be sold on credit or on the installment plan. 
(b)  The governing body may waive this rule by a regulation permitting the cemetery sexton on application of the immediate survivors of the person interred to reserve not more than one adjacent grave space per each grave space purchased by same for not to exceed one year upon making a nonrefundable deposit in the amount established in section 42-208(c) for each grave space reserved. The cemetery sexton shall issue a receipt for the deposit stating the terms thereof. The amount thereof shall be credited to the purchase price upon receipt thereof in full. The deposit shall be by the cemetery sexton placed in the general operating fund and the cemetery endowment fund in equal shares; provided, however, that any partial payment, sale or contract then in effect shall be completed in accordance with its terms. 
(c)  An individual may make a request to the cemetery sexton to hold a grave space or spaces for a period of ten business days, unless a longer period of time is approved by the cemetery sexton. If the grave space or spaces are not purchased within the designated time period, the hold will expire. 
(Code 1968, § 6-36; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 3, 9-18-12; Ord. No. 2735-2016, § 10, 8-16-16) 
Sec. 30-81. - Cemetery conveyances-Deed. 
    All cemetery deeds or conveyances shall be issued to the purchaser thereof under the seal of the city and the same shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the clerk. All persons desiring to purchase cemetery lots or grave space shall apply to the city clerk at the clerk's office and upon payment of the purchase price thereof shall be entitled to a certificate conveying such rights to the cemetery lot as shall be authorized by law. All such certificates shall be recorded in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1968, § 6-37) 
Sec. 30-82. - Same-Rights conveyed. 
    Cemetery lots owned by the city shall be conveyed by a certificate signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk under the seal of the city, specifying that the purchaser to whom the same is issued is the owner of the lot or lots described therein by number, as laid down on the cemetery map or plat, for the sole purpose of human interment. Such certificate shall vest in the purchaser, the purchaser's heirs and assigns, a right in fee simple to such lot or portions thereof, for the sole purpose of interment, under the regulations of the governing body. Such certificate shall be entitled to be recorded in the office of the county register of deeds, without further acknowledgment and such description of lots shall be deemed and recognized as a sufficient description thereof. All such conveyances shall be registered by the city clerk in the cemetery lot register without fee and before the same be issued to the grantee, the clerk shall cause the same to be recorded with county register of deeds, the recording fee therefor to be added and collected with the sale price. 
(Code 1968, § 6-38) 
Sec. 30-83. - Transfer of titles; approval required. 
    The title to cemetery lots, or portions thereof, may be transferred to other persons by a quitclaim deed by the owner thereof, but no such transfer shall be valid until approved by the governing body. Before any such transfer will be recognized by the city as valid, a quit claim deed transfer fee of $25.00 shall be paid to the city clerk, and the instrument shall be recorded by the city clerk in the cemetery lot register. The city retains the option to purchase any lot or portion thereof which the owner may desire to dispose of, at a price not to exceed the price paid for each lot, less the endowment, and less the amount of any annual care charges due and unpaid at the time. 
(Ord. No. 1962, § 1, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 4, 9-18-12) 
Sec. 30-84. - Disposition of funds from sales of lots. 
    When a lot, fractional lot, or single grave space is purchased, a portion of the sale price shall be credited to and deposited in the cemetery endowment fund, to be invested and kept in trust as provided by division 3 of this article; the remaining sum derived from the sale price shall be credited to and deposited in the general operating fund. 
(Code 1968, § 6-41) 
Sec. 30-85. - Limitation on number of lots. 
    The city will sell only such lots or fractions thereof as the purchaser shall have reasonable need, and the city reserves the right to limit the number of lots or portions thereof which any person may purchase or have title to at any one time. 
(Code 1968, § 6-42) 
Sec. 30-86. - Reopening graves; disinterment; permits. 
(a)  Any person desiring to reopen any grave in the cemetery to disinter or remove any body therefrom, or for any other purpose, shall first obtain a disinterment permit from the city clerk to be issued upon proper application and the payment of the service charge required by section 30-87. The application shall give the number of the lot and block on which such grave is situated, the name of the person buried therein, the time of such burial and the place where such body is to be reburied, if it is to be reburied, and the reason therefor. The application shall be signed by a member of the family or when there is no family, by the next of kin desiring to reopen the grave and upon the approval thereof, a permit shall be issued. The permit shall contain the information disclosed in the application and shall be issued over the signature of the city clerk and under the seal of the city and shall authorize the reopening of the grave as described by the application. 
(b)  The cemetery sexton shall upon receipt of the permit reopen the grave and remove the body therefrom. Upon completion of the work, and the reinterment if there shall be one, the cemetery sexton shall make a return of the permit to the city clerk with the statement of the charges incurred in accordance with the rules of the cemetery; provided, that an order of the district court, or the judge thereof, for the exhumation of the body of the deceased person shall be a sufficient application for the permit required hereunder and the cost of such exhumation including the payment of the required service charges shall be a claim against the county as provided by law. 
(Code 1968, § 6-63) 
Sec. 30-87. - Reopening and disinterment; reinterment; service charges. 
(a)  The applicant for a permit to reopen any grave or to disinter or exhume any body buried in the cemetery shall pay to the city clerk the fee established in section 42-210. 
(b)  When the permit holder proposes a reinterment in another lot in the cemetery, a fee shall be paid to the city clerk in the amount established in section 42-209, in addition to the disinterment fee established in section 42-210. 
(Code 1968, § 6-64; Ord. No. 2566-2012, § 2, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 30-88. - Grave opening, closing fees. 
    Grave opening and closing charges shall be as established in section 42-209. 
(Code 1968, § 6-65) 
Sec. 30-89. - Grave spaces; interments per space. 
(a)  At Valley View Cemetery, all designated one-half grave spaces shall allow for an interment of a casket size three feet or less and may be purchased for one-half the price of an adult grave space. 
(1)  There shall be no more than one casket (as described above) buried per each one-half grave space. 
(2)  There shall be no more than two cremations interred per each one-half grave space. 
(3)  There shall be no more than four cremations interred per each whole adult grave space. 
(4)  There shall be no more than one adult casket interred per each whole adult grave space. Multiple adult casket burials on single whole adult grave spaces are not allowed. 
(5)  Combinations of interments, other than those listed above will be allowed only after approval from the cemetery sexton. 
(b)  At Sunset Memorial Gardens, an adult grave space must be purchased for each interment. 
(Code 1968, § 6-66; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 5, 9-18-12) 
Secs. 30-90-30-110. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ENDOWMENT FUND[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- City exempted from surety bond requirement for endowment fund, app. A, Charter Ord. No. 5. 
State Law reference- Endowment fund, K.S.A. 12-1408 et seq. 

Sec. 30-111. - Fund created. 
    There is hereby created pursuant to K.S.A. 12-1408 an endowment fund for the Valley View Cemetery and Sunset Memorial Gardens, the public cemeteries owned and controlled by the city. Funds derived from the endowment of specified parts of the cemetery, as provided in section 30-112, shall automatically be placed in the endowment fund hereby created, and such other funds shall be placed therein as the governing body shall determine from time to time. 
(Code 1968, § 6-76) 
Sec. 30-112. - Endowment for perpetual care. 
    All grounds located within Valley View Cemetery or Sunset Memorial Gardens are provided with perpetual care. For each grave space, $50.00 of the purchase price shall be invested into the endowment fund to secure perpetual care for such grave space. Any income generated from said investments shall be expended as provided by the statute under which the endowment fund provided for in this article is created, or by amendments to that statute. In handling funds paid to it under this section, the city shall be liable only for the faithful discharge of the trust imposed upon it. 
(Ord. No. 1962, § 1, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 2563-2012, § 6, 9-18-12) 
State Law reference- Investment of funds, K.S.A. 12-140. 
Sec. 30-113. - Certificate to be issued. 
    When any person shall make a payment to the city as provided in section 30-112, the city shall cause to be issued to such person a receipt, or certificate, setting out clearly the name of the person making the payment, the amount paid, the particular part of the cemetery to which the payment relates, the purpose for which it is made, the fact that the principal of the payment can be used only for investment, an agreement on the part of the city to give the specified part of the cemetery perpetual care, and any other fact pertinent to the transaction that it may be found advisable to include. 
(Code 1968, § 6-78) 
Sec. 30-114. - Investment and expenditure of funds. 
    The endowment fund created by this division shall be invested from time to time, by the governing body, in such investments as the statute or amendments thereto permit, and the income from these investments shall be expended as they may be needed in caring for, beautifying, and improving the cemetery and the lots specially endowed. In no case shall the principal of the endowment fund be used for any other purpose whatever except investment. 
(Code 1968, § 6-79) 
State Law reference- Investment of endowment funds, K.S.A. 12-1410. 
Sec. 30-115. - Custodian and custodian's bond. 
    All funds and securities belonging to the cemetery endowment fund shall be in the custody of the finance director. 
(Code 1968, § 6-80) 
Sec. 30-116. - Records to be kept. 
(a)  The city clerk shall keep a complete and accurate record of each transaction under this division, including the name of the person paying any sum of money to the city, the date of payment, the amount paid, the part of the cemetery that is to receive perpetual care, and such other data as is found necessary or desirable to keep. 
(b)  The endowment fund created by this division and the income therefrom shall be kept on the books of both the city clerk and the city finance director, in separate accounts, to be called the cemetery endowment fund. 
(c)  The city clerk and the city finance director shall each keep a complete and accurate record of all investments belonging to the cemetery endowment fund. 
(Code 1968, § 6-81) 
Chapter 34 - EMERGENCY SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fees pertaining to emergency services, § 42-231 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 54. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 34-1-34-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES RELEASE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 38. 

Sec. 34-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Emergency action means all exigent activities conducted in order to prevent or mitigate harm to the public health and safety and the environment from a release or threatened release of any material into or upon land, water or air. 
    Recoverable expenses includes those expenses of the city that are reasonable, necessary and allocable to an emergency action. Recoverable expenses shall not include normal budgeted expenditures that are incurred in the course of providing what are traditionally city services and responsibilities, such as routine firefighting protection. Expenses allowable for recovery may include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Disposable materials and supplies consumed and expended specifically for the purpose of the emergency action. 
(2)  Compensation of employees for the time and efforts devoted specifically to the emergency action. 
(3)  Rental or leasing of equipment used specifically for the emergency action (e.g., protective equipment or clothing, scientific and technical equipment). 
(4)  Replacement costs for equipment owned by the city that is contaminated beyond reuse or repair, if the equipment was a total loss and the loss occurred during the emergency action (e.g., self-contained breathing apparatus irretrievably contaminated during the response). 
(5)  Decontamination of equipment contaminated during the response. 
(6)  Special technical services specifically required for the response (e.g., costs associated with the time and efforts of technical experts or specialists not otherwise provided for by the city). 
(7)  Other special services specifically required for the emergency action. 
(8)  Laboratory costs of analyzing samples taken during the emergency action. 
(9)  Any costs of cleanup, storage, or disposal of the release material. 
(10)  Costs associated with the services, supplies and equipment procured for a specific evacuation of persons or property. 
(11)  Medical expenses incurred as a result of response activities. 
(12)  Legal expenses that may be incurred as a result of the emergency action, including efforts to recover expenses pursuant to this article. 
    Release means any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, emptying, discharging, injecting, escaping, dumping or disposing into or upon land, water or air, of any material. 
    Threatened release means any imminent or impending event potentially causing but not resulting in a release, but causing the city to undertake an emergency action. 
(Code 1968, § 11-140) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-32. - Strict liability. 
    Any person causing or responsible for a release or threatened release resulting in an emergency action shall be strictly liable to the city for the recoverable expenses resulting from the emergency action. There shall be a rebuttal presumption that any person owning or controlling property causing a release or threatened release is responsible for such release or threatened release. 
(Code 1968, § 11-141) 
Sec. 34-33. - Recovery of expenses. 
(a)  Itemization of recoverable expenses. City personnel and departments involved in an emergency action shall keep an itemized record of recoverable expenses resulting from an emergency action. Promptly after completion of an emergency action, the appropriate city department shall certify those expenses to the city manager. 
(b)  Submission of claim. The city shall submit a written itemized claim for the total expenses incurred by the city for the emergency action to the responsible person and a written notice that unless the amounts are paid in full to the city within 30 days after the date of the mailing of the claim and notice, the city will file a civil action seeking recovery for the stated amount. 
(c)  Lien on property. The city may cause a lien in the amount of the recoverable expenses to be placed on any real property located within the city owned by the person causing or responsible for the emergency action. 
(d)  Civil suit. The city may bring a civil action for recovery of the recoverable expenses against any and all persons causing or responsible for the emergency action. 
(Code 1968, § 11-142) 
Secs. 34-34-34-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ALARM SYSTEMS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 22; fire prevention and protection, ch. 46; law enforcement, ch. 54. 

Sec. 34-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm system means an assembly of equipment and devices arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention to which the police department or fire department is expected to respond. The term alarm system shall include the terms burglar alarm systems, holdup alarm systems, fire alarm systems, alarm systems which monitor temperature or humidity, and any system related to the protection of an unauthorized intrusion into a premises or an attempted robbery at a premises. 
    Alarm user means the person in control of any building, structure, or facility who purchases, leases, contracts for, or otherwise obtains an alarm system or for the servicing or maintenance of an alarm system and thereafter has such system monitored at a law enforcement center. 
    Automatic dialing device means any alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect. 
    Central monitoring system means the facility at the law enforcement center utilized for monitoring alarm systems, said system monitored by the city by and through the police department. 
    False alarm means the activation of an alarm system in the city or unincorporated areas of the county through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, improper adjustment, negligence of a person, or an alarm signal transmitted in the absence of an alarm condition, except when an alarm system is activated by violent conditions of nature or any other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to or controlled by the alarm user or when initiated by an act of God. 
    Law enforcement center means the county law enforcement center located at 302 North Ninth, Garden City, Kansas. 
    Primary trunk line means the 911 telephone number leading into the county law enforcement center used for the purpose of handling emergency calls on a person-to-person basis and which line is identified as the emergency number listed in the telephone directory issued by the telephone company, or any other telephone line leading directly into the county law enforcement center that is for the purpose of handling emergency calls, which line or lines are identified as specific numbers included among the emergency numbers listed in the telephone directory issued by the telephone company. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-157), 8-23-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 34-57. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a violation of any of the provisions of this article is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-160), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 34-58. - Administrative charges. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, the user of any alarm system that transmits more than five false alarms to which law enforcement personnel or fire safety personnel are requested to respond within a one-year period shall be charged an administrative service fee in accordance with section 42-231. 
(b)  All administrative charges assessed under this section shall be due and payable in the office of the city clerk within 30 days after the receipt of notification that such fee has been assessed and is due. 
(c)  All new alarm systems shall receive a 90-day grace period from the date of activation for the purpose of adjustments and corrections in the alarm system prior to the assessment of any administrative charges set forth in this section. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-158), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 34-59. - Automatic dialing devices; direct dialing prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or business to program or use an automatic dialing device to dial directly into the county law enforcement center, whether by dialing 911, a primary trunk line, or any other number or line leading into the county law enforcement center. It shall be unlawful for any person or business to fail to disconnect or reprogram an automatic dialing device within 12 hours of receipt of written notice to disconnect or reprogram such device from the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-159), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 34-60. - Dispute resolution. 
    Should a disagreement arise over whether any particular alarm should be considered a false alarm under this article, the facts surrounding the circumstances of the alarm activation shall first be presented to the chief of police, who shall, after consideration of all of the information presented, determine whether or not the activation constitutes a false alarm as defined in this article. If disagreement still exists after consideration by the chief of police, the facts surrounding the alarm activation shall be presented to the city manager, who shall, after consideration of all the information presented, determine whether or not the alarm activation constitutes a false alarm. All such disagreements must be presented to the chief of police within 20 days after the date of notification that an administrative fee is due as a result of a particular alarm being determined to be a false alarm. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4, 8-23-94) 
Chapter 38 - ENVIRONMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Hazardous substance releases, § 34-31 et seq.; fees pertaining to environment, § 42-251 et seq.; natural resources, ch. 58; oil and gas wells and pipelines, § 58-31 et seq.; solid waste, ch. 74; vegetation, ch. 94. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 38-1. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 38-2. - Nuisance deposits. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to throw, deposit, discharge, excrete, or leave human or animal waste on any public or private property, unless the disposal of the waste is done in a restroom facility recognized as a sanitary means of disposing of human or animal waste. The prohibition in this section includes public urination or defecation by a person. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4, 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-3. - Vehicle nuisances. 
    It shall be unlawful to park on the streets or alleys of the city, any vehicle, trailer, or other container transporting, carrying, or hauling any livestock or any other vehicle, trailer, or container having been used for such purpose, if the vehicle, trailer, or container contains any animal filth or waste, manure, or decaying animal or vegetable matter offensive to another individual so as to be a public nuisance. It shall further be unlawful to park or leave standing any such vehicle, trailer, or container on any private premises. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4, 8-23-94) 
Secs. 38-4-38-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ABANDONED, WRECKED, ETC., PROPERTY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 38-31. - Impoundment fees. 
(a)  An impoundment fee in the amount established in section 42-251 shall be charged against owners of any and all property impounded under the provisions of this article. 
(b)  Impoundment costs as required above shall be in addition to costs incurred in the removal of impounded vehicles from the place of impoundment to the impoundment facility and the costs of notification through certified mail. 
(c)  No impoundment fees shall be charged against the buyer of an impounded vehicle when the vehicle is sold at public auction. 
(Code 1968, § 27-305; Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-136), 8-23-94) 
Secs. 38-32-38-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOTOR VEHICLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 86. 
State Law reference- Abandoned and disabled vehicles, K.S.A. 8-1101 et seq. 

Sec. 38-56. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable means a condition of being junked, wrecked, wholly or partially dismantled, discarded, abandoned or unable to perform the function or purpose for which it was originally constructed. 
    Motor vehicle or vehicle means, without limitation, any automobile, truck, tractor or motorcycle which as originally built contained an engine, regardless of whether it contains an engine at any other time. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(b)), 8-23-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 38-57. - Findings. 
    The governing body finds that junked, wrecked, dismantled, inoperative or abandoned vehicles affect the health, safety and general welfare of citizens of the city because they: 
(1)  Serve as a breeding ground for flies, mosquitoes, rats, and other insects and rodents; 
(2)  Are a danger to persons, particularly children, because of broken glass, sharp metal protrusions, insecure mounting on blocks, jacks or other supports; 
(3)  Are a ready source of fire and explosion; 
(4)  Encourage pilfering and theft; 
(5)  Constitute a blighting influence upon the area in which they are located; 
(6)  Constitute a fire hazard because they frequently block access for fire equipment to adjacent buildings and structures. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(a)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-58. - Nuisances unlawful; defined; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit any motor vehicle nuisance on private property within the city. 
(b)  A motor vehicle nuisance is any motor vehicle which is not currently registered or tagged pursuant to K.S.A. 8-126-8-149, as amended; or parked in violation of city ordinance; or incapable of moving under its own power; or in a junked, wrecked or inoperable condition, regardless of registration or tag. Any one of the following conditions shall raise the presumption that a vehicle is junked, wrecked or inoperable: 
(1)  Absence of a current registration plate upon the vehicle; 
(2)  Placement of the vehicle or parts thereof upon jacks, blocks, or other supports; 
(3)  Absence of one or more parts of the vehicle necessary for the lawful operation of the vehicle upon a street or highway. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle which is enclosed in a garage or other building; 
(2)  Any person conducting a business enterprise in compliance with existing zoning regulations or who places such vehicles behind screening of sufficient size, strength, and density to screen such vehicles from the view of the public and to prohibit ready access to stored vehicle by children. However, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to authorize the maintenance of a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(c)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-59. - Designation of enforcing officer. 
    The city manager shall designate a public officer to be charged with the administration and enforcement of this division. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(d)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-60. - Complaints; inquiry and inspection. 
    The public officer shall make inquiry and inspection of premises upon receiving a complaint that a nuisance exists. The public officer may make such inquiry and inspection when such officer observes conditions which appear to constitute a nuisance without a complaint. Upon making any inquiry and inspection the public officer shall make a written report of findings. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(e)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-61. - Right of entry. 
    It shall be a violation of this division to deny the public officer the right of access and entry upon private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inquiry and inspection to determine if a nuisance exists. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(f)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-62. - Order of violation. 
(a)  Any person found by the public officer to be in violation of section 38-58 shall be served an order of violation (order) issued by the governing body or its designee. The code enforcement officer is hereby designated by the governing body for the purpose of issuing the order required herein. The order shall be served by first class mail, or by personal service. If a person has failed to accept delivery or otherwise failed to effectuate receipt of an order sent pursuant to this section during the preceding 24-month period, the governing body may provide notice of the issuance of an order by any reasonable manner, including, but not limited to, door hangers, conspicuous posting of an order on a premise, personal notification, telephone communication, or first class mail. If the whereabouts of such person are unknown and the same cannot be ascertained after a diligent search by the public officer, the notice requirements of this section shall not apply, and the public officer may proceed with abatement. 
(b)  The order shall state the condition which is in violation of section 38-58. The order shall also inform the person that: 
(1)  Such person shall have ten days from the date of mailing or personal service of the order to abate the condition in violation of section 38-58; 
(2)  Such person has ten days from the date of mailing or personal service of the order to request a hearing before the governing body of the matter as provided by section 38-65; 
(3)  Failure to abate the condition or to request a hearing within the time allowed may result in prosecution as provided by subsection (c) of this section and/or abatement of the condition by the city as provided by section 38-63. 
(c)  Should any person fail to comply with the order to abate a nuisance or request a hearing, the public officer may file a complaint in the municipal court of the city, and upon conviction, the person shall be guilty of a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. Every day during or on which a violation occurs or continues after notice has been served shall constitute an additional or separate offense. Upon a first conviction, a person shall be fined $100.00; for a second conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $300.00 shall be imposed; and for a third and subsequent conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(d)  Within a 12-month period of the date of the order issued under the authority of this section, should the city or a person abate the described nuisance condition by removal of the motor vehicle, and then the motor vehicle is returned to the same premises resulting in the same nuisance condition, the city may proceed to abate the nuisance condition pursuant to section 38-63, without the issuance of a new resolution or order. 
(Ord. No. 2403, § 1, 5-13-08; Ord. No. 2825-2019, § 1, 2-5-19) 
Sec. 38-63. - Failure to comply; abatement. 
    In addition to or as alternative to prosecution as provided in section 38-62 above, the public officer may seek to remedy violations of this division in the following manner. If a person to whom an order has been sent pursuant to section 38-62 has neither alleviated the conditions causing the alleged violation nor requested a hearing before the governing body within the time period specified in section 38-62, the public officer may present a resolution to the governing body for adoption authorizing the public officer or other agents of the city to abate the conditions causing the violation at the end of ten days after passage of the resolution. Abatement shall include removal, impoundment, and sale of the vehicle. The resolution shall further provide that the costs incurred by the city shall be charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which the nuisance was located as provided in section 38-66. A copy of the resolution shall be served upon the person in violation in one of the following ways: 
(1)  Personal service upon the person in violation; 
(2)  Service by first class mail; or 
(3)  If the whereabouts of such person are unknown and the same cannot be ascertained in the exercise of reasonable diligence, an affidavit to that affect shall be made by the public officer and filed with the city clerk, and the serving of the resolution shall be made by publishing the same once each week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper. 
(Ord. No. 2403, § 2, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-64. - Disposition of vehicle. 
    Any motor vehicle which has been removed and impounded as provided in section 38-63, such impoundment for 30 days or more, shall be disposed of in the following manner: 
(1)  If such motor vehicle has displayed thereon a registration plate issued by the State Division of Vehicles, or a comparable agency in any other state, and has been registered with the division, the public officer shall mail a notice by certified mail to the registered owner thereof, addressed to the address as shown on the certificate of registration, and any lienholder of record, stating that if the owner or lienholder does not claim such motor vehicle, and pay the removal and storage charges incurred by the city on the vehicle within 15 days from the mailing of the notice, that the vehicle will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
(2)  After 15 days from date of notice, the public officer shall publish a notice once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official newspaper, which notice shall describe the motor vehicle by name of maker, model, color, and serial number, and owner, if known, and state that the motor vehicle has been impounded by the city and that it will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash, if the owner thereof does not claim the motor vehicle within ten days of the date of the second publication of the notice and pay the removal and storage charges, and publication costs incurred by the city. 
(3)  If the motor vehicle does not display a registration plate issued by the division and is not registered with the division, the public officer, after 30 days from date of impoundment, may publish a notice once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper, which notice shall describe the motor vehicle by name of maker, model, color, and serial number, and shall state that the motor vehicle has been impounded by the city and that it will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for each, if the owner thereof does not claim the motor vehicle within ten days of the notice of the second publication of the notice and pay the removal and storage charges, and publication costs incurred by the city. 
(4)  When the city has complied with the provisions of this section with respect to a motor vehicle which has been declared to be a nuisance, and has been removed and impounded, and the owner thereof does not claim the vehicle within the time stated in the notice and pay the removal and storage charges and publication costs incurred by the city on the motor vehicle, the city may sell the motor vehicle at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
(5)  After any sale pursuant to this section, the city may file proof thereof with the division and the division shall issue a certificate of title to the purchaser of the motor vehicle. All funds derived from the sale of motor vehicles pursuant to this section, after payment of the expenses of the abatement, impoundment and sale, shall be paid into the general fund of the city. 
(6)  Any person attempting to recover a motor vehicle impounded, shall show proof of valid registration and ownership of the motor vehicle, and pay any other fees incurred by the city for removal and storage of the motor vehicle, prior to release of the motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2276, § 1, 8-10-04) 
Sec. 38-65. - Hearing. 
    If a hearing is requested within the ten-day period as provided in section 38-62(b), such request shall be made in writing to the governing body. Failure to make a timely request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of the person's right to contest the findings of the public officer before the governing body. The hearing shall be held by the governing body as soon as possible after the filing of the request therefor, and the person shall be advised by the city of the time and place of the hearing at least five days in advance thereof. At any such hearing, the person may be represented by counsel, and the person and the city may introduce such witnesses and evidence as is deemed necessary and proper by the governing body. The hearing need not be conducted according to the formal rules of evidence. Upon conclusion of the hearing, the governing body shall record its determination of the matter by means of adopting a resolution and serving the resolution upon the person in the matter provided in section 38-63. 
(Ord. No. 1858, § 4(20-135(l)), 8-23-94) 
Sec. 38-66. - Costs assessed. 
    If the city abates the nuisance pursuant to section 38-63, the cost of the abatement, impoundment, and sale, shall be charged against the lot or parcel of ground on which the nuisance was located, subject to credit for any funds received from the sale of a vehicle. The city clerk shall, at the time of certifying other taxes to the county clerk, certify the costs as provided in this section. The county clerk shall extend the same on the tax roll, the assessment shall become a lien against the property on which the nuisance was located, and it shall be collected by the county treasurer and paid to the city as other city taxes are collected and paid. In addition to remedies available to the city to collect assessments levied against property, if any assessments for costs of abatement levied by the city in accordance with this section remain unpaid by the owner of a lot or parcel of ground, the city may collect the amount due in the same manner as a personal debt of the property owner to the city, by bringing an action in the appropriate district court. 
(Ord. No. 2243, § 1, 8-12-03) 
Secs. 38-67-38-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - OTHER PROPERTY 

Sec. 38-86. - Unlawful parking or standing. 
    No person shall park or stand for any period of time, any nonmotorized item of personal property not attached to a motor vehicle on any street, avenue, boulevard, thoroughfare, trafficway, highway, alley, municipal parking lot or any other public way used for vehicular travel. If an item of personal property is attached to a motor vehicle by a means so as to allow the motor vehicle to tow or pull the personal property, the personal property may only park or stand on a public way when so attached to the motor vehicle for a period of time not to exceed 72 hours, after which time the personal property must be removed from the public way. For the purpose of this section, personal property shall be defined as, and include, all boats, nonmotorized trailers, campers, farm equipment and machinery, implements of husbandry, special mobile equipment, and all other personal property that does not have its own motive power. 
(Ord. No. 1862, § 1(a), 9-13-94) 
Sec. 38-87. - Designation of enforcing officer. 
    The city manager shall designate a public officer to be charged with the administration and enforcement of this division, which may include, but not be limited to, any law enforcement officer of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 1862, § 1(b), 9-13-94) 
Sec. 38-88. - Complaints; inquiry and inspection. 
    The public officer shall make inquiry and inspection of a premises or public way upon receiving a complaint that an item of personal property is parked in violation of this division. The public officer may make inquiry and inspection without a complaint. 
(Ord. No. 1862, § 1(c), 9-13-94) 
Sec. 38-89. - Right of entry. 
    It shall be a violation of this division to deny the public officer the right of access and entry upon private property at any reasonable time for the purpose of making inquiry and inspection to determine if a violation of this division exists, and to determine the owner of, or person authorized to have control of, such unlawfully parked personal property. 
(Ord. No. 1862, § 1(d), 9-13-94) 
Sec. 38-90. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Any person found by the public officer to be in violation of section 38-86 shall be served a notice of such violation. The notice may be oral or written. If written, the notice shall be served by first class mail or by personal service. If the whereabouts of the person is unknown and the same cannot be ascertained after a diligent search by the public office, the notice requirements of this section shall not apply, and the public officer may proceed with abatement as allowed by section 38-92. 
(b)  The notice shall state the personal property which is in violation of subsection (a) of this section. The notice shall also inform the person that: 
(1)  Such person shall have five days from the date of mailing or service of the notice to abate the condition in violation of subsection (a) of this section; and 
(2)  Failure to abate the condition shall result in prosecution as provided by section 38-91 and/or abatement of the condition by the city as provided by section 38-92. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 1, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-91. - Penalty. 
    Should any person fail to comply with the notice to abate the condition, the public officer may file a complaint in the municipal court of the city against such person, and upon conviction of any violation of the provisions of section 38-86, the person shall be guilty of a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. Upon a first conviction, a person shall be fined $100.00; for a second conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $300.00 shall be imposed; and for a third and subsequent conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 2, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-92. - Abatement. 
    In addition to or as alternative to prosecution as provided in section 38-90, the public officer may seek to abate the condition. If a person to whom a notice has been sent pursuant to section 38-90 has not alleviated the condition causing the alleged violation within the time period specified in subsection (b) of section 38-90, the public officer may abate the condition. Abatement shall include removal, impoundment, and sale of the personal property. 
(Ord. No. 1862, § 1(h), 9-13-94) 
Sec. 38-93. - Disposition of personal property. 
    Any personal property which has been removed and impounded as provided in section 38-92, such impoundment for 30 days or more, or any personal property determined to be abandoned and coming into the possession of the city, shall be disposed of in the following manner: 
(a)  The public officer shall mail a notice by first class mail to the owner of the personal property, stating that if the owner does not claim the personal property, and pay the removal and storage charges incurred by the city on the personal property within 15 days from the mailing of the notice, that the personal property will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
(b)  After 15 days from date of notice, the public officer shall publish a notice once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official newspaper, which notice shall describe the personal property as clearly as possible, with the name of the owner, if known, and state that the personal property has been impounded by the city and that it will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash, if the owner thereof does not claim the personal property within ten days of the date of the second publication of the notice and pay the removal and storage charges, and publication costs incurred by the city. 
(c)  If the city cannot discern the owner of the personal property after reasonable and diligent search, the public officer, after 30 days from date of impoundment, may publish a notice once a week for two consecutive weeks in the official city newspaper, which notice shall describe the personal property as clearly as possible, and shall state that the personal property has been impounded by the city and that it will be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for each, if the owner thereof does not claim the personal property within ten days of the notice of the second publication of the notice and pay the removal and storage charges, and publication costs incurred by the city. 
(d)  When the city has complied with the provisions of this division with respect to personal property which has been removed and impounded, and the owner thereof does not claim the personal property within the time stated in the notice and pay the removal and storage charges and publication costs incurred by the city on the personal property, the city may sell the personal property at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. All funds derived from the sale of personal property pursuant to this section, after payment of the expenses of the removal, impoundment and sale, shall be paid into the general fund of the city. In lieu of sale at a public auction, the city may dispose of abandoned bicycles through donation to any entity serving a public purpose. 
(Ord. No. 2404, § 3, 5-13-08) 
Secs. 38-94-38-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WEEDS AND OBNOXIOUS CONDITIONS 

Sec. 38-111. - Weeds to be removed. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, lessee, tenant, or other person having legal title to, occupying, or having charge or control of any real property (property) to permit weeds to remain upon the property or any area between the property lines of the property and the centerline of any adjacent street or alley, including but not specifically limited to sidewalks, streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way and all other areas, public or private. All weeds as hereinafter defined are hereby declared a nuisance and are subject to abatement as hereinafter provided. 
(Ord. No. 2021 § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 38-112. - Definitions. 
(a)  Calendar year as used herein , means that period of time beginning January 1 and ending December 31 of the same year. 
(b)  Weeds as used herein , means any of the following: 
(1)  Brush and woody vines shall be classified as weeds; 
(2)  Vegetation and indigenous grasses which may attain such large growth as to become, when dry, a fire menace to adjacent improved property; 
(3)  Vegetation which bears or may bear seeds of a downy or wingy nature; 
(4)  Vegetation which is located in an area which harbors rats, insects, animals, reptiles, or any other creature which either may or does constitute a menace to health, public safety, or welfare; 
(5)  Vegetation and indigenous grasses on or about property which, because of its height, has a blighting influence on a neighborhood. Any such vegetation and indigenous grasses shall be presumed to be blighting if they exceed 12 inches in height. 
(Ord. No. 2021 § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 38-113. - Public officer; notice to remove. 
    The city manager shall designate a public officer to be charged with the administration and enforcement of this article. The public officer shall notify in writing the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of any property in the city upon which weeds exist in violation of this article, by first class mail or by personal service, once per calendar year. Such notice shall include the following: 
(a)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property is in violation of the city weed control law; 
(b)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property is ordered to cut the weeds within ten days of the date of issuance of notice; 
(c)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property may request a hearing before the city manager within five days of the issuance of notice; 
(d)  That if the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property does not cut the weeds, the city or its authorized agent will cut the weeds and assesses the cost of the cutting, including a reasonable administrative fee, against the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property. That the cost of cutting or otherwise destroying weeds shall be assessed at the rate set forth in section 42-252; 
(e)  That the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property will be given an opportunity to pay the assessment, and, if it is not paid, it will be added to the property tax as a special assessment, and become a personal debt; 
(f)  That no further notice shall be given prior to removal of weeds during the current calendar year; 
(g)  That the city manager should be contacted if there are any questions regarding the notice. 
    If there is a change in the record owner of title to real property subsequent to the giving of notice pursuant to this subsection, the city may not recover any costs or levy an assessment for the costs incurred by the cutting or destruction of weeds on such property unless the new record owner of title to the real property is provided notice as required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 2406, § 1, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-114. - Abatement; assessment of costs. 
(a)  Upon the expiration of the ten-day period established in section 38-113(b), and in the event that the owner, occupant or agent in charge of the property shall neglect or fail to comply with the requirements of section 38-113, the public officer shall cause to be cut, destroyed, and/or removed all weeds and abate the nuisance created thereby at any time during the current calendar year. 
(b)  The public officer shall give notice to the owner, occupant, or agent in charge of the property, by first class mail, of the costs of abatement of the nuisance. The notice shall state that the payment is due and payable within 30 days following mailing of the notice. 
(c)  If the costs of removal or abatement remain unpaid after 30 days following mailing of notice, a record of the costs of cutting and destruction and/or removal shall be certified to the city clerk who shall cause such costs to be assessed against the particular lot or parcel of land on which the weeds were so removed, and against such lots or parcels of land in front of or abutting on such street or alley on which such weeds were so removed. The city clerk shall certify the assessment to the county clerk at the time other special assessments are certified for spreading on the tax rolls of the county. In addition to remedies available to the city to collect assessments levied against property, if any assessments for costs of abatement levied by the city in accordance with this section remain unpaid by the owner of a lot or parcel of ground, the city may collect the amount due in the same manner as a personal debt of the property owner to the city, by bringing an action in the appropriate district court. 
(Ord. No. 2406, § 2, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-115. - Right of entry. 
    The public officer, and the public officer's authorized assistants, employees, contracting agents or other representatives are hereby expressly authorized to enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for the purpose of cutting, destroying and/or removing weeds in a manner consistent with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2021 § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 38-116. - Unlawful interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, or to attempt to prevent, the public officer or the public officer's authorized representative from entering upon any lot or parcel of land, or from proceeding with cutting and destruction of weeds. Such interference shall constitute an ordinance violation. 
(Ord. No. 2021 § 1, 7-22-97) 
Sec. 38-117. - Penalty. 
    A violation of any of the provisions of this article is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. Upon a first conviction, a person shall be fined $100.00; for a second conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $300.00 shall be imposed; and for a third and subsequent conviction within a five-year period of time, a fine of $500.00 shall be imposed. 
(Ord. No. 2406, § 3, 5-13-08) 
Sec. 38-118. - Noxious weeds. 
(a)  Nothing in this article shall affect or impair the rights of the city under the provisions of Chapter 2, Article 13 of the Kansas Statutes Annotated, relating to the control and eradication of certain noxious weeds. 
(b)  For the purpose of this action, the term noxious weeds shall mean kudzu (Pueraria lobata), field bindweed (Convolvulus arvensis), Russian knapweed (Centaurea picris), hoary cress (Lepidium draba), Canada thistle (Cirsium arvense), quackgrass (Agropyron repens), leafy spurge (Euphorbia esula), burragweed (Franseria tomentose and discolor), pignut (Hoffmannseggia densiflora), musk (nodding) thistle (Carduus nutans L.), and Johnson grass (Sorghum halepense). 
(Ord. No. 2021 § 1, 7-22-97) 
ARTICLE IV. - GRAFFITI 

Sec. 38-120. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Aerosol paint container means any aerosol container that is adapted or made for the purpose of applying spray paint or other substances capable of defacing property. 
    Broad-tipped marker means any felt tip indelible marker or similar implement with a flat or angled writing surface that, at its broadest width, is greater than one-fourth of an inch, containing ink or other pigmented liquid that is not water soluble. 
    Enforcement/eradication personnel means staff of the city, including city manager, the designee(s) of the city manager or any law enforcement officer of the police department. 
    Etching equipment means any tool, device or substance that can be used to make permanent marks on any natural or man-made surface. 
    Graffiti means any unauthorized inscription, word, figure, painting or other defacement that is written, marked, etched, scratched, sprayed, drawn, painted or engraved on or otherwise affixed to any surface of public or private property by any graffiti implement, to the extent that the graffiti was not authorized in advance by the owner or occupant of the property, or, despite advance authorization, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance by the city. 
    Graffiti implement means an aerosol paint container, broad-tipped marker, paint stick or graffiti stick, which is capable of leaving a visible mark on any natural or man-made surface. 
    Paint stick or graffiti stick means any device containing a solid form of paint, chalk, wax, epoxy, or other similar substance capable of being applied to a surface by pressure and leaving a mark of at least one-eighth of an inch in width. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, cooperative association, private corporation, personal representative, receiver, trustee, assignee or any other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 1973, § 2, 8-27-96) 
Sec. 38-121. - Prohibited acts. 
(a)  Defacement. It shall be unlawful for any person to apply graffiti to any natural or man-made surface on any public property or private property, without the permission of the owner or occupant. 
(b)  Possession of graffiti implements. 
(1)  At or near school facilities. It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of eighteen years to possess any graffiti implement while on any public or private school property, grounds, facilities, buildings or structures, or in areas immediately adjacent to those specific locations.
