Sec. 74-38. - Prohibited material. 
    The following materials or substances shall be prohibited from being placed in city refuse containers: 
(a)  All liquids. 
(b)  All medical service waste generated through human or animal care through inpatient or outpatient services. 
(c)  All unprocessed animal matter intended for consumption by animals but not yet processed. 
(d)  All building contractor waste. 
(e)  Any items not considered by definition as ?trash? shall be prohibited from being placed in city refuse containers. 
(Ord. No. 2129 § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 74-39. - Reserved. 
Sec. 74-40. - Landfill. 
    The landfill for the city, and all facilities thereon, shall be under the control and supervision of the owner of the landfill, and all rules and regulations for use of the landfill shall be governed by the owner. 
(Code 1968, § 13-15; Ord. No. 1904, § 12, 4-25-95) 
Sec. 74-41. - Violations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any premises within the city, either as owner or tenant thereof, in a manner as to become offensive, dangerous, or annoying to the public, or to persons residing in the vicinity, or dangerous or injurious to the public health. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of medical services waste in city refuse containers. The state department of health and environment and state department of human resource, industrial safety and health section shall be notified in writing of any violation. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of unprocessed animal waste intended for consumption by animals in city refuse containers. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of building contractor waste in city refuse containers. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of refuse in city containers who have not contracted with the city for refuse collection and disposal service, or who do not reside within the city limits. 
(Code 1968, § 13-16; Ord. No. 1904, § 13, 4-25-95) 
Chapter 78 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Consumption of alcoholic liquor in public places, § 6-133; moving of buildings, § 18-236 et seq.; fees pertaining to streets, sidewalks and other public places, § 42-471 et seq.; traffic and vehicles, ch. 86; streets trees and other trees on public property, § 94-61 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 78-1. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. If any person shall continue any obstruction or make any unlawful use, as provided by this chapter, after being notified by the chief of police to remove the same or cease to make unlawful use of such place each day's continuance shall constitute a separate offense and punishable hereunder. 
(Code 1968, §§ 25-1, 25-31) 
Sec. 78-2. - Permit for construction along streets. 
    Before any person shall begin any excavation along or adjacent to any street or sidewalk in the city or the construction, remodeling or repairing of any structure so located, application shall be made to the city clerk for a permit when it is proposed to use or encumber the sidewalks, streets, alleys or public ways of the city during the course of such work; provided, that an application for a building permit for such construction or improvement shall be deemed to satisfy this section when the permit therefor shall authorize the use or encumbering of the public ways in the city. The application shall be referred to the city manager, or designee, for approval before a permit is issued and the city manager may refer the application to the governing body when it is proposed to close off any portion of a sidewalk, street or alley from public travel during the course of work; provided further, that no sidewalk, curb or pavement shall be cut, destroyed or removed hereunder, except as authorized by ordinance. Upon the issuance of any permit and before the work shall begin, the permit holder shall submit plans for constructing a temporary walk when the sidewalk is to be closed and a plan for protecting the traveling public during such time. The city manager shall direct the permit holder to erect and maintain suitable fences, barricades or other structures to safeguard the public from injury and shall cause warning lights to be placed and maintained during the nighttime. Upon completion of the work on the abutting lot, the contractor or person in charge shall clean up the sidewalk or public way within not less than ten days after the completion of the work. 
(Code 1968, § 25-2) 
Sec. 78-3. - Removal of barricades or lights. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, throw down, run down, destroy, carry away, or otherwise injure any barricade, structure or railing constructed and maintained in accordance with section 78-2, or to remove, carry away, interfere with or injure any lights, warning lights or flares along or about any such work during the time they are in use. 
(Code 1968, § 25-3) 
Sec. 78-4. - Encroachments generally. 
(a)  The word "encroachment" when used in this section shall mean and include any sign, awning, canopy, marquee, billboard or other advertising device, merchandise stand or display, building or other structure, or other use for private purposes of any character which exists in or rests upon or projects above the right-of-way or any portion thereof of a public street. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful, except as hereinafter provided, for any person to erect, construct, install, place, maintain or allow to remain or to permit the erection, construction, installation, placing, maintenance or remaining of any encroachment upon or above the right-of-way, or any portion thereof, of the following designated streets or portions of streets: 
(1)  Main Street, from Maple Street to Fulton Street; 
(2)  Fulton Street, from Main Street to First Street; 
(3)  Kansas Avenue, from Third Street to Center Street; 
(4)  Jones Avenue, from Taylor Street to the west city limits. 
(c)  Any encroachment existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section was derived under a valid permit from the city may be continued for a period of 15 years after December 15, 1966 unless discontinued or unless the same shall become defective and unsafe prior to the expiration of such period, in which case the same shall be removed by the owner or person permitting the erection, construction, installation, placing or maintenance of the same. 
(d)  Whenever any encroachment exists in violation of the provisions of this section, the governing body shall direct the city clerk to forthwith issue notice requiring the removal of such encroachment within a time specified in such notice. If the owner of such encroachment, or agent, is known, such notice shall be a written notice served in person or by mail upon such owner or agent. If the owner or agent is unknown, such notice shall be published once in the official city paper. If the owner or agent shall fail or refuse to remove the encroachment within the time fixed in the notice, the city shall cause the encroachment to be removed. 
(Code 1968, §§ 25-146-25-149) 
Sec. 78-5. - Storage on sidewalks. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to store, place, leave or allow to be left on any sidewalk or traffic way of the city any item longer than is reasonably necessary for unloading the same; provided, that where any sidewalk is not less than ten feet wide, occupants of any premises or building fronting thereon may place benches or chairs which occupy a space on such sidewalk not exceeding three feet from the property line and the same shall not interfere with public travel thereon; provided further, that the governing body may grant a temporary permit for limited times only for the sidewalks or streets to be used by the occupants of the premises adjacent thereto and the same shall not endanger or inconvenience the public. The city reserves the right at any time upon notice to the owner or occupant who shall have obstructed the street or sidewalk to remove any obstruction at the expense of the owner or occupant. 
(Code 1968, § 25-4) 
Sec. 78-6. - Cellar entrance regulations. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave unprotected or leave open a cellar or basement door or any hole or opening in any sidewalk in the city or permit the same to remain or be in an insecure or unsafe condition. 
(Code 1968, § 25-5) 
Sec. 78-7. - Curbside mailboxes. 
    Whenever the United States Postal Service requires curbside mail delivery, the owners of lots adjacent to the parking area may construct a mail box and single support post, in such a manner that the mail box shall not protrude or extend beyond the house side of the support post, nor shall the mail box extend beyond the inside of the curb on the street side of the support post, and the center of such support post shall not be located more than nine inches from the house side of the existing curb. 
(Code 1968, § 25-9) 
Sec. 78-8. - Trespassing on parking. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive over, ride or cross any portion of the street parking, either with vehicles or livestock, which shall be adjacent to the premises of any person owning or occupying property, which parking shall have been prepared, plotted and maintained as parking for such premises. It shall be further unlawful for any person to drive a motor vehicle over a curb, sidewalk or parking area, except at an established entrance; provided, that the governing body may authorize the owner of abutting property to use the unimproved parking adjacent to any street for the standing or parking of vehicles when the curb shall have been removed and such portion of the street shall be improved for such purposes at the expense of the abutting property owner. 
(Code 1968, § 25-10) 
Sec. 78-9. - Snow and ice removal. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of ground adjoining or abutting upon any public street or public way within the city wherein a sidewalk is located, to remove from such sidewalk all snow and ice accumulations, in a manner to allow for the safe and unimpeded travel of pedestrians. 
Sec. 78-10. - Discharge of air conditioners. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to accumulate any wastewater or fluid discharges from any air conditioning or refrigeration units and to cast or discharge the same into or upon any street, alley or public way of the city; provided, that all accumulations of such wastes or discharges upon private premises found to be a nuisance may be abated as provided by ordinance; provided further, that this section shall not be construed to deny the disposal of such wastes or discharges on private premises in accordance with the plumbing code or by means of disposal wells. 
(Code 1968, § 25-20) 
Sec. 78-11. - Culverts. 
    Culverts may be constructed or maintained across any drainage ditch or drain when it shall be impracticable to open, construct, or maintain an entrance across any such ditch or drain, upon application to and the approval of the city engineer. All such culverts shall be placed and constructed in accordance with the standard specifications and plans established by the engineer for such purposes. The abutting landowner shall pay the cost of all such culverts in the manner provided by law. 
(Code 1968, § 25-60) 
Sec. 78-12. - Building materials; barricades. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any building materials, vehicles or like obstructions in or on any street, alley, sidewalk or public way in the city during the course of any improvement unless the same be guarded by barricades at all times or in the nighttime unless any such work or obstruction be guarded with red lanterns or lights sufficient in number and so placed as to guard vehicles and passersby from injury or danger. All such lights shall be lighted before dark and left lighted during the nighttime; provided, that it shall be the duty of any officer or employee of the city having charge of any such work for the city to comply with the provisions of this section and the laws of the state pertaining thereto and to maintain the required barricades, signs and lights as in the case of other persons; provided further, that the street superintendent is authorized to direct the placing of any barricades, warning or detour signs or lights required by law, and said officer is authorized, if the public safety requires it, to close off the public streets or sidewalks or any portion thereof to prevent the use of the same during the progress of any work. 
(Code 1968, § 25-64) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 
Sec. 78-13. - Health, safety, and welfare regulations. 
    The authority of a person or utility to use and occupy the public right-of-way shall always be subject and subordinate to the reasonable public health, safety and welfare requirements and regulations of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 1, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-14. - Specific portions of right-of-way restricted. 
(a)  The city shall have the authority to prohibit the use or occupation of a specific portion of public right-of-way by a person or utility due to a reasonable public interest, necessitated by public health, safety and welfare, based upon a recommendation of the city engineer, and which is nondiscriminatory among all authorized persons or utilities. 
(b)  If the city denies a request to use or occupy a specific portion of the public right-of-way, the person or utility shall be served a notice of such denial by first class mail. The notice shall indicate that the person or utility shall have ten days from the date of receipt of the notice to request a public hearing by the governing body concerning the denial. Failure to make a timely request for a hearing shall constitute a waiver of the person's or utility's right to contest the denial before the governing body. The hearing shall be held by the governing body, within 30 days after the filing of the request therefor, and the person or utility shall be advised by the city of the time and place of the hearing. Following the public hearing, if the governing body denies the request to use or occupy a specific portion of the public right-of-way, such determination may be appealed to district court. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 1, 11-14-06) 
Secs. 78-15-78-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 78-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Excavation means the disturbance to the existing surface of the public right-of-way, including backfilling and surface restoration, in any manner whatsoever other than normal maintenance performed by the city street department. The term shall also include excavations made on private property which removes or imperils the lateral support of a public right-of-way. 
    Facility includes line, fiber optic cable, tower, pipe, pipeline, tube, main, service, trap, vent, vault, manhole, meter, gauge, regulator, valve, conduit, wire, tower, pole, pole line, anchor, cable, junction box, service box, pedestal, antennae, transformer or other material, structure, or object of any kind or character, which is or may be lawfully constructed, left, placed, or maintained in, upon, along, across, under or over any public right-of-way. 
    Public right-of-way means only the area of real property in which the city has a dedicated or acquired right-of-way interest in the real property, including the area on, below or above the present and future streets, alleys, avenues, roads, highways, parkways, or boulevards, or easements dedicated or acquired as public right-of-way, or public utility easements. The term does not include real property owned by the city, unless specifically authorized by an easement or other agreement. The term does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to wireless telecommunications or other nonwire telecommunications or broadcast service, private easements obtained by utilities or private easements in platted subdivisions or tracts. 
    Standard plans and specifications means standards for excavations in public rights-of-way approved and adopted by the city, and as may be amended from time to time. 
    Utility means a private company and/or corporation authorized by franchise or other agreement to use and occupy public right-of-way, or city department, which provides a particular service to the public. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-42. - Permits required; applications; fees; bond. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person or utility to make an excavation in any public right-of-way without first obtaining a permit for such purposes from the city. Provided, that an annual blanket excavation permit may be issued to a utility; further provided that city departments are exempt from the permitting requirement. 
(b)  The application for an excavation permit shall show the name and address of the applicant, name and address of person performing the work if not the applicant, the location and nature of the work involved and the approximate starting and completion dates of such work, including backfilling, surface restoration and removal of all obstructions, material and debris. Adjustment to the terms of the excavation permit may be granted by the city engineer or assistant, for good and sufficient cause. 
(c)  The permit may require the work to be done without making any excavation or cutting any street pavement; provided that utility mains and service lines may be installed prior to permanent street or alley improvements, the places reserved for such utility mains. 
(d)  The application for an excavation permit shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established in section 42-471(1) of this Code. An annual blanket excavation permit application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established in section 42-471(2) of this Code. 
(e)  In the case of an annual blanket excavation permit, the permittee shall provide written notification, on a weekly basis, to the city engineer of all excavations work. City departments shall provide such notification. 
(f)  Before an excavation permit as herein provided is issued, the applicant shall deposit with the city clerk a surety bond in the amount of $10,000.00 for each single excavation permit, or $50,000.00 for each annual blanket excavation permit, payable to the city, unless the applicant can provide another form of surety or proof of sufficient solvency, to satisfy the city attorney. Only one $10,000.00 surety bond shall be required annually for each applicant for a single excavation permit, regardless of the number of single excavation permits issued to an applicant during a year. The required surety bond must be: 
(1)  With good and sufficient surety; 
(2)  By a surety company authorized to transact business in the state; 
(3)  Satisfactory to the city attorney in form and substance; and 
(4)  Conditioned upon the permittee's compliance with this article and to secure and hold the city and its officers and employees harmless against any and all claims, judgments, or other costs arising from the excavation and other work covered by the excavation permit or for which the city or any city officer or employee may be made liable by reason of any accident or injury to persons or property through the fault of the permittee, either in not properly guarding the excavation or for any other injury resulting from the negligence of the permittee, and further conditioned to restore all excavations made in compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-43. - Plans, specifications adopted. 
    The standard plans and specifications for excavations and placement of utilities in public rights-of-way, as contained in the GENERAL IMPROVEMENTS HANDBOOK, CITY OF GARDEN CITY, 2017, prepared by the city engineer, are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2356, § 1, 12-12-06; Ord. No. 2770-2017, § 1, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 78-44. - Restoration; costs. 
(a)  Any person or utility authorized or permitted to use the public right-of-way is hereby required to repair all damage to the public right-of-way, and the adjacent impacted area, caused by the activities of that person or utility, while occupying, installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in the public right-of-way and to return the right-of-way, to its functional equivalence before the damage pursuant to the reasonable requirements and specifications of the city; provided that where restoration work is not completed by the permit holder in accordance with the standard plans and specifications, the city may remove and replace such work at the cost of the permit holder and the city may refuse to issue permits for additional work to such person unless such charges against them have been paid. The city reserves the right to restore any excavation, at its option, such restoration to be a charge against the permit holder. 
(b)  Permit holder shall be responsible for any and all repairs or additional restoration work required by the city within one year of the date of acceptance by the city engineer of the original restoration work. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-45. - Open excavations; building materials; barricade. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave any excavation open or uncovered, or to leave any building materials, vehicles or other obstructions, in any public right-of-way in the city during the course of any excavation work unless such excavation be guarded by barricades at all times. It shall be the duty of any officer or employee of the city, having charge of any such work, to comply with the provisions of the article and applicable laws of the state. The street superintendent is authorized to place such barricades and other devices as required and to close off the public streets, sidewalks or portions thereof, if necessary to ensure public safety, to prevent the use of same during the course of any work; provided that when any barricades or other devices are placed by the city due to the permit holders refusal or negligence, such barricades or devices shall be charged against the permit holder. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-46. - Obstruction of drainage and protection of storm sewer. 
(a)  The permit holder shall maintain all gutters, and other drainage facilities of the city, free and unobstructed for the full depth of the adjacent curb and for at least two feet from the face of the curb at any gutter. 
(b)  The permit holder shall be required to take measures to protect the storm sewer system from excessive contamination from permitted activities. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-47. - Care of excavated material. 
    All material piled adjacent to any excavation shall be maintained in such a manner as not to endanger those working in the excavation, pedestrians or vehicular traffic. The city engineer or assistant, may require the permit holder to remove excavated material from the work site. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-48. - Noise, dust and debris. 
    In the performance of the excavation work, the permit holder shall take appropriate measures to reduce, to the fullest extent practicable, noise, dust and debris. Except during emergency situations, no excavation work shall be performed between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. which would produce noise of sufficient volume to disturb the sleep of occupants of neighboring property. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-49. - Clearance for emergency facilities. 
    Excavation work shall be performed and conducted so as not to interfere with access to fire hydrants, fire stations, fire escapes or any other emergency facilities designated by the city engineer. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-50. - Protection of utilities, relocations. 
(a)  The permit holder shall be responsible for locating utilities, using the "Kansas One Call" system, prior to excavating. The permit holder shall not interfere with any existing facility without prior written consent of the city engineer and the owner of the facility. Facility relocations shall be performed by the owner. No facility shall be relocated unless the cost of such relocation is borne by the permit holder. The permit holder shall support and protect all facilities, which may be affected by the excavation work, until final backfill compaction and/or surface restoration has been completed. Should any facility be damaged during any excavation work, the permit holder shall promptly notify the owner thereof. Repair of such damage shall be the responsibility of the owner, unless otherwise directed, and shall be at the expense of the permit holder; provided that should such damage be the result of the facility owner's negligence, repair of such damage shall be the responsibility of the owner. The permit holder shall inform itself as to the existence and location and depth of all underground facilities within the excavation area prior to any work and protect the same against damage. 
(b)  Whenever requested by the city, in order to accomplish construction and maintenance activities directly related to improvements for the health, safety and welfare of the public, a person or utility promptly shall remove its facilities from the public right-of-way or shall relocate or adjust its facilities within the public right-of-way at no cost to the city. Such relocation or adjustment shall be completed as soon as reasonably possible within the time set forth in any request by the city for such relocation or adjustment. Any damages suffered by the city or its contractors as a result of such person's or utility's failure to timely relocate or adjust its facilities shall be borne by such person or utility. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-51. - Abandonment of underground facilities. 
    Whenever the use of an underground facility is abandoned in place except the abandonment of service lines three inches or less in diameter serving a single property, the facility owner shall file a written statement, within 30 days, to the city engineer detailing the abandoned facility. If such abandoned facility is in the way, or subsequently becomes in the way, of an installation of the city installation, the owner shall remove the abandoned facility, or portions thereof, or pay the cost of such removal, during the course of excavation for the city installation. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-52. - Backfill; restoration and cleanup. 
(a)  The permit holder shall backfill the excavation in accordance with the standard plans and specifications. The permit holder may be required to furnish soils tests at the expense of the permit holder. 
(b)  As the excavation work progresses, all public rights-of-way shall be thoroughly cleaned of all rubbish, excess earth or other debris resulting from such work. Such cleanup work shall be at the expense of the permit holder. The permit holder may be required to perform periodic cleanup work during the progress of the work. The permit holder shall perform cleanup work upon completion of the work or within 24 hours of notification, failure to do so may result in the cleanup being performed by the city and such costs being charged to the permit holder. When excavation work is in landscaped areas, the area shall be reestablished in a like manner upon completion. Trees and shrubs shall not be removed, even temporarily, without first obtaining consent from the city engineer or assistant. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-53. - Pavement restoration. 
    Upon completion of backfilling, permanent pavement patching shall be accomplished in accordance with the standard plans and specifications. Use of temporary pavement materials shall be authorized by the city engineer or assistant in advance. The permit holder shall be responsible for maintaining any temporary surfacing until the permanent patch may be completed. Failure of the permit holder to maintain the temporary surface within four hours may result in such work being performed by the city and charged to the permit holder. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-54. - Emergency excavations. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prevent any excavations as may be necessary for the protection of life or property, whether public or private, or to prevent damage to the public right-of-way and improvements thereon, provided that the person making such excavation apply for a permit on the first working day after such work is commenced; and in the case of an annual blanket permit holder, such work shall be noted on their weekly submittal. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-55. - Preservation of survey markers. 
    Any survey marker set for the purpose of locating or preserving the lines of any public right-of-way or private property, or any survey bench mark, shall not be removed or disturbed without obtaining written permission from the city engineer. Permission to remove or disturb such survey marker or bench mark shall be granted upon the condition that restoration of such markers shall be at the expense of the permit holder. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-56. - Inspections. 
    The city engineer shall make such inspections as are necessary in the enforcement of this article. The city engineer shall have the authority to promulgate and cause to be enforced such rules and regulations as may be necessary to enforce and carry out the intent of this article. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-57. - Maintenance of facility records. 
    Every person owning, using, controlling or having an interest in facilities within public rights-of-way, shall have on file with the city engineer, maps, and other drawings, showing the location, size and kind of installation of all facilities, except service lines serving a single property. Annually, at a time specified by the city engineer, corrected maps shall be filed. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Sec. 78-58. - Indemnity. 
(a)  The permit holder shall indemnify and hold the city and its officers and employees harmless against any and all claims, lawsuits, judgments, costs, liens, losses, expenses, fees (including reasonable attorney fees and costs of defense), proceedings, actions, demands, causes of action, liability and suits of any kind and nature, including personal or bodily injury (including death), property damage or other harm for which recovery of damages is sought, to the extent that it is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be caused by the negligence of the permit holder, any agent, officer, director, representative, employee, affiliate or subcontractor of the permit holder, or their respective officers, agents, employees, directors or representatives, while installing, repairing or maintaining facilities in the public right-of-way. 
(b)  The indemnity provided by this subsection does not apply to any liability resulting from the negligence of the city, its officers, employees, contractors or subcontractors. If a permit holder and the city, are found jointly liable by a court of competent jurisdiction, liability shall be apportioned comparatively in accordance with the laws of this state without, however, waiving any governmental immunity available to the city under state law and without waiving any defenses of the parties under state or federal law. 
(c)  This section is solely for the benefit of the city and the permit holder and does not create or grant any rights, contractual or otherwise, to any other person or entity. 
(Ord. No. 2350, § 2, 11-14-06) 
Sec. 78-59. - Penalty. 
(a)  The date for return of streets and alleys to original configuration as specified in this article shall be firm and realistic in order to allow for rescheduling of traffic, solid waste collection, etc. If the street or alley has not been restored by the declared date, except delays caused by acts of God, the permit holder shall be subject to a fine of $50.00 per day for each and every day beyond the declared date until such street or alley is restored. 
(b)  If it becomes necessary for the city to perform any work which is the responsibility of the permit holder, such work shall be billed to the permit holder. Failure to pay such charges may result in the city withholding approval for future work requiring permits under this article. 
(Code 1968, § 25-65) 
Secs. 78-60-78-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Sidewalk construction and repair, K.S.A. 12-1801 et seq. 

Sec. 78-76. - Standard specifications; permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, reconstruct or repair any sidewalk or driveway in the city, except as herein provided. All such sidewalk work shall be performed in strict conformity with the standard specifications adopted by the governing body for such work. Before any sidewalk shall be constructed, reconstructed or repaired, the person, before commencing such work, shall obtain a permit from the city engineer. 
(b)  The application in each case shall be accompanied by fees in the amount established in section 42-472. The permit issued pursuant to this article shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1968, § 25-32) 
Sec. 78-77. - Adoption of specifications. 
    The standard plans and specifications for the construction, reconstruction and repair of sidewalks, as contained in the GENERAL IMPROVEMENTS HANDBOOK, CITY OF GARDEN CITY, 2017, prepared by the city engineer, are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2356, § 1, 12-12-06; Ord. No. 2770-2017, § 2, 9-5-17) 
Sec. 78-78. - Grades and locations. 
(a)  Where no sidewalk has been established, the city engineer may establish the grade. 
(b)  The city engineer will determine the type of sidewalk and/or driveway which may be permitted in any given location in conformity with the provisions of this article. Sidewalks must be of the same type and of the same width on the street frontage in any given block. 
(Code 1968, § 25-35) 
Sec. 78-79. - Supervision. 
    Any sidewalks and driveways constructed, reconstructed or repaired under the provisions of this article shall be constructed under the supervision of the city engineer, except that the provisions of this article shall not be construed to apply in any way to any improvements constructed entirely upon private property. 
(Code 1968, § 25-36) 
Secs. 78-80-78-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET AND SIDEWALK CUTS 

Sec. 78-101. - Permits required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cut or destroy pavements, curbs or sidewalks, or to remove the same, for any purpose without applying for and receiving a permit for such purposes from the city clerk. The permit issued pursuant to the requirements of this section shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issue. 
(Code 1968, § 25-55) 
Sec. 78-102. - Permit application; fees. 
    The application for the permit required by this article shall show the description of the property, the location of and the nature of the work to be done. The permit shall be issued only upon the approval of the city engineer. All such work shall be done and completed in accordance with the provisions of this article and the same shall be supervised by the engineer or some member of the department appointed for the purpose. The application in each case shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount established in section 48-473. 
(Code 1968, § 25-56) 
Sec. 78-103. - Replacement; backfill; costs. 
    In every case, except where otherwise required by law, the cost of restoring any pavement, curb or sidewalk, removed in accordance with this article, shall be at the expense of the person holding the permit. The city reserves the right to restore the public work removed at its option, the same to be a charge against the permit holder. 
(Code 1968, § 25-57) 
Sec. 78-104. - Curb cuts. 
    Where curbs are cut or removed or cut and replaced, all such work shall be done at the expense of the person having a permit or other authority for such purpose. Where the curb shall be replaced, the work shall be done in accordance with the standard specifications and plans therefor established by the city engineer and kept on file in the office of the city clerk and the city engineer. It shall be unlawful for any person to change the grade of any curbline in replacing any curb, or to fail to replace curb, and it shall be further unlawful to bridge any curb and gutter or to place any building materials therein to establish a crossing from the street to any private premises, except temporarily during the course of any work in the making of a driveway entrance. 
(Code 1968, § 25-58) 
Sec. 78-105. - Private driveways; costs. 
    When any street is being paved and curbed, or has been paved and curbed, any person being the owner of lands abutting thereon and who may desire to construct a driveway from the curbline to the lot line may do so; provided, that required permit is obtained from the city engineer. The driveway shall be constructed under the direction of the city engineer in accordance with the standard specifications and plans established by the city engineer. All such work shall be done in such a manner as not to change or interfere with the gutter flow line or sidewalk grades where such driveway crosses any sidewalk; provided further, that where the sidewalk shall not satisfy the requirements or specifications for sidewalks used as a part of a driveway entrance, the sidewalk shall be removed and reconstructed according to the standard specifications therefor. All such work shall be done at the cost of the person owning the abutting lands. 
(Code 1968, § 25-59) 
Sec. 78-106. - Cutting and removing pavement; replacement. 
    The person having a permit or authority to cut or remove any pavement or permanent surfacing of any street shall at the discretion of the city engineer, replace the same at the expense of the permit holder, the same to be done in accordance with the specifications of the original improvement or pavement; provided, that where the work of replacement and restoration is not completed by the permit holder in accordance with the requirements of this section, the city manager may direct the proper officers of the city to remove and replace such work at the cost of the person who had begun such work and the city may refuse to grant permits for additional work of like nature to such persons unless such charges against them have been paid and satisfied. 
(Code 1968, § 25-62) 
Secs. 78-107-78-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - BUILDING NUMBERING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 18. 

Sec. 78-131. - Authorized. 
    Buildings and building sites in the city shall be numbered in accordance with the rules and regulations set forth in this article. 
(Code 1968, § 25-76) 
Sec. 78-132. - Principal baselines. 
(a)  The principal base line for numbers of buildings and building sites on the streets running north and south shall be the right-of-way of the Atchison, Topeka, and Santa Fe Railway Company. The word "North" shall prefix the names of all streets lying north of such right-of-way and the word "South" shall prefix the names of all streets lying south of such right-of-way. 
(b)  The principal baseline for numbers of buildings and building sites on the streets running east and west shall be Main Street. The word "East" shall prefix the names of all streets lying east of Main Street and the word "West" shall prefix the names of all streets lying west of Main Street. 
(c)  Numbering of blocks beginning on each side of the baselines shall start with 100 and continue numbering each block in each direction from the baselines in the hundreds successively; or until an auxiliary baseline is reached. 
(Code 1968, §§ 25-77, 25-78, 25-81, 25-82) 
Sec. 78-133. - Auxiliary baselines. 
    Due to the many irregularities in the size of blocks, in the direction and number of streets in different additions to the city, the city engineer shall establish additional, or auxiliary baselines, or correction lines, to be used in determining the proper numbers of buildings and building sites. 
Sec. 78-134. - Manner of numbering. 
    Buildings and building sites shall be so numbered that: 
(1)  Only odd numbers shall appear on the north and west sides of streets; 
(2)  Only even numbers shall appear on the south and east sides of streets; and 
(3)  No building or building site shall have the number 100 nor any exact multiple of 100; 
(4)  One number shall be assigned to each lot or space of 50 feet or less; 
(5)  In duplexes or two apartment houses on one lot, one of the units or apartments may be designated with the figure "one-half" added; 
(6)  In multiple-unit apartment buildings, each apartment or unit may be designated in numerical order, beginning with "1" or alphabetical order beginning with "A." 
(Code 1968, §§ 25-79, 25-80) 
Sec. 78-135. - Map to govern; engineer to assign numbers. 
    The city engineer shall prepare a master house number map of the city. In case of doubt or where a question arises as to the proper number to be assigned to any lot or building, the city engineer shall decide the question and fix the number of such lot or building. 
Sec. 78-136. - Placement, style of numbers. 
    All buildings shall have conspicuously placed, upon the front of the building, the number provided by this article. All buildings that may be erected or relocated after the taking effect of this article shall be numbered as herein provided prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy. The numbers shall be at least three inches in height so as to be easily seen from the street. 
(Code 1968, §§ 25-87, 25-88) 
Secs. 78-137-78-155. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - GARDEN CITY EXHIBITION AREA[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 66. 

Sec. 78-156. - Objectives. 
    The governing body hereby establishes the policy and procedure governing the use of the city exhibition area. The objective of this policy is to set forth the permitted usage of such facility commensurate with the original design, the applicable laws of the city, county, and the state, as well as the wishes of prospective users. The term prospective users is defined as follows: Units of government (military and civil), corporations, organizations, and individual persons who agree to and act in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1968, § 25-168) 
Sec. 78-157. - Permitted usage. 
    The following uses at the city exhibition area are deemed appropriate: 
(1)  Parking for adjacent functions. 
(2)  Outdoor exhibit space when required by adjacent function in the fairground property. 
(3)  Drivers training instruction. 
(4)  Automobile, truck and implement shows. 
(5)  Fair and carnival exhibits provided that no grounding stakes be driven into or through the hard surfacing. 
(6)  Any uses deemed as incidental and/or accessory to those listed above. 
(Code 1968, § 25-169) 
Sec. 78-158. - Nonpermitted usage. 
    All uses/activities not permitted under section 78-157 are prohibited: 
(Code 1968, § 25-170) 
Sec. 78-159. - Fees. 
    There shall be no fee required for the use of the city exhibition area except for the condition noted below when required: 
(1)  Electric power. The city has electric power available on site. If an organization or individual desires electricity, the request shall be made to the city manager and utility superintendent no later than one week prior to the date required. The fee levied by the city will be only that which is necessary to cover the cost of power supply to the area and shall be based upon the meter reading for the period specified. The utility department of the city shall maintain complete administrative and functional control of the electrical supply system on site. 
(2)  Traffic control/police protection. The city shall make available upon request traffic control and/or police protection personnel. The request for such services shall be made to the city manager and chief of police no later than two weeks prior to the date required. The fee levied by the city for the above services shall be only that which is required to adequately staff for the request on a per-man-per-hour basis. 
(3)  Trash pickup and disposal. The city shall make available upon request trash pickup and disposal service. The request for such service shall be made to the city manager and superintendent of sanitation no later than one week prior to the date required. The fees for such service shall be as established in section 42-474. 
(Code 1968, § 25-171) 
Sec. 78-160. - Liability. 
    In general, the city will in no way be held responsible for or liable to any unit of government, organization, corporation or individual for actions resulting in damages to property, injury of persons, or theft of property. Further clarification is as follows: 
(1)  Prior approval for use. When a request for use of the facility has been made prior to the date needed, the organization or individual involved shall validate by signature, a waiver of all liability to the city on a form acceptable to the same. 
(2)  No prior approval for use. When an organization or individual utilizes the facility without prior approval or knowledge of the city, but in accordance with the activities as outlined in section 78-157, the city shall not be held liable. 
(3)  Unauthorized use. When an organization or individual utilizes the facility in a manner as outlined in section 78-158, or in any manner not allowed by the applicable laws of the city, county, or state, the city shall not be held liable. 
(Code 1968, § 25-172) 
Chapter 82 - TAXATION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-436 et seq.; businesses, ch. 22; fees pertaining to taxation, § 42-501 et seq; city exempted from certain tax limits, app. A, Charter Ord. No. 20. 

Sec. 82-1. - Retailers' sales tax. 
(a)  A retailers' sales tax in the amount of one-half of one percent is levied in the city according to K.S.A. 12-187 et seq. The retailers' sales tax shall take effect on October 1, 2015, or on the earliest date thereafter that the Kansas Department of Revenue can begin collecting such retailers' sales tax, and shall expire on the date ten years after it is first levied, unless repealed earlier by an ordinance of the city. 
(b)  Except as may otherwise be provided by law, such tax shall be identical in its application and exemptions to the Kansas Retailers' Sales Tax Act and all laws and administrative rules and regulations of the Kansas Department of Revenue relating to the state retailers' sales tax shall apply to such city retailers' sales tax insofar as such laws and regulations may be made applicable. The services of the department of revenue shall be utilized to administer, enforce and collect such tax. 
(Code 1968, § 2-12.2.1; Ord. No. 2703-2015, §§ 1, 2, 8-4-15) 
State Law reference- Authority for above tax, K.S.A. 12-189. 
Chapter 86 - TRAFFIC AND VEHICLES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Moving of buildings, § 18-236 et seq.; abandoned or wrecked motor vehicles, § 38-56 et seq.; fees pertaining to traffic and vehicles, § 42-521 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 78; vehicles for hire, ch. 98. 
State Law reference- Uniform act regulating traffic on highways, K.S.A. 8-1401 et seq.; general powers of local authorities, K.S.A. 8-2002. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 86-1. - Reserved. 
Sec. 86-2. - Standard Traffic Ordinance. 
(a)  Incorporating Standard Traffic Ordinance. There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating traffic within the corporate limits of the City of Garden City, Kansas, that certain standard traffic ordinance known as the "Standard Traffic Ordinance for Kansas Cities," Edition of 2018, prepared and published in book form by the League of Kansas Municipalities, Topeka, Kansas, hereinafter referred to as Standard Traffic Ordinance, save and except such articles, sections, parts, or portions as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified, added, or amended. No fewer than three copies of said Standard Traffic Ordinance shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as Adopted by Ordinance No. 2799-2018," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be omitted or changed clearly marked to show any such omission or change and to which shall be attached a copy of this ordinance, and filed with the City Clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge, city attorney, city prosecutor, and all administrative departments of the city charged with enforcement of the ordinance shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of such Standard Traffic Ordinance similarly marked, as may be deemed expedient. All references to the Standard Traffic Ordinance as adopted and incorporated into this Code shall be in a form designating section 86-2 followed in parenthesis followed by the section number of the Standard Traffic Ordinance, as incorporated. (For example, section 33 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance as incorporated shall be referred to as section 86-2(33).) 
(b)  Amendment. The following section of the Standard Traffic Ordinance is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 30. Driving Under the Influence of Intoxicating Liquor or Drugs; Penalties. 
(a)  Driving under the influence is operating or attempting to operate any vehicle within this city while: 
(1)  The alcohol concentration in the person's blood or breath as shown by any competent evidence, including other competent evidence, is .08 or more; 
(2)  The alcohol concentration in the person's blood or breath, as measured within three (3) hours of the time of operating or attempting to operate a vehicle, is .08 or more; 
(3)  Under the influence of alcohol to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle; 
(4)  Under the influence of any drug or combination of drugs to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle; or 
(5)  Under the influence of a combination of alcohol and any drug or drugs to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle. 
(b)  No person shall operate or attempt to operate any vehicle within this city if the person is a habitual user of any narcotic, hypnotic, somnifacient, or stimulating drug. 
(c)  If a person is charged with a violation of this section involving drugs, the fact that the person is or has been entitled to use the drug under the laws of this state shall not constitute a defense against the charge. 
(d)  Upon a first conviction of a violation of this section, a person shall be sentenced to not less than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours nor more than six (6) months imprisonment, or in the court's discretion one hundred (100) hours of public service, and be fined $1,000. The person convicted must serve at least forty-eight (48) consecutive hours imprisonment or one hundred (100) hours of public service either before or as a condition of any grant of probation or suspension, reduction of sentence or parole. 
(e)  On a second conviction of a violation of this section, a person shall be sentenced to not less than ninety (90) days nor more than one (1) year imprisonment and be fined $1,750. The person convicted must serve at least ten (10) consecutive days imprisonment before the person is granted probation, suspension, or reduction of sentence or parole or is otherwise released. 
(f)  In addition, prior to sentencing for any conviction, the court shall order the person to participate in an alcohol and drug evaluation conducted by a provider in accordance with K.S.A. 8-1008, and amendments thereto. The person shall be required to follow any recommendation made by the provider after such evaluation, unless otherwise ordered by the court. 
(g)  Any person eighteen (18) years of age or older convicted of violating this section who had one or more children under the age of eighteen (18) years in the vehicle at the time of the offense shall have such person's punishment enhanced by one (1) month of imprisonment. This imprisonment must be served consecutively to any other minimum mandatory penalty imposed for a violation of this section. Any enhanced penalty imposed shall not exceed the maximum sentence allowable by law. 
(h)  If a person is charged with a violation of this section involving drugs, the fact that the person is or has been entitled to use the drug under the laws of this state shall not constitute a defense against the charge. 
(i)  The court may establish the terms and time for payment of any fines, fees, assessments, and costs imposed pursuant to this section. Any assessment and costs shall be required to be paid not later than ninety (90) days after imposed, and any remainder of the fine shall be paid prior to the final release of the defendant by the court. 
(j)  In lieu of payment of a fine imposed pursuant to this section, the court may order that the person perform community service specified by the court. The person shall receive a credit on the fine imposed in an amount equal to $5 for each full hour spent by the person in the specified community service. The community service ordered by the court shall be required to be performed not later than one (1) year after the fine is imposed, or by an earlier date specified by the court. If by the required date the person performs an insufficient amount of community service to reduce to zero (0) the portion of the fine required to be paid by the person, the remaining balance of the fine shall become due on that date. 
(k)  (1)  Except as provided in paragraph (5), in addition to any other penalty which may be imposed upon a person convicted of a violation of this section, the court may order that the convicted person's motor vehicle or vehicles be impounded or immobilized for a period not to exceed one (1) year and that the convicted person pay all towing, impoundment, and storage fees or other immobilization costs. 
(2)  The court shall not order the impoundment or immobilization of a motor vehicle driven by a person convicted of a violation of this section if the motor vehicle had been stolen or converted at the time it was driven in violation of this section. 
(3)  Prior to ordering the impoundment or immobilization of a motor vehicle or vehicles owned by a person convicted of a violation of this section, the court shall consider, but not be limited to, the following: 
(A)  Whether the impoundment or immobilization of the motor vehicle would result in the loss of employment by the convicted person or a member of such person's family; and 
(B)  Whether the ability of the convicted person or a member of such person's family to attend school or obtain medical care would be impaired. 
(4)  Any personal property in a vehicle impounded or immobilized pursuant to this subsection may be retrieved prior to or during the period of such impoundment or immobilization. 
(5)  As used in this subsection, the convicted person's motor vehicle or vehicles shall include any vehicle leased by such person. If the lease on the convicted person's motor vehicle subject to impoundment or immobilization expires in less than one (1) year from the date of the impoundment or immobilization, the time of impoundment or immobilization of such vehicle shall be the amount of the time remaining on the lease. 
(l)  The court shall electronically report every conviction of a violation of this section and every diversion agreement entered into in lieu of further criminal proceedings on a complaint alleging a violation of this section to the division including any finding regarding the alcohol concentration in the offender's blood or breath. Prior to sentencing under the provisions of this section, the court shall request and shall receive from the division a record of all prior convictions obtained against such person for any violations of any of the motor vehicle laws of this state. 
(m)  For the purposes of determining whether a conviction is a first or second conviction in sentencing under this section: 
(1)  Conviction includes being convicted of a violation of this section or entering into a diversion agreement in lieu of further criminal proceedings on a complaint alleging a violation of this section; 
(2)  Conviction includes being convicted of a violation of a law of any state or an ordinance of any city, or resolution of any county, which is comparable to this section or entering into a diversion agreement in lieu of further criminal proceedings in a case alleging a violation of such law, ordinance, or resolution; 
(3)  Only convictions occurring on or after July 1, 2001, shall be taken into account when determining the sentence to be imposed for a first or second offender. Nothing in this provision shall be construed as preventing any court from considering any convictions or diversions occurring during the person's lifetime in determining the sentence to be imposed within the limits provided for a first or second offense; 
(4)  Any convictions for a violation of the following sections occurring during a person's lifetime shall be taken into account: 
(A)  Driving a commercial motor vehicle under the influence, K.S.A. 8-2,144, and amendments thereto, or Section 30.1 of this ordinance; 
(B)  Operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs, K.S.A. 32-1131, and amendments thereto; 
(C)  Involuntary manslaughter while driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, K.S.A. 21-3442, prior to its repeal, or K.S.A. Supp. 21-5405(a)(3) or (a)(5), and amendments thereto; 
(D)  Aggravated battery as described in K.S.A. Supp. 21-5413(b)(3) or (b)(4), and amendments thereto; and 
(E)  Aggravated vehicular homicide, K.S.A. 21-3405a, prior to its repeal, or vehicular battery, K.S.A. 21-3405b, prior to its repeal, if the crime was committed while committing a violation of K.S.A. 8-1567, and amendments thereto; 
(5)  Receiving punishment under the uniform code of military justice or Kansas code of military justice for an act which was committed on a military reservation and which would constitute a crime described in subsections (m)(2) or (m)(4) if committed off a military reservation in this state; 
(6)  Multiple convictions of any crime described in subsections (m)(2) or (m)(4) arising from the same arrest shall only be counted as one conviction; 
(7)  It is irrelevant whether an offense occurred before or after conviction for a previous offense; and 
(8)  A person may enter into a diversion agreement in lieu of further criminal proceedings for a violation of this section, and amendments thereto, only once during the person's lifetime. 
(n)  For the purposes of determining whether an offense is comparable, the following shall be considered: 
(1)  The name of the out-of-jurisdiction offense; 
(2)  The elements of the out-of-jurisdiction offense; 
(3)  Whether the out-of-jurisdiction offense prohibits similar conduct prohibited by the closest approximate Kansas offense. 
(o)  Upon conviction of a person of a violation of this section, the division, upon receiving a report of conviction, shall suspend, restrict or suspend and restrict the person's driving privileges as provided by K.S.A. 8-1014, and amendments thereto. 
(p)  Upon conviction of a person of a violation of this section, the court may order the convicted person to pay restitution to any victim who suffered loss due to the violation for which the person was convicted. 
(q)  No plea bargaining agreement shall be entered into nor shall any judge approve a plea bargaining agreement entered into for the purpose of permitting a person charged with a violation of this section to avoid the mandatory penalties established by this section. For the purpose of this subsection, entering into a diversion agreement pursuant to K.S.A. 12-4413 et seq., and amendments thereto, shall not constitute plea bargaining. 
(r)  The alternatives set out in subsection (a) may be pleaded in the alternative, and the city may, but shall not be required to, elect one or two of the three prior to submission of the case to the fact finder. 
(s)  For the purpose of this section: 
(1)  Alcohol Concentration means the number of grams of alcohol per 100 milliliters of blood or per 210 liters of breath. 
(2)  Drug includes toxic vapors as such term is defined in K.S.A. Supp. 21-5712, and amendments thereto. 
(3)  Imprisonment shall include any restrained environment in which the court and law enforcement agency intend to retain custody and control of a defendant and such environment has been approved by the governing body of the city. 
(t)  Upon the filing of a complaint, citation, or notice to appear alleging a person has violated the acts prohibited by this section, and prior to conviction thereof, a city attorney shall request and shall receive from the: 
(1)  Division a record of all prior convictions obtained against such person for any violations of any of the motor vehicle laws of this state; and 
(2)  Kansas Bureau of Investigation central repository all criminal history record information concerning such person. 
(u)  As used in this section: 
(1)  Imprisonment shall include any restrained environment in which the court and law enforcement agency intend to retain custody and control of a defendant and such environment has been approved by the board of county commissioners or the governing body of a city. 
(2)  Drug includes toxic vapors as such term is defined in K.S.A. Supp. 21-5712, and amendments thereto. (K.S.A. Supp. 8-1567) 
(c)  Amendment. The following section of the Standard Traffic Ordinance is hereby amended to read as follows: 
Section 30.1. Driving Commercial Motor Vehicle Under the Influence of Intoxicating Liquor or Drugs; Penalties. 
(a)  Driving a commercial motor vehicle under the influence is operating or attempting to operate any commercial motor vehicle within this city while: 
(1)  The alcohol concentration in the person's blood or breath as shown by any competent evidence, including other competent evidence is .04 or more; 
(2)  The alcohol concentration in the person's blood or breath, as measured within three (3) hours of the time of operating or attempting to operate a vehicle, is .04 or more; 
(3)  Under the influence of alcohol to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle; 
(4)  Under the influence of any drug or combination of drugs to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle; 
(5)  Under the influence of a combination of alcohol and any drug or drugs to a degree that renders the person incapable of safely driving a vehicle; or 
(6)  Committing a violation of subsection (a) of Section 30 of this ordinance. 
(b)  No person shall operate or attempt to operate any vehicle within this city if the person is a habitual user of any narcotic, hypnotic, somnifacient, or stimulating drug. 
(c)  If a person is charged with a violation of this section involving drugs, the fact that the person is or has been entitled to use the drug under the laws of this state shall not constitute a defense against the charge. 
(d)  Upon a first conviction of a violation of this section, a person shall be sentenced to not less than forty-eight (48) consecutive hours nor more than six (6) months imprisonment, or in the court's discretion one hundred (100) hours of public service, and fined not less than $750 nor more than $1,000. The person convicted must serve at least forty-eight (48) consecutive hours imprisonment or one hundred (100) hours of public service either before or as a condition of any grant of probation or suspension, reduction of sentence or parole. 
(e)  On a second conviction of a violation of this section, a person shall be sentenced to not less than ninety (90) days nor more than one (1) year imprisonment and fined not less than $1,250 or more than $1,750. The person convicted must serve at least fourteen (14) consecutive days imprisonment before the person is granted probation, suspension, or reduction of sentence or parole or is otherwise released. 
(f)  In addition, prior to sentencing for any conviction, the court shall order the person to participate in an alcohol and drug evaluation conducted by a provider in accordance with K.S.A. 8-1008, and amendments thereto. The person shall be required to follow any recommendation made by the provider after such evaluation, unless otherwise ordered by the court. 
(g)  Any person eighteen (18) years of age or older convicted of violating this section who had one or more children under the age of eighteen (18) years in the vehicle at the time of the offense shall have such person's punishment enhanced by one (1) month of imprisonment. This imprisonment must be served consecutively to any other minimum mandatory penalty imposed for a violation of this section. Any enhanced penalty imposed shall not exceed the maximum sentence allowable by law. 
(h)  If a person is charged with a violation of this section involving drugs, the fact that the person is or has been entitled to use the drug under the laws of this state shall not constitute a defense against the charge.

The person shall receive a credit on the fine imposed in an amount equal to $5 for each full hour spent by the person in the specified community service. The community service ordered by the court shall be required to be performed not later than one (1) year after the fine is imposed, or by an earlier date specified by the court. If by the required date the person performs an insufficient amount of community service to reduce to zero (0) the portion of the fine required to be paid by the person, the remaining balance of the fine shall become due on that date. 
(k)  The court shall electronically report every conviction of a violation of this section to the division. Prior to sentencing under the provisions of this section, the court shall request and shall receive from the: 
(1)  Division a record of all prior convictions obtained against such person for any violations of any of the motor vehicle laws of this state; and 
(2)  Kansas Bureau of Investigation central repository all criminal history record information concerning such person. 
(l)  For the purposes of determining whether a conviction is a first or second conviction in sentencing under this section: 
(1)  Conviction includes being convicted of a violation of a law of any state or an ordinance of any city, or resolution of any county, which is comparable to this section or entering into a diversion agreement in lieu of further criminal proceedings in a case alleging a violation of such law, ordinance, or resolution; 
(2)  Only convictions or diversions on or after July 1, 2001, shall be taken into account when determining the sentence to be imposed for a first or second offender; 
(3)  Any convictions for a violation of the following sections occurring during a person's lifetime shall be taken into account: 
(A)  This section or K.S.A. 8-2,144, and amendments thereto; 
(B)  Operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs, K.S.A. 32-1131, and amendments thereto; 
(C)  Involuntary manslaughter while driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, K.S.A. 21-3442, prior to its repeal, or K.S.A. Supp. 21-5405(a)(3) or (a)(5), and amendments thereto; 
(D)  Aggravated battery as described in K.S.A. Supp. 21-5413(b)(3) or (b)(4), and amendments thereto; and 
(E)  Aggravated vehicular homicide, K.S.A. 21-3405a, prior to its repeal, or vehicular battery, K.S.A. 21-3405b, prior to its repeal, if the crime was committed while committing a violation of K.S.A. 8-1567, and amendments thereto; 
(4)  Receiving punishment under the uniform code of military justice or Kansas code of military justice for an act which was committed on a military reservation and which would constitute a crime described in subsections (l)(1) or (l)(3) if committed off a military reservation in this state; 
(5)  It is irrelevant whether an offense occurred before or after conviction for a previous offense; and

For the purpose of this subsection, entering into a diversion agreement pursuant to K.S.A. 12-4413 et seq., and amendments thereto, shall not constitute plea bargaining.
