(Ord. No. 2250, § 1, 10-28-03) 
Sec. 86-13. - One-way streets and alleys-Designation. 
    When properly posted, traffic shall move only in the direction indicated, upon the following streets and alleys, as follows: 
(a)  The north-south alley lying between Center Street and Anderson Street, and connecting Melanie Lane and Harding Street, is designated as a one-way alley, with the flow of traffic being north to south. 
(b)  The north-south alley lying between Sixth Street and St. Catherine Hospital Complex connecting Spruce Street and Walnut Street, is designated as a one-way alley, with the flow of traffic being south to north. 
(c)  The north-south alley lying between Sixth Street and Fifth Street connecting Laurel Street and Pine Street, is designated as a one-way alley, with the flow of traffic being north to south. 
(d)  The north-south alley lying between Eighth Street and Main Street connecting City Parking Lot and Pine Street, is designated as a one-way alley, with the flow of traffic being south to north. 
(e)  The north-south alley lying between 10th Street and 11th Street and connecting Buffalo Jones Avenue and Kansas Avenue, except the north 150 feet thereof, is designated as a one-way alley, with the flow of traffic being south to north. 
(f)  Spruce Street, from Main Street to Garden City Avenue is designated as a one-way street, with the flow of traffic being from east to west. 
(g)  Grant Avenue, from Eighth Street to Main Street is designated as a one-way street, with flow of traffic being from west to east. 
(h)  Stevens Avenue, from Pine Street to Garden City Avenue is designated as a one-way street, with the flow of traffic being from south to northwesterly direction. 
(i)  Olive Street, from Main Street to Seventh Street is designated as a one-way street, with flow of traffic being from west to east. 
(j)  Seventh Street, from Olive Street to Holmes Avenue is designated as a one-way street, with flow of traffic being from north to south. 
(k)  Fourth Street, from Maple Street to Finnup Drive is designated as a one-way street, with flow of traffic being from north to south. 
(l)  Zoo Roads are designated as one-way streets, with flow of traffic being from the entrance gate on Fourth Street to the exit gate on Fifth Street in a clockwise direction. 
(m)  Finnup Drive (Park Road), from Fourth Street to the Zoo South Maintenance Gate is designated as a one-way street, with flow of traffic being in a clockwise direction starting at Fourth Street and ending at the south maintenance gate for the zoo. 
(Ord. No. 2250, § 1, 10-28-03; Ord. No. 2510-2011, §§ 1, 3, 4-5-11) 
Sec. 86-14. - Maximum speed limits-Designation. 
    In accordance with the provisions of section 33 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance, as amended, K.S.A. 8-1559, and K.S.A. 8-1560, as amended, and as applicable to the designated streets and alleys, the following maximum speed limits are hereby established. Should a speed limit designated in this section be different than, or in conflict with, a maximum speed limit established in section 86-2 of this Code, amending section 33 of the Standard Traffic Ordinance, this section shall control the maximum speed limit in effect on the designated street, as follows: 
(1)  Main Street (US 83B, US 50B/83B): 40 miles per hour beginning at the actual south city limits and extending northerly for approximately 0.27 mile to the beginning of the four-lane pavement; 30 miles per hour from the beginning of the four-lane pavement northerly for approximately 0.25 mile to a point 50 feet north of the centerline of Santa Fe Street, and 20 miles per hour from a point 50 feet north of the centerline of Santa Fe Street northerly through the business district. 
(2)  Fulton Street (US 50B): 45 miles per hour beginning at the actual east city limits and extending westerly for approximately 0.68 mile to a point 792 feet east of the centerline of Campus Drive; 40 miles per hour from a point 792 feet east of the centerline of Campus Drive westerly for approximately 0.55 miles to a point 72 feet east of the centerline of Fleming Street; 35 miles per hour from a point 72 east of the centerline of Fleming Street westerly for approximately 0.81 mile to a point 69 feet east of the centerline of Fourth Street; 30 miles per hour from a point 69 feet east of the centerline of Fourth Street westerly through the business district and junction of Fulton Street and Main Street and westerly to the west city limits. 
(3)  Kansas Avenue (K 156, US 50B/83B): 45 miles per hour beginning at the east city limits and extending westerly for approximately 0.21 mile to a point 287 feet west of the centerline of Leslie Road; 40 miles per hour from the point 287 feet west of the centerline of Leslie Road westerly for approximately 1.27 miles to a point 298 feet east of the centerline of Fleming Street; 35 miles per hour from a point 298 feet east of the centerline of Fleming Street westerly for approximately 0.55 mile to a point 284 feet east to the centerline of Fourth Street; 30 miles per hour from a point 284 feet east of the centerline of Fourth Street westerly to Five Points intersection. 
(4)  Campus Drive: 40 miles per hour from the intersection of Campus Drive and Fulton Street (US 50B) and running north to the north city limits. 
(5)  Mary Street: 40 miles per hour commencing at the west city limits boundary at a point 500 feet east of the centerline of VFW Road and continuing thence east to the east city limits boundary at the intersection of US 50/83/400 (Bypass) and Mary Street. 
(6)  Taylor Avenue (US 83B): 35 miles per hour from Five Points intersection running north to a point 300 feet north of Campbell Avenue; 45 miles per hour from a point 300 feet north of Campbell Avenue running north to a point 530 feet north of the centerline of Mary Street; 55 miles per hour from a point 530 feet from the centerline of Mary Street north to the north city limits. 
(7)  Third Street: 40 miles per hour commencing at a point 125 feet north of the centerline of Long Boulevard and running north to the north city limits. 
(8)  Cherokee Road: 20 miles per hour commencing at the intersection of Cherokee Road and Pawnee Road and running north to Mary Street. 
(9)  Maple Street: 20 miles per hour commencing at the intersection of Maple Street and Fifth Street and running east to Third Street. 
(10)  Fourth Street: 20 miles per hour commencing at the intersection of Maple Street and Fourth Street and running north to Fulton Street. 
(11)  Spruce Street: 20 miles per hour commencing at the intersection of Sixth Street and Spruce Street and running east to Fourth Street. 
(12)  Parks: 20 miles per hour within any park. 
(13)  Alleys: 15 miles per hour in all alleys within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 2382, § 1, 8-28-07; Ord. No. 2510-2011, §§ 2, 3, 4-5-11; Ord. No. 2622-2013, § 1, 9-17-13; Ord. No. 2688-2015, § 1, 2-3-15; Ord. No. 2720-2016, § 1, 4-5-16) 
Secs. 86-15-86-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 

Sec. 86-31. - Application for establishment of loading zones. 
(a)  Applications for loading zones shall be processed in the following manner: 
(1)  Application shall be made in writing to the city engineer. 
(2)  The city engineer shall cause such application to be investigated and determine the necessity for the proposed loading zone as set forth in the application. 
(3)  The city engineer shall immediately thereafter report such findings to the governing body in writing together with a recommendation as to the disposition of the application. 
(4)  After recommended disposition is made by the city engineer the entire file shall be submitted to the governing body, who will either approve or reject the recommendation of the city engineer. 
(b)  If the application is favorably acted upon by the governing body, the city clerk will notify the city engineer, who will cause such loading zone to be marked with appropriate signs or markings showing that such designated area is a loading zone. 
(c)  The privilege granted under this section may be revoked by the governing body at any time by seven days written notice to the applicant. No rights granted hereunder are transferable. 
(Code 1968, § 27-240) 
Sec. 86-32. - Parking and standing of taxicabs. 
    The driver of a taxicab shall not stand or park the same upon any street in any business district at any place other than at a taxicab stand, when same have been established, except that this provision shall not prevent the driver of any taxicab vehicle from temporarily stopping in accordance with the stopping or parking regulations at any place for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers. 
(Code 1968, § 27-243) 
Cross reference- Taxicab stands, § 98-43. 
Sec. 86-33. - Commercial motor vehicles, parking provisions. 
    No commercial motor vehicle shall park upon any public street, alley or parking lot except in those areas designated as truck parking zones. No commercial motor vehicle shall park upon any private property not zoned for commercial use. Commercial motor vehicles may park in exception to this section while actually engaged in the process of loading or unloading their wares, merchandise, cargo, commodities or persons. For the purposes of this section, commercial motor vehicle shall include all motor vehicles with a weight of 16,000 pounds or greater, or that is greater than any of the following dimensions: eight feet wide, eight feet high or 20 feet long. Commercial motor vehicle shall not include recreational vehicles, as defined by the Standard Traffic Ordinance. 
(Ord. 2425, § 1, 2008) 
Sec. 86-34. - Parking vehicle not bearing current registration plate. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park, stand or leave any motor vehicle, motorcycle, motor-driven cycle, or motorized bicycle not bearing a currently valid registration plate or plates, upon any public street, alley, thoroughfare, right-of-way, municipal parking lot, or other public area within the city. 
(Code 1968, § 27-255) 
Sec. 86-35. - C-3 zoning district. 
(a)  This section applies in the C-3 zoning district. 
(b)  Any person shall be permitted to park free of charge in any designated parking space within a city-owned parking lot or upon a city controlled street right-of-way, provided, however, that this section shall in no way permit parking of unauthorized or inappropriate vehicles in those spaces marked truck parking or handicapped parking only, and provided further, that except on Sundays or holidays, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle for a longer consecutive period of time than that designated between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. in any area designated as a limited parking area and so marked. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the C-3 zoning district shall be all of that area so defined on the district zoning map. 
(Code 1968, §§ 27-257, 27-258) 
Sec. 86-36. - Unlawful parking or abandonment of motor vehicle on private property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any motor vehicle to park or abandon a motor vehicle upon private property, or upon any area developed as a privately operated off-street parking facility, without the consent of the owner, lessor, or person in charge of the private property or off-street parking facility. 
(b)  Upon complaint from an owner, lessor, or person in charge of private property or an off-street parking facility, that a motor vehicle is parked or abandoned on the private property or off-street parking facility without the consent of the owner, lessor, or person in charge, the chief of police, or designated officer, shall enforce the provisions of subsection (a) of this section through removal and impoundment of the motor vehicle. 
(c)  The owner, lessor, or person in charge of private property or an off-street parking facility making a complaint under this section and requesting removal of an unlawfully parked or abandoned motor vehicle, shall be responsible to the city for the costs associated with removal of the motor vehicle. The cost of removal shall be specified in policy adopted by the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 2292, § 1, 1-11-05) 
Sec. 86-37. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, or the Standard Traffic Ordinance, a person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter may be sentenced to pay a fine which shall be fixed by the judge of the municipal court not exceeding $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 2038, § 1, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 86-38. - Emergency snow routes. 
(1)  Declaration of snow emergency. The city manager may declare a snow emergency: (a) whenever snow has accumulated in the city to a depth of two inches with more snow falling and/or the forecast for more snowfall in the immediate future, or (b) designated by the city manager or designee when, in the opinion of the city manager or designee, weather conditions warrant the designation of a snow emergency for the protection of the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city. Once in effect, the provisions of this section shall remain in effect until the snow route has been plowed, snow is no longer accumulating; and the snow emergency has been terminated as provided herein. While the snow emergency is in effect, it shall be unlawful: (a) to park a motor vehicle or other personal property (vehicle) on any street designated an emergency snow route in subsection (4) of this section; or (b) to operate a vehicle on any emergency snow route in such manner or condition that the vehicle stalls and is unable to proceed. 
(2)  Notice of snow emergency by city manager; termination. The city manager or designee shall cause appropriate notice of the designation of a snow emergency to be given through the local press, radio, and other media. The snow emergency shall be terminated by notice given substantially in the same manner as the snow emergency was declared. 
(3)  Removal of parked vehicles. All vehicles parked on emergency snow routes must be removed before the snow on the route has accumulated to a depth of two inches or within one hour after notice of a snow emergency has been declared by the city manager or designee. Any vehicle parked on an emergency snow route after the depth of two inches or more has been reached may be ticketed and/or removed by a police officer to the nearest garage or other place of safety, and the vehicle may not be recovered until the towing and any storage charges are paid by the owner of the vehicle. 
(4)  Emergency snow routes; establishment; signs. The following streets are hereby established as emergency snow routes within the city: 
a.  Campus Drive; 
b.  Fleming Street; 
c.  Main Street, north from Kansas Avenue, and south between Kansas Avenue and the river bridge; 
d.  Taylor Avenue; 
e.  Mary Street; 
f.  Kansas Avenue; 
g.  Fulton Street; 
h.  Fourth Street (Fulton Street to Kansas Avenue); 
i.  Downtown area, 8th Street to 7th Street on Chestnut Street, Laurel Street and Pine Street; 
j.  8th Street, between Fulton Street and Walnut Street; 
k.  7th Street, between Fulton Street and Spruce Street; 
l.  Stevens Avenue, between Pine Street and 8th Street. 
Upon passage of the ordinance codified in this section, appropriate signs shall be installed along each of the streets above designated an emergency snow route. 
(5)  Penalty. A violation of any of the provisions of this section is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. In addition to any penalty provided by section 1-8, any person violating this section shall also pay to the city, any and all towing or storage charges incurred by the city as a result of removal of any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 2051, §§ 1-5, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 2170, § 1-5, 10-30-01; Ord. No. 2564-2012, § 1, 10-2-12) 
Sec. 86-39. - Parking on non-improved surfaces. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or allow to be parked for any period of time, any motor vehicle, trailer, recreational vehicle or motorcycle in the front or side yard setback area of any lot in an R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or R-C residential district in the city, unless the area used for parking is in compliance with the zoning regulations of the city, and is improved with concrete, asphalt, gravel or similar hard surface. For purposes of this section, front yard and side yard setback shall have the same meaning as defined by the zoning regulations of the city. Each day during which a violation of this section continues, shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be a class C violation, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 2262, § 1, 3-24-04) 
Secs. 86-40-86-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BICYCLES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal authority to regulate bicycles, K.S.A. 8-2002(a)(8); bicycles generally, K.S.A. 8-1586 et seq. 

Sec. 86-61. - Effects of regulations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to do any act forbidden or fail to perform any act required in this article. 
(b)  The parent of any child and the guardian of any ward shall not authorize or knowingly permit any such child or ward to violate any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The provisions of this article and every section herein, and the provisions of section 132 of the standard traffic ordinance shall not apply to the operation of a bicycle by a law enforcement officer engaged in the discharge of official duties which require the use and operation of a bicycle. 
(Code 1968, § 27-275; Ord. No. 1918, § 1, 8-8-95) 
Sec. 86-62. - U-turns. 
    Whenever authorized signs are erected indicating that no right or left or "U" turn is permitted, no person operating a bicycle or motorized bicycle shall disobey the direction of any such sign, except where such person dismounts from the bicycle or motorized bicycle to make any such turn, in which event such person shall then obey the regulations applicable to pedestrians. 
(Code 1968, § 27-285(b)) 
Sec. 86-63. - Riding on sidewalks. 
(a)  No person shall ride a bicycle or motorized bicycle upon a sidewalk within a business district. 
(b)  The chief of police is authorized to erect signs on any sidewalk or roadway prohibiting the riding of bicycles or motorized bicycles thereon by any person, and when such signs are in place no person shall disobey such signs. 
(c)  No person shall ride or drive any motorized bicycle upon any sidewalk in the city. 
(Code 1968, § 27-290) 
Sec. 86-64. - Prohibited areas. 
    No person shall ride a bicycle or motorized bicycle upon the grass or sidewalk, walking trail or jogging trail in the Finnup Park, A. Harold Long Park, Stevens Park, or Finney County Courthouse Square, nor upon or across the lawn of any private property in the city, nor on the grass or sidewalk around the swimming pool, nor in Deane Wiley Park. 
(Code 1968, § 27-291) 
Secs. 86-65-86-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - COMMERCIAL MOTOR VEHICLE SAFETY REGULATIONS 

Sec. 86-80. - Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations; adopted and incorporated by reference. 
    There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating traffic upon highways and streets of the city that certain standard safety regulation known as the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, 2017 Edition, prepared and published in book form by J.J. Keller and Associates, Inc., 3003 Breezewood Lane, P.O. Box 368, Neenah, Wisconsin 54957-0368, parts 383, 385, 390, 391, 392, 393, 395, 396 and 397, save and except such articles, sections, parts or portions as are hereafter omitted, deleted, modified or amended. No less than three (3) copies of said book shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as adopted by Ordinance No. 2776-2017," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be omitted or changed clearly marked to show any such omission or change and to which shall be attached a copy of the ordinance, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge, city prosecutor, city attorney, and all administrative departments of the city charged with the enforcement of these regulations shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of said book as may be deemed expedient. All references to the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations as adopted and incorporated into this Code shall be in a form designating section 86-80 followed in parenthesis followed by the section number of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, as incorporated. (For example, section 383 of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations as incorporated shall be referred to as section 86-80(FMCSR 383).) 
(Ord. No. 2776-2017, § 1, 11-9-17) 
Sec. 86-81. - Same; sections 390.27, 390.37 and 383.53 repealed; substitute provisions. 
    Sections 390.27, 390.37 and 383.53 of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations are hereby repealed. The following substitute provisions are adopted: 
(a)  The municipal court clerk is hereby directed to abstract all convictions of violations committed by persons holding a Commercial Driver's License (CDL) to the Driver's Control Bureau of the Department of Revenue of the State of Kansas. Any further action to a person's CDL as a result of the abstracted conviction will be at the discretion of the Driver's Control Bureau in accordance with state statutes and regulations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, parts 383, 385, 390, 391, 392, 393, 395, 396 and 397. The municipal court judge may establish a schedule of fines for violations of any section of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, parts 383, 385, 390, 391, 392, 393, 395, 396 and 397, such fine not less than one hundred fifteen dollars ($115.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus court costs. Any person who violates the provisions of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations, parts 383, 385, 390, 391, 392, 393, 395, 396 and 397, shall, upon conviction, be punished as set forth in the schedule of fines. With the exception of a violation of part 385.325(c), all violations of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations shall be traffic infractions, as defined by code section 86-4(a). A violation of part 385.325(c) shall be a Class B violation. 
(Ord. No. 2776-2017, § 1, 11-9-17) 
Sec. 86-82. - Same; section 396.9(a) repealed; amended. 
    Section 396.9(a) of the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Regulations is hereby repealed, to be amended to read as follows: 
396.9(a). Personnel authorized to perform inspections. Inspections of motor carriers' vehicles in operation shall be conducted by Commercial Vehicle Safety Alliance (CVSA) certified officers. 
(Ord. No. 2776-2017, § 1, 11-9-17) 
Sec. 86-83. - Regulating the size, weight and load of vehicles; K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, adopted and incorporated by reference. 
(a)  There is hereby incorporated by reference for the purpose of regulating the size, weight and load of vehicles within the city, K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, and any amendments thereto. No less than three (3) copies of said book shall be marked or stamped "Official Copy as adopted by Ordinance No. 2776-2017," with all sections or portions thereof intended to be omitted or changed clearly marked to show any such omission or change and to which shall be attached a copy of the ordinance, and filed with the city clerk to be open to inspection and available to the public at all reasonable hours. The police department, municipal judge, city prosecutor, city attorney, and all administrative departments of the city charged with the enforcement of these regulations shall be supplied, at the cost of the city, such number of official copies of said book as may be deemed expedient. All references to K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, as adopted and incorporated into this Code shall be in a form designating section 86-83 followed in parenthesis followed by the section number of K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, as incorporated. (For example, 8-1901 of K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19 as incorporated shall be referred to as section 86-83(K.S.A. 8-1901).) 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19. The municipal court judge may establish a schedule of fines for violations of any section of K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, such fine not less than one hundred fifteen dollars ($115.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), plus court costs. Any person who violates the provisions of K.S.A. Chapter 8, Article 19, shall, upon conviction, be punished as set forth in the schedule of fines. 
(Ord. No. 2776-2017, § 1, 11-9-17) 
Chapter 90 - UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 90-1-90-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER AND ELECTRICITY GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer means the party using the service. 
    Customer means the party in whose or which name the account is carried. 
    Domestic service unit means a single-family residence or dwelling place, including an individual apartment or a private roominghouse renting not more than three rooms that are not equipped for light housekeeping or each unit of a duplex residential dwelling, where service is utilized only for domestic purposes and no professional service, commercial enterprise or other business activity is offered or conducted. 
    Nondomestic service unit means a service unit not qualifying as a domestic service unit including any residence or apartment accommodating two or more families, each having separate kitchen facilities, location where more than three rooms are rented or available to transient or permanent roomers, public roominghouse, hotel, cottage, camp, cabin camp, motel, motor court, trailer park or camp, sports field, church, school or other institution or place where professional services are offered or any commercial enterprise or business activity is conducted. 
    Owner means the legal or equitable owner of the real property connected or hereafter connected to the waterworks or electrical system of the city. 
    Service means the sale or supply of water or electrical energy by the city to customers or consumers. 
    Service unit means each location requiring service that is under separate ownership, occupancy or lease including each owner, tenant or occupant utilizing a portion of a single building or location. 
(Code 1968, § 29-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-32. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a violation of any of the provisions of this is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 90-33. Rights - Reserved. 
    The city reserves the right to disconnect or refuse service to any customer or consumer who shall be found by the department to have violated any provision of this article or rules and regulations of the department pertaining to water and/or electric service. 
(Code 1968, § 29-20) 
Sec. 90-34. - Other rules and regulations. 
    Other rules and regulations will be prepared and published by the city manager in accordance with this article which shall not be inconsistent therewith in those cases where this article shall be silent and make no provision. 
(Code 1968, § 29-21) 
Sec. 90-35. - Application for water and electric service installation; contract. 
    Before the city shall make any new installation to serve any premises with water or electrical energy, an application for any such connection shall be made in writing by the owner of the premises to be connected or by an authorized representative at the office of the city clerk. All such applications shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk. The application shall give the location of the property to be served by its legal description or otherwise, of the type of service desired and the use for which service will be required. If there is no water main or power line to which a connection can be made, the requirements regarding extensions must be made before the application for the service connection will be accepted. The application and its acceptance shall constitute a contract between the applicant and the city for the installation of the connection. 
(Code 1968, § 29-3) 
Sec. 90-36. - Service contracts; application. 
    All water and/or electric service shall be made available by the city only on the basis of a written contract between the city and the applicant for any such service. Application for such service shall be made in writing by the customer or an authorized representative to the city clerk. The application shall designate the location of property to be served and state fully and truly the purpose for which service is requested and shall, upon acceptance by the city, constitute an agreement on the part of the applicant to abide by and be bound by all rules and regulations of the city now in force or hereafter to be made pursuant to ordinances relating to the supply and use of electrical current and/or water by such applicant and to pay the rates now or hereafter fixed by the city for such service until the same is disconnected at the request of the customer in writing, or for other reasons by the city. Such agreement shall be binding and effective when approved on behalf of the city by the city clerk and upon the deposit of such amounts as security for the payment of bills for services rendered, as provided in this article has been made by the customer. 
(Code 1968, § 29-4) 
Sec. 90-37. - Reserved. 
Sec. 90-38. - Temporary service. 
    Contractors, builders and others requiring water or electricity, where no permanent services are available, may receive such service upon the making of an application as in the case of permanent services and where practicable service shall be granted upon the making of a deposit to secure the bills to accrue, based upon the estimate of the service to be required and the payment of the cost to the city of making the temporary connection. Where practicable, meters shall be installed to measure such service, but the amount of any such bills shall not be less than the minimum monthly bill for such service where the amount due may be estimated. 
(Code 1968, § 29-6) 
Sec. 90-39. - Separate connections; multiple service rules. 
    Except as otherwise provided, there shall be a separate water service and a separate electric service connection for each service unit. 
(Code 1968, § 29-7) 
Sec. 90-40. - Meter testing charge. 
    Upon written request, the city clerk shall issue an order for a test to be made of the accuracy of any metering device. Testing of a meter more than once at a customer's request in a 12-month period, where the meter is found to be accurate within three percent (over or under) from exact accuracy, shall result in a $50.00 fee charged to the customer. 
(Code 1968, § 29-11; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 1, 12-20-11) 
Sec. 90-41. - Disputed bills. 
    In the case of disputed bills, and where the meter has not been registering or has been under or over registering by the excess of three percent, bills may be corrected on the basis of the estimated usage as shown by the average of previous bills for a like seasonable period of three months or longer when the meter registered properly. 
(Code 1968, § 29-12) 
Sec. 90-42. - Service failures. 
    The city shall not be responsible for any losses or damages due to failure of service from any cause, the breakage of any line, or failure of equipment, power source, or any failure of service due to any riot, mob, violence, strike, flood, or war damage or otherwise, or due to any failure in the customer's or consumer's lines, apparatus, wiring, connections or equipment. Should the city be called due to the failure of service and it shall be determined to be due to the failure of the wiring or lines or equipment and attachments thereof which by this article are made the responsibility of such consumer, a maximum charge of the actual costs incurred by the city in making such service call including the cost of equipment and personnel but in no case less than $35.00 may be added to the service bill of the customer for the next succeeding month. 
(Code 1968, § 29-13; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 2, 12-20-11) 
Sec. 90-43. - Shutting off water and electricity. 
    The city reserves the right without notice to shut off water or electric service temporarily for the purpose of making repairs or extensions and for other like purposes, but will insofar as possible give suitable notice or warning of such discontinuance of service and the duration thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 29-14) 
Sec. 90-44. - Access to property; inspection. 
    The city reserves the right for the officers and employees of the department to inspect any premises at all reasonable hours in connection with the supply of water or electric services to private premises within or without the city. Authorized agents of the city shall have free access at all reasonable hours to any premises to read the meters, examine the location or condition of lines, wires or pipes and other fixtures and apparatus used in connection with water or electric service. 
(Code 1968, § 29-15) 
Sec. 90-45. - Consumers not to supply other parties. 
    No consumer of water or electric service shall supply water or electricity in any way, by sale, gift or otherwise, to any other person, nor shall any such consumer permit others to attach onto such service connections for any purpose except in accordance with the rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 29-16) 
Sec. 90-46. - Taking service without authority. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, by means of any trick, device, or in any manner except as may be authorized and approved by this article and regulations of the city, to receive, consume or in any manner divert or appropriate to such person's own use or to the use of another any electric current or water belonging to and made available by the city. All such service shall be supplied and furnished by the city in accordance with the rules and regulations provided therefor. 
(Code 1968, § 29-17) 
Sec. 90-47. - Tampering with meters. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, singly or jointly, by means of any trick or device or in any unlawful manner, to stop, hinder or prevent the electric or water meters registering electric or water service to be consumed by the user thereof from registering the electric current or water consumed. It shall be further unlawful for any person to prevent such meters from registering correctly or to make them stop or run backwards or to tamper with or in any manner willfully injure or destroy such meters or registering devices. 
(Code 1968, § 29-18) 
State Law reference- Tampering with meters, K.S.A. 68-1601 et seq. 
Sec. 90-48. - Taking service after discontinuance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to break or remove any seal or device used in shutting off or discontinuing water and/or electric service, or to reconnect or turn on any such service after the same shall have been disconnected in any case where the same shall have been disconnected or discontinued for failure to make payments of the monthly bills or for violation of any rules or regulations of the city or provisions of this article. 
(Code 1968, § 29-19) 
Sec. 90-49. - Damaging, stealing property; unlawful use of water or electricity; penalty. 
    Any person who shall willfully or wantonly destroy, injure, deface, or in any way harm any water pipe, hydrant, faucet, valve, meter or meter box, placed in the city for its use or the use of the public or located on property not owned by such person, or who shall take any water from any hydrant, faucet, or pipe on any park, street, or in any public room or building in the city, or on any property not owned by such person, except for use on the premises, or who shall willfully and wantonly destroy, injure, deface or harm any electric light globule, pole, transformer, meter or meter box, or other electric apparatus, device, or equipment owned and used by the city, or who shall take any electric energy from any of the electric transmission lines or wires belonging to the city, without the proper authority to do so, or who shall carry off any pipe, wires, tools, apparatus, fueling, or any other property or equipment belonging to the city, or who shall open any fire plug or water hydrant or other water pipe belonging to the city and permit or allow water to be turned out of or run out upon the ground, without lawful authority to do so, shall be punished as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1968, § 29-22) 
Secs. 90-50-90-80. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ACCOUNTING AND BILLING 

Sec. 90-81. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Other services includes, but is not limited to, sewer service. 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-82. - Billing dates; date of payment; late payment fees. 
(a)  Water, electric and other services furnished by the city shall be furnished in accordance with the rates, rules and regulations established therefor. The charges for all such services shall be computed and collected monthly. The statement or bill for service rendered shall have designated thereon the date which is the last day on which payments of service charges can be made without payment of a late payment fee. Said date shall be 15 days from the date of mailing. The customer shall be allowed to make payments at the rate so designated at the office of the city clerk during regular business hours and on or before the close of business hours for the due date so designated, provided that when the due date shall fall on Saturday, Sunday or any day observed as a holiday in the city, payment may be made without penalty on the succeeding business day during regular business hours. 
(b)  If the statement or bill for service shall not be paid within the time so designated in subsection (a) of this section, the city clerk or manager of collections and accounts shall cause to be added to the statement or bill for service a late payment fee of five percent of the amount of the statement or bill for service, and which shall be collected at the time of payment of said statement or bill for service. The statement or bill for service rendered shall show the amount to be paid before the designated due date and the amount to be paid after the designated due date, which amount shall include the late payment fee of five percent. 
(c)  Any sales tax required to be collected by the state and local jurisdictions shall also be included in both amounts to be paid. 
(d)  If payment with late payment fee included is not paid and received at the office of the city clerk by the close of regular business hours or within an additional seven days thereafter, a delinquent notice will be sent notifying the customer that service will be cut off and discontinued if not paid by the close of regular business hours for the date specified on the delinquent notice, and until full payment is made of bills then due and accrued to the date of discontinuance together with all late payment fees and charges. No service so disconnected shall be reconnected until all bills, late payment fees and charges are paid in full, and a service charge of $15.00 for each service meter so disconnected shall have been paid for reconnection of the service meter, provided that the request for resumed service shall be made during the regular business hours of the city, and a maximum charge of the actual costs incurred by the city in making such service reconnection, including the cost of equipment and personnel, but in no case less than $40.00 for each service performed after regular business hours, Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, and until the security deposit required by this article shall have been restored to such amount as may be required under the regulations of the city. 
(e)  The billing procedures hereinbefore established shall also govern the billing of all persons for solid waste removal and sanitary sewer services. 
(Code 1968, § 29-50; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 3, 12-20-11) 
Sec. 90-83. - Monthly billing. 
    The city clerk shall cause each customer to be furnished monthly by mail a statement of such customer's service account. Failure to receive a bill shall not excuse a customer from the obligation to pay within the time specified. A month as used in this section shall mean a period approximately 30 days. 
(Code 1968, § 29-51) 
Sec. 90-84. - Meter deposits for permanent and temporary service. 
(a)  All new electrical customers shall pay a deposit before power is supplied. All residential customers shall pay a deposit of $200.00, and all commercial customers shall pay a deposit of $400.00, except as provided in subsections (b)-(e) below. 
(b)  New electrical customers who can provide a credit letter from their previous electric utility which shows that within the last 12 months they had a utility payment history of no more than one late payment, no insufficient funds checks, or no non-pay disconnects and that their final bill was paid on time, shall not be required to post the deposit required by subsection (a). 
(c)  In the event that service is to be discontinued as a result of the failure of a customer to pay utility bills, the amount of the deposit may be increased up to an amount equal to two times the normal deposit. 
(d)  Meter deposit refund checks which are not cashed by the individuals entitled to receive them within one year of their mailing by the city, and unclaimed meter deposits for accounts that have been inactive over two years, shall be deposited in the appropriate utility fund of the city. 
(e)  Any person desiring temporary lighting and power service from the city during construction activities, before permanent power is installed, shall pay a nonrefundable deposit of $50.00 for the meter to secure payment of electricity used. The person applying for temporary service shall pay for the electricity used at the commercial rate. 
(Code 1968, §§ 29-5, 29-52; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 4, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2581-2013, § 1, 2-5-13) 
Sec. 90-85. - Security deposit fund; interest; refund. 
(a)  The security deposit set forth in section 90-84 shall be made to the city clerk and shall be kept in a separate account and deposited in the fund designated as the "security deposit fund." Security deposits shall be nontransferable from one customer to another customer. 
(b)  Interest shall be payable, in accordance with K.S.A. 12-822, as adjusted by the KCC and credited January 1 of each calendar year. The same shall be payable upon demand to the customer depositing the same or may be credited on the payment of any bill rendered. Interest due and accrued shall not draw interest. 
(c)  Upon the discontinuance of any utility service, at the request of the customer, the city may refund to the customer said deposit plus accrued interest to date thereon less any amount due and owed to the city for services furnished prior thereto, or may transfer such deposit to a new billing address if such account is less than one year old. Security deposits collected from a customer whose account credit rating has been satisfactorily maintained for a period of 12 consecutive months shall be returned to the customer. For purposes of credit rating security deposit return, credit shall have been established by the customer if payment of all charges has been made for a period of 12 consecutive months prior to the date upon which the bill becomes delinquent and not in dispute. Return of such deposits shall be initiated at the completion of the 12-month period and may be credited against current billings until such time as the customer's deposit plus accrued interest has been returned. The city may require the identification of the person surrendering the original deposit receipt. In lieu of the original deposit receipt, the city may require that the customer sign a standard release form acknowledging return of the deposit and interest thereon. All security deposits not applied for and refunded within one year after discontinuance of service on terminated accounts shall be deposited in the waterworks or electric fund, as the case may be, by the city clerk. 
(Code 1968, § 29-53) 
Sec. 90-86. - Application of deposit. 
    If any customer shall for any reason fail to pay any account rendered for service used (including, but not limited to, water, sewer, electricity and refuse service), connection or reconnection charges, charges for repairs, penalties incurred or other payments required by this article, it shall be the duty of the city clerk immediately to apply such deposit to the payment of the account then due; provided, that the application of such deposit shall not in any way prevent the discontinuance or disconnection of service of any such customer. Upon resumption of service, the depleted security deposit shall be restored in accordance with section 90-84 and every customer reconnected or resuming service where a deposit shall have been applied to payment of accrued bills or otherwise refunded shall make a deposit as in the case of an original application. 
(Code 1968, §§ 29-5, 29-54) 
Sec. 90-87. - Service regulations. 
    All new service installation and service connections and disconnections or reconnections shall be made only on the written order of the city clerk. All applications for new service installation or service connections shall be made to the manager of collections and accounts in writing at the manager's office on forms provided for the purpose. Any customer may have service disconnected upon an order in writing to the city clerk and upon the payment of any final bill rendered for such service in accordance with this article; provided, that the city manager shall make suitable regulations for the discontinuance of service and may waive any informality in making of an application to discontinue service. 
(Code 1968, § 29-55) 
Sec. 90-88. - New customer connection fee. 
    A connection fee for all domestic water and/or sanitary sewer service, and for all electric service shall be paid to the city clerk upon making application for such services. The nonrefundable fee shall be $15.00 for each domestic water and/or sanitary sewer service connection and $15.00 for each electric service connection. The provisions of this section shall not apply to services that are reconnections of services that have been discontinued for nonpayment, and for landlords who require three days or less for cleaning and refurbishing of a tenant unit. 
(Code 1968, § 29-59; Ord. No. 2581-2013, § 2, 2-5-13) 
Secs. 90-89-90-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WATER AND SEWERS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Plumbing code, § 18-321 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-111. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a violation of any of the provisions of this article is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 90-112. - Installation of connection; fees. 
    All residential, commercial and industrial water service connection installations for new structures and existing structures requiring a new service installation shall be installed by the City of Garden City Water Department. For the purpose of this section, the water main shall be considered as being in the middle of the adjoining street right-of-way and the city will extend water service from the main to the property line for a distance not to exceed 100 feet without provisions requiring additional extensions of water mains. 
(1)  Service tap fees will be charged as follows: 
a.  One-inch service ..... $900.00 
b.  One and one-half-inch service ..... $1,200.00 
c.  Two-inch service ..... $1,400.00 
d.  Three-inch service ..... $1,600.00 
e.  Four-inch service ..... $2,000.00 
f.  Six-inch service ..... $2,200.00 
g.  Eight-inch service ..... $2,400.00 
(2)  In addition to the tap fee, a service installation fee shall be included with the other charges due and payable when acquiring a building permit for new construction. Service installation fees for existing structures requiring a new service shall be due and payable when acquiring the necessary plumbing permit. The service installation fee will be based upon the city's cost for labor, equipment, materials and meter. 
(3)  The metering device shall in be supplied by the city and shall remain the property of the city and shall remain the property of the city; said city reserving the right to repair or replace such meters as deemed appropriate by the water department. 
(4)  The property owner shall be responsible for extending the service line from the meter to the building. This service line shall be installed according to the most recently adopted International Plumbing Code. If the property owner has obtained approval for a multi-unit metering installation, the property owner will be responsible for installation of service line from the curb stop to the building. 
(5)  The costs of any street, curb, gutter, and sidewalk repair resulting from property owner requesting additional water connections to a property, or the upgrading of an existing water service, are to be borne by the property owner. The costs of the repairs charged to the property owner will be at the city's cost of such repair. 
(6)  The city shall require from the property owner a 48-hour notification to schedule the main tap and meter installation. 
(7)  Multi-family housing units may apply to the water department for a multi-unit meter installation. A multi-unit water metering agreement must be entered into between a property owner and the city. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 1, 6-13-00; Ord. No. 2651-2014, § 1, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 90-113. - Extension of mains. 
    The city may extend its water mains within or without the city by construction or purchase, when applications have been made and agreements entered into by persons along the proposed extension that will produce a revenue in the judgment of the governing body sufficient to pay interest on the cost of extension and the operating cost of the service; provided, that the city may make extensions without applications having been made if in the judgment of the governing body the best interests of the city would be served; provided further, that the city may at its option require any proposed customer situated outside the city limits to whom it may decide to sell water to construct such person's own connection to a water main within the city limits at such customer's own expense and to maintain it at such customer's expense; provided, however, that if such premises shall be brought within the city, the city may enter into an agreement to acquire Title to and maintain any main which shall be located within any street or public grounds of the city, the price of such water main to be at its salvage value. 
(Code 1968, § 29-63) 
Sec. 90-114. - Service availability charge. 
    If the city makes extensions of water mains into platted subdivisions without application having been made or agreements entered into, as referenced in section 90-113, a service availability charge will be levied against the owner of each platted lot adjacent to such water main extension at such time as the main is available for service and monthly thereafter, in accordance with section 90-177. This charge shall continue to apply when such main is tapped for customer usage and all charges levied in accordance with section 90-177. This service availability charge shall cease only when a platted lot becomes a metered customer. 
(Code 1968, § 29-63.1) 
Sec. 90-115. - Abandoned service pipe. 
    All service pipes that may become useless because of laying of larger or new services, or because water will no longer be used through them must be permanently closed off at the water main at the expense of the owner of the premises, by a licensed plumber or authorized city employee, only upon the authorization of the superintendent of the water department prior to disconnection. 
(Code 1968, § 29-64; Ord. No. 2651-2014, § 2, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 90-116. - Additional service where parcel subdivided. 
    In the event of the subdivision of any parcel or piece of ground and the placing or construction of other dwellings or commercial buildings thereon, the service installed for the use of the original building and its appurtenances shall be deemed to have been installed only to supply water to such buildings or appurtenances immediately adjacent to the service connection. New water service shall be installed as in the case of any other original installation. 
(Code 1968, § 29-65) 
Sec. 90-117. - Meters-Use, ownership, repairs. 
    Water shall be supplied by the city by meter measure. Two-inch and lesser meters shall be furnished by the department and shall remain the property of the city. The city shall keep the meter in good repair unless damaged or injured by some cause other than natural wear and usage. If the meter is damaged by hot water, steam, rough use, or any cause other than from natural wear or use, the customer shall be charged the amount of the repair. The amount shall be placed upon the water bill of the customer for the succeeding month and shall be due and payable within the time provided for the payment of bills. If the cost of repairs shall not be paid within the time provided for the payment of such bill, the water service may be disconnected as in other cases. 
(Code 1968, § 29-66) 
Sec. 90-118. - Same-Location and installation. 
    Water meters shall be installed by the city in a vertical position in a location protected from freezing and easily accessible for reading. The city reserves the right to designate the location of all meters and when installed outside a building, they shall be placed in a suitable meter box of materials furnished by or approved by the city. All meter boxes or vaults shall be installed by the city or in accordance with specifications approved by the city. Multi-unit meter installations must be installed as indicated in the multi-unit water metering agreement. 
(Code 1968, § 29-67; Ord. No. 2651-2014, § 3, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 90-119. - Materials, installation to be specified by department. 
    The city shall specify the kind of pipe, service or curb cocks, curb boxes and all fittings and equipment therefor. The curb boxes shall in all cases be placed upon the public property and shall control the supply of water. All services connected to the city's public water supply will be constructed in accordance with the currently adopted edition of the International Plumbing Code and the city's water system standard specification. 
(Code 1968, § 29-68; Ord. No. 2651-2014, § 4, 7-15-14) 
Sec. 90-120. - Tampering; unauthorized connections. 
    It shall be unlawful and deemed an offense for any person to tamper with any city water main, fire main, water meter can, water meter, water meter setting, storm or sanitary sewer line or to make any connection to, on, or in, any water main, fire main, water meter can, water meter, water meter setting, storm or sanitary sewer system of the city without written permission from the city; or to reconnect any water or sewer service when it has been discontinued until such bills as are due are paid in full, including the assigned cut-off and reconnection charges. 
(Ord. No. 2330, § 1, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 90-121. - Water and sewage fund; allocation of revenue. 
    All revenue collected from the operation of the domestic water system and wastewater collection and treatment system, whether from the collection of charges for domestic water service or use of the wastewater collection and treatment system or from the sale of any property or material connected with the water and sewage department, shall be deposited to the credit of the water and sewage fund for the use of such water and sewage systems as provided by law, and as further provided below: 
(1)  The operation, maintenance and renewal of the domestic water system and wastewater collection and treatment system of the city. 
(2)  The payment of the salaries of employees engaged in the operation and administration of the domestic water system and wastewater collection and treatment system of the city. 
(3)  The repayment of federal grant funds, used for the construction of the domestic water system and wastewater collection and treatment system, as required by law. 
(4)  The retirement of the loans or bonded indebtedness and the payment of the interest thereon of the obligations of the city to construct such domestic water system and wastewater collection and treatment system. 
(5)  Other expenses as may be required by terms of the loan agreement or the terms and covenants of the bonds and so directed by the ordinance issuing such bonds. 
(6)  Provided that all above conditions are complied with, that five percent of the gross revenue derived from the customer collections of the domestic water system be transferred daily upon receipt to the water maintenance reserve fund for the purpose of constructing, equipping, repairing, maintaining and improving the domestic water system. 
(7)  Provided that all above conditions are complied with, that five percent of the gross revenue derived from the customer collections of the wastewater system be transferred daily upon receipt to the wastewater repair and replacement fund for the purpose of constructing, equipping, repairing, maintaining and improving the wastewater collection and treatment system, and supporting the wastewater repair and replacement schedule adopted by resolution of the city commission. 
(Ord. No. 2139, § 1, 2-13-01) 
State Law reference- Water and sewage fund, K.S.A. 12-858. 
Sec. 90-122. - Right of entry-Inspections. 
    The duly authorized officials or employees of the city, during all business hours of each secular day and upon reasonable request, shall be entitled to enter upon the premises of any property having a connection or connections with the sewage disposal system of the city for the purpose of inspecting such property to the end of securing any information relating to the charge to be made against such premises for the use of such system. It shall be the duty of each owner, agent or occupant of such property to permit such entry and inspection and to offer such assistance that shall be reasonable to enable such inspector to make such inspection. 
(Code 1968, § 29-71) 
Sec. 90-123. - Same-Discontinuance of water service for interference. 
    If any owner, agent, tenant or other occupant of any premises shall refuse the entry or prevent or interfere with the inspection provided for in section 90-122, the city is hereby empowered and authorized to discontinue and disconnect the water service to such premises and such water service shall not thereafter be connected to such premises until the water cut-off charge and water reconnection charge have been paid. 
(Code 1968, § 29-72) 
Secs. 90-124-90-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - WATER SUPPLY EMERGENCIES 

Sec. 90-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consumer means any person using water for any purpose from the city's water distribution system and for which either a regular charge is made or, in the case of coin sales, a cash charge is made at the site of delivery. 
    Waste of water includes, but is not limited to: 
(1)  Permitting water to escape down a gutter, ditch, or other surface drain; or 
(2)  Failure to repair a controllable leak of water due to defective plumbing. 
    Water means water available to the city for treatment by virtue of its water rights or any treated water introduced by the city into its water distribution system, including water offered for sale at any coin-operated site. 
(Code 1968, § 29-73(a)-(c)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-142. - Classes of water use. 
    The following classes of water use are established for purposes of this division: 
(1)  Class 1: Water used for outdoor watering, either public or private, for gardens, lawns, trees, shrubs, plants, parks, golf courses, playing fields, swimming pools or other recreational areas; or the washing of motor vehicles, boats, trailers or the exterior of any building or structure. 
(2)  Class 2: Water used for any commercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes, except water actually necessary to maintain the health and personal hygiene of bona fide employees while such employees are engaged in the performance of their duties at their place of employment. 
(3)  Class 3: Domestic usage, other than that which would be included in either classes 1 or 2. 
(4)  Class 4: Water necessary only to sustain human life and the lives of domestic pets and maintain minimum standards of hygiene and sanitation. 
(Code 1968, § 29-73(d)) 
Sec. 90-143. - Declaration of a water warning or emergency. 
(a)  Whenever the governing body of the city finds that drought conditions or some other condition causing a major water supply shortage are present and supplies are starting to decline, it shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a water warning exists and that it will recommend restrictions on nonessential uses during the period of warning. Such a warning shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the beginning and ending of the water warning shall be effective upon their publication in the official city newspaper. Pursuant to the approval of the Chief Engineer, Division of Water Resources, Kansas Department of Agriculture, the recommended restrictions on nonessential uses may be extended to private wells within the city limits. 
(b)  Whenever the governing body of the city finds that any emergency exists by reason of a shortage of water supply needed for essential uses, it shall be empowered to declare by resolution that a water supply emergency exists and that it will encourage voluntary water conservation or impose mandatory restrictions on water use during the period of the emergency. Such an emergency shall be deemed to continue until it is declared by resolution of the governing body to have ended. The resolutions declaring the existence and end of a water supply emergency shall be effective upon their publication in the official city newspaper and may be publicized additionally through the general news media or any other appropriate method for making such resolutions public. Pursuant to the approval of the Chief Engineer, Division of Water Resources, Kansas Department of Agriculture, the mandatory restrictions on water use may be extended to private wells within the city limits. 
(Code 1968, § 29-74; Ord. No. 2695-2015, § 1, 4-21-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2695-2015, § 1, adopted Apr. 21, 2015, amended the catchline of § 90-143 from "Declaration of a water emergency" to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 90-144. - Voluntary and mandatory conservation measures. 
(a)  Upon the declaration of a water supply emergency as provided in section 90-143, the city manager is authorized to call on all water consumers to employ voluntary water conservation measures to limit or eliminate nonessential water uses including, but not limited to, limitations on the following uses: 
(1)  Sprinkling of water on lawns, shrubs or trees (including golf courses); 
(2)  Washing of automobiles; 
(3)  Use of water in swimming pools and fountains; 
(4)  Waste of water. 
(b)  Upon the declaration of a water supply emergency as provided in section 90-143, the city manager is also authorized to implement certain mandatory water conservation measures, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Suspension of new connections to the city's water distribution system, except connections of fire hydrants and those made pursuant to agreements entered into by the city prior to the effective date of the declaration of the emergency; 
(2)  Restrictions on the uses of water in one or more classes of water use, wholly or in part; 
(3)  Restrictions on the sales of water at coin-operated facilities or sites; 
(4)  The imposition of water rationing based on any reasonable formula including, but not limited to, the percentage of normal use and per capita or per consumer restrictions; 
(5)  Complete or partial bans on the waste of water; and 
(6)  Any combination of the foregoing measures. 
(Code 1968, § 29-75) 
Sec. 90-145. - Emergency water rates and regulations. 
(a)  Upon the declaration of a water supply emergency as provided in section 90-143, the governing body of the city shall have the power to adopt emergency water rates by ordinance designed to conserve water supplies. Such emergency rates may provide for, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Higher charges for increasing usage per unit of use (increasing block rates); 
(2)  Uniform charges for water usage per unit of use (uniform unit rate); or 
(3)  Extra charges in excess of a specified level of water use (excess demand surcharge). 
(b)  During the effective period of any water supply emergency as provided for in section 90-143, city manager is empowered to promulgate such regulations as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this division, any water supply emergency resolution, or emergency water rate ordinance. Such regulations shall be subject to the approval of the governing body at its next regular or emergency meeting. 
(Code 1968, § 29-76) 
Sec. 90-146. - Violations, disconnections and penalties. 
(a)  If the city manager or other city official or officials charged with implementation and enforcement of this division or a water supply emergency resolution learn of any violation of any water use restrictions imposed pursuant to sections 90-144 or 90-145, a written notice of the violation shall be affixed to the property where the violation occurred and mailed to the consumer of record and to any other person known to the city who is responsible for the violation or its correction. Such notice shall describe the violation and order that it be corrected, cured or abated immediately or within such specified time as the city determines is reasonable under the circumstances. If the order is not complied with, the city may terminate water service to the consumer subject to the following procedures: 
(1)  The city shall give the consumer notice by mail that water service will be disconnected within a specified time due to the violation and that the consumer will have the opportunity to appeal the termination by requesting a hearing scheduled before the city governing body or a city official designated as a hearing officer for the governing body; 
(2)  If such a hearing is requested the consumer charged with the violation shall be given a full opportunity to be heard before termination is ordered; and 
(3)  The governing body or hearing officer shall make findings of fact and order whether service should continue or be terminated. 
(b)  A fee of $50.00 shall be paid for the reconnection of any water service terminated pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. Upon subsequent violations, the reconnection fee shall be $200.00 for the second violation and $300.00 for any additional violations. 
(c)  Any consumer may also be charged with violation of this division and prosecuted in municipal court. Any person so charged and found guilty in municipal court of violating the provisions of this division shall be guilty of a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1968, § 29-77) 
Secs. 90-147-90-160. - Reserved.

Sec. 90-176. - Special contracts. 
    This subdivision shall not limit the right of the city to negotiate separate contracts for supplying water to its citizens and others, within and without the city, on such terms as may be deemed advisable and are approved by the governing body. 
(Code 1968, § 29-100)

The city reserves the right to require special contracts in the case of unusual water requirements.

Water service under this schedule is applicable to individually metered service units and for multiple service units served through single service connections all of which are considered for commercial or industrial type use. The city reserves the right to require special contracts in case of unusual water requirements.

Sec. 90-178. - Service units. 
    A service unit shall consist of any or each of the following: 
(1)  A single-family dwelling or residence or an individual domestic apartment; 
(2)  A private roominghouse renting not more than three rooms not equipped for light housekeeping; 
(3)  Each such unit of a duplex dwelling; 
(4)  Each business or commercial unit or enterprise under separate ownership, occupancy or lease, tenanting or occupying a single building (by the owner or tenants, or tenants exclusively); or 
(5)  Each separate domestic or business unit (tenanting or occupying) any dwelling or business or commercial building (by the owner and tenants, or tenants exclusively). 
(Code 1968, § 29-93)
