Subdivision III. - Sewer 

Sec. 90-201. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    User means a person or legal entity producing or causing to be produced wastewater requiring processing and treatment to remove pollutants and having premises connected to the wastewater collection and treatment system. 
    Wastewater is synonymous with sewage and the two terms may be interchanged without altering the meaning of either. 
    Wastewater collection and treatment system means a system including sanitary sewers, sewer mains, pump stations, processing and treating facilities, holding ponds, etc., all used for the gathering, transporting and treating of wastewater prior to its reentry into rivers, streams or other bodies of water. 
(Code 1968, § 29-88) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-202. - Authority to levy charges. 
    There are hereby levied on all persons using the wastewater collection and treatment system of the city, a schedule of charges as provided in this division. 
(Code 1968, § 29-89) 
Sec. 90-203. - Service charges established. 
    Monthly service charges based on the quantity of water used in or on the premises as the same is measured by a water meter or meters are hereby established subject to the exceptions provided. All meters must be approved by the city manager in accordance with standards adopted by the governing body. The charges contained in this division are effective upon the dates or events noted on the schedule. 
(Code 1968, § 29-91.1) 
Sec. 90-204. - Wastewater schedule of charges. 
    The monthly wastewater disposal system rates required and to be charged and collected through its officers and agents for the use and services rendered by the wastewater disposal system of the city, the same being a part of the water and sewage system of the city, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential use. For each service unit using the city's water and sewage system for domestic purposes in a one-family residence, or one-family apartment, or private rooming house, none of which offer for rent more than three sleeping rooms not equipped for light housekeeping, or separately metered multifamily dwelling, or separately metered home in a manufactured home park or separately metered unit in a motel, used and occupied as a residence and having a wastewater connection directly or indirectly with the wastewater disposal system of the city, a monthly charge based on the quantity of water used on the premises furnished with such wastewater service, for users or customers within the corporate limits of the city shall be as follows: 
Effective for October 1, 2018 and thereafter 
Base charge, per month: $9.50 
Plus, for each 1,000 gallons, per month: $2.00 
The maximum monthly charge will not exceed $67.00 
(2)  Single metered multifamily use. For each service unit using the city's water and sewage system for domestic purposes where a multifamily dwelling (duplex and greater), apartment, single-family apartment or private rooming house in which more than three rooms are rented or available to rent to transient or permanent roomers having a wastewater connection directly or indirectly with the wastewater disposal system of the city and a water connection to the water system of the city through a single or master meter, a monthly charge for users or customers within the corporate limits of the city shall be as follows: 
Effective for October 1, 2018 and thereafter 
$21.50 per dwelling unit, billed to the tenant or occupant. 
(3)  Single metered mobile homes or manufactured housing. For each service unit using the city's water and sewage system for domestic purposes where a mobile home or manufactured housing unit having a wastewater connection directly or indirectly with the wastewater disposal system of the city and a water connection to the water system of the city through a single or master meter, a monthly charge for users or customers within the corporate limits of the city shall be as follows: 
Effective for October 1, 2018 and thereafter 
$21.50 per dwelling unit, billed to the master water meter account. 
(4)  Commercial use. For each service unit using the city's water and sewerage system for commercial purposes or a combination of commercial and domestic purposes, including any commercial enterprise or business activity where the public is invited to come for service rendered or for the transaction of business, or where any service-connected outbuilding or appurtenances on the same premises is used as a place of any professional office or the rendering of a professional service; or where any manufacturing, processing or building activity is conducted for hire or profit; or where service is taken for resale or shared with others; public rooming house; hotel; motel; sports field; church; school or other institution; or any other separately metered commercial enterprise having a wastewater connection directly or indirectly with the wastewater disposal system of the city, a monthly charge based on the quantity of water used on the premises furnished with such wastewater service, for users or customers within the corporate limits of the city shall be as follows: 
Effective for October 1, 2018 and thereafter 
Base charge, per month: $14.50 
Plus, for each 1,000 gallons, per month: $2.00 
(5)  Water not obtained for city. If, on any premises, except a single-family dwelling, connected with the wastewater disposal system of the city's, water is obtained from a source other than the city's water and sewage system, then the user shall at the user's expense, install and maintain on such premises a water meter satisfactory to the director of public utilities or his representative, which shall measure all water received on such premises from all sources, or such water obtained from sources other than the city's water and sewage system, may be measured and determined by other records kept and maintained by such user and open to inspection by and acceptable to the city's representative and in such cases, the wastewater service charge to be made against such premises shall be based on the aggregate quantity of water received on said premises from the city's water and sewage system and all other sources. 
(6)  User outside city limits. For users or customers outside the corporate limits of the city entitled to use the city's wastewater disposal system by virtue of consent of the governing body, the rates for such use shall be double those prescribed under subsections (1), (2), (3), (4), and (5). 
(Ord. No. 2143, § 1, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 2435, § 1, 3-20-09; Ord. No. 2800-2018, § 1, 8-21-18) 
Sec. 90-205. - Determination of "quantity of water used" basis. 
    When, under the provisions of this division, the amount of any wastewater disposal system charge shall be determined to be the amount of water used upon any premises furnished with wastewater disposal system service by the water and sewage system of the city, the quantity of water so used upon the premises based upon the meter reading dates for the months of December, January and February, shall be averaged each year, and rounded to the nearest 1,000 gallons, to obtain the usage basis for determining the wastewater service charge due; provided, however, that customers having a new billing address following the last determination of the wastewater service charge will be billed as follows until a new usage basis is obtained: 
For residential use under subsection 90-204(1), the residential use rate equivalent to a monthly usage of 8,000 gallons; 
For commercial use under subsection 90-204(4), the commercial use rate equivalent to a monthly usage of 10,000 gallons. 
    The charges as described under section 90-204 shall be annually placed in effect as soon as practical upon the determination of the average water usage for the months of December, January, and February. 
(Ord. No. 2139 § 1, 2-13-01; Ord. No. 2435, § 1, 3-20-09) 
Sec. 90-206. - Extra strength surcharge. 
(a)  Wastewater discharge to the wastewater system from each industrial or commercial user shall be subject to an extra strength surcharge when the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) concentration exceeds 300 milligrams per liter, the suspended solids (SS) concentration exceeds 300 milligrams per liter, the fat, oil and grease (FOG) concentration exceeds 75 milligrams per liter, the ammonia (NH4) concentration exceeds 30 milligrams per liter, or the phosphorus (P) concentration exceeds 25 milligrams per liter, as determined by standard analysis procedures approved by the Environmental Protection Agency. The extra strength surcharge will be calculated according to the formula: 
S = V (0.00834) [ A(BOD-300) + B(SS-300) + C(FOG-75) + D(NH4-30) + E(P-25)] 
Where: 
S = Extra strength surcharge, in dollars 
V = Wastewater volume, in thousands of gallons 
0.00834 = Conversion factor for thousands of gallons to million pounds 
A = Applicable unit charge for BOD in dollars per pound from the schedule below 
BOD = BOD strength index in parts per million or mg/l 
B = Applicable unit charge for SS in dollars per pound from the schedule below 
SS = SS strength index in parts per million or mg/l 
C = Applicable unit charge for FOG in dollars per pound from the schedule below 
FOG = FOG strength index in parts per million or mg/l 
D = Applicable unit charge for NH4 in dollars per pound from the schedule below 
NH4 = NH4 strength index in parts per million or mg/l 
E = Applicable unit charge for P in dollars per pound from the schedule below 
P = P strength index in parts per million or mg/l 
(b)  Extra strength unit charges: 
Pollutant Inside City 
per pound Outside City 
per pound BOD(A) $0.16 $0.24 SS(B) 0.12 0.18 FOG(C) 2.10 3.15 NH4(D) 1.50 2.25 P(E) 0.20 0.30  
(Ord. No. 2139, § 1, 2-13-01; Ord. No. 2435, § 3, 3-20-09) 
Sec. 90-207. - Exception to scheduled charges. 
(a)  If, on any premises, except those classified residential, there shall be used more than 50,000 gallons of water in any one month, and in the calendar year last preceding such month there was used more than 50,000 gallons of water per month for at least six months in such calendar year, and if, as established by separate approved meter installed and maintained by the user at the user's expense or other records kept and maintained by such user and open to inspection by a city representative, more than one-half of the water used in such month was not discharged into the wastewater collection and treatment system of the city, then the charge for such premises shall be based on the amount of water received on such premises during such month less the amount of such water which was not discharged into the city's wastewater collection and treatment system. 
(b)  Water, as measured by separate meter and used only for the operation of lawn sprinkling systems on the premises and from which no other outlet is provided, shall not be included in the determination of wastewater collection and treatment charges for the premises. 
(Code 1968, § 29-91.7) 
Sec. 90-208. - Minimum charges. 
    The minimum monthly charges for each billing month of approximately 30 days are hereby fixed and shall be determined by the number of "service units" serviced through a single meter and/or the size of the meter installed, whichever is the greater. 
(Code 1968, § 29-96) 
Sec. 90-209. - Tank water and miscellaneous sales. 
    For miscellaneous and tank water sales provided at the dispensing station or by agreement with the water department at a hydrant and not delivered to a service connection attached to the municipal waterworks distribution system, the following charges shall apply: 
(1)  All water so delivered at a rate of $1.65 per 1,000 gallons or fraction thereof; provided, that delivery of any such sales shall be made only at dispensing stations within the corporate limits of the city, and under rules and regulations as may be established by the city manager; provided further, that the minimum charge for any such water sales shall be $5.00. 
(2)  Water delivered through a hydrant, at a rate of $1.65 per 1,000 gallons or fraction thereof, shall require a meter issued by the water department. Written authorization from the water department is required and shall indicate specific locations and duration of use, and shall be available at the point of use for verification. In the event of an extended period of use, meter readings are required to be reported to the water department by the 25th of each month. Readings not reported or meters not returned by the 25th of the month will be assessed a non-refundable $50.00 monthly meter fee, and will be billed regardless of water usage. 
(3)  Unauthorized taking of water from a hydrant, or failure to use a meter, as required by this section, is a Class C offense, punishable as provided in Section 1-8. 
(Ord. No. 2202, § 1, 8-27-02; Ord. No 2258, § 1, 1-27-04) 
Sec. 90-210. - Temporary service. 
    For temporary use of water that cannot be metered, the rates and conditions under which such water is furnished shall be as determined by the city manager; provided, the rates for water delivered shall in no event be less than the rates herein fixed for water used within the corporate limits of the city as set out under section 90-177; provided further, that the customer taking water under any such temporary service arrangements shall pay the city their costs incident to making such temporary service available in addition to the rates for water delivered. 
(Code 1968, § 29-95) 
Sec. 90-211. - No charge when water disconnected for entire month. 
    No service charge shall be made against any premises for the use of the wastewater collection and treatment system when no wastewater of any kind has been discharged into the system and when the city's water system has been disconnected from the premises for the entire month. 
(Code 1968, § 29-91.8) 
Sec. 90-212. - Inspection. 
    The duly authorized representative of the city, during all regular business hours or upon reasonable request, shall be entitled to enter upon any premises connected with the wastewater collection and treatment system of the city for the purpose of inspecting such premises to secure information relating to the charges made against such premises for the use of such system. 
(Code 1968, § 29-91.9) 
Sec. 90-213. - Discontinuance of service. 
    If any owner, agent, tenant or other occupant of any premises shall refuse, prevent, or interfere with the inspection provided for in section 90-212 or if any user shall fail to comply with the provisions of section 90-204(5), the city manager is hereby empowered and authorized to discontinue and disconnect the water service to such premises after due notice and opportunity for hearing. 
(Code 1968, § 29-91.10) 
Secs. 90-214-90-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SEWER USE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 90-236. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in milligrams per liter. 
    Building drain means that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives the discharge from soil, waste, and other drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer, beginning five feet (1 .5 meters) outside the inner face of the building wall. 
    Building sewer means the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other places of disposal. 
    Combined sewer means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    Garbage means solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    Industrial wastes means the liquid wastes from industrial manufacturing processes, trade, or business as distinct from sanitary sewage. 
    Liquid waste hauler means any person, persons, partnership, corporation, its agents or employees including businesses, or firms, which transport liquid, nonhazardous waste of domestic origin. Industrial wastes, grease and oil, filling station or car wash mud traps must be disposed of in another manner. 
    Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake, or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
    pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the wastes from the preparation, cooking, and (dispensing of food that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing the public sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1.27 centimeters) in any dimension. 
    Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have equal rights, and is controlled by public authority. 
    Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries sewage and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are not intentionally admitted. 
    Sewage means a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions, and industrial establishments, together with such groundwaters, surface waters, and stormwaters as may be present. 
    Sewage treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. 
    Sewage works means all facilities for collecting, pumping, treating and disposing of sewage. 
    Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying sewage. 
    Slug means any discharge of water, sewage, or industrial waste which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation. 
    Storm drain (sometimes termed storm sewer) means a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes sewage and industrial wastes, other than unpolluted cooling water. 
    Superintendent means the superintendent of sewage works, wastewater and/or of water pollution control of the city or the authorized deputy, agent, or representative of such officer. 
    Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface or, or are in suspension in water, sewage, or other liquids, and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    Watercourse means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 1, 6-13-00) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-237. - Violations. 
(a)  Any person found to be violating any provision of this division except section 90-243, shall be served by the city with written notice stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit, not to exceed 30 days, for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. 
(b)  Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit provided for in subsection (a) of this section, shall be guilty of a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
(c)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss or damage occasioned the city by reason of such violation. 
(Code 1968, § 14-47) 
Sec. 90-238. - Authority to enter all properties. 
    The superintendent and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this division. The superintendent shall have no authority to inquire into any processes including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper, or other industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sanitary or storm water sewers or waterways or facilities for waste treatment. 
(Ord. No. 2330, § 1, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 90-239. - Unlawful sewage disposal. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage, or other objectionable waste. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(c)  Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility intended or used for the disposal of sewage. 
(d)  The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human employment, recreation, or other purposes, situated within the city and abutting on any street, alley, or right-of-way in which there is now located or may in the future be located a public sanitary or combined sewer of the city, is hereby required at the owner's expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this division, within 90 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that such public sewer is within 100 feet (30.5 meters) of the property line. 
(Code 1968, § 14-41) 
Sec. 90-240. - Private sewage disposal system. 
(a)  Where a public sanitary or combined sewer is not available under the provisions of section 90-239, the building sewer shall be connected to a private sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the city manager and/or authorized representative. The application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city, which the applicant shall supplement by any plans, specifications, and other information as are deemed necessary by the city. A permit and inspection fee of $50.00 shall be paid to the city at the time the application is filed. 
(c)  A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the superintendent. The superintendent shall be allowed to inspect the work at any state of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall notify the superintendent when the work is ready for final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The inspection shall be made within 24 hours of the receipt of notice by the superintendent. 
(d)  The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the department of health and environment of the state. No permit shall be issued for any private sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where the area of the lot is less than 7,000 square feet (8.372 square meters). No septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet. 
(e)  At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private sewage disposal system, a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this division, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material. 
(f)  The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, at no expense to the city. 
(g)  No statement contained in this division shall be construed to interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the health officer. 
(h)  When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be connected to said sewer within 60 days and the private sewage disposal system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bankrun gravel or dirt. 
(Code 1968, § 14-42) 
Sec. 90-241. - Connection permits. 
(a)  No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof without first obtaining a written permit from the authorized city representative. 
(b)  There shall be two classes of building sewer permits: 
(1)  For residential and commercial service; and 
(2)  For service to establishments producing industrial wastes. 
In either case, the owner or agent shall make application on a special form furnished by the city. The permit application shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information required by the inspection department. 
(c)  All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The cost for connecting the building sewer to the public sewer shall be $500.00 per connection for those properties not included in a sanitary sewer benefit district serving the property, and no cost per connection for those properties included in a benefit district. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation of the building sewer. 
(d)  A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every building; except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, courtyard, or driveway, the building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and the whole considered as one building sewer. Provided that, when two or more businesses are located in the same building, separate sewers for each business shall be required when deemed necessary by the inspection department. 
(e)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only when they are found, on examination and test by the city, to meet all requirements of this section. 
(f)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the A.S.T.M. and W.P.C.F. Manual of Practice No. 9 shall apply. 
(g)  Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(h)  No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(i)  The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the city before installation. 
(j)  The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the city when the building sewer is ready for inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made under the supervision of the city. 
(k)  All excavations for the building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city, all at the expense of the applicant and shall be performed by the applicant. 
(Code 1968, § 14-43) 
Sec. 90-242. - Unlawful sewer discharge. 
    Storm water and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers, as are specifically designated storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the city. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the city to a storm sewer or natural outlet. 
(Ord. No. 2330, § 1, 4-25-06) 
Sec. 90-243. - Unlawful to tamper with sewage works equipment. 
    No unauthorized person shall break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which is part of the sewage works. Unlawful tampering with sewage works equipment is a class C violation. 
(Code 1968, § 14-45) 
Sec. 90-244. - Sewer main cleaning; improperly maintained grease traps and interceptors. 
    There shall be a charge of $200.00 per hour, or any portion thereof, whenever it is necessary for the sewer maintenance personnel to clean any sewer line which has been plugged due to the absence of or improper maintenance and/or operation of grease, oil and sand interceptors or traps. When, in the opinion of the superintendent and city engineer, conditions warrant the installation of interceptors or traps, the owner of the property in question shall be required to install an interceptor or trap in accordance with the applicable provisions of chapter 18. 
(Ord. No. 2108, § 1, 11-23-99) 
Sec. 90-245. - Monitoring charge. 
    When federal, state or local regulations require monitoring of the waste from a commercial or industrial user, that user shall pay a monitoring charge. The monitoring charge shall consist of all cost for personnel, material and equipment used to collect and analyze samples from the user's wastewater. The exact charge shall be based on actual costs and shall be determined by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 2005, § 2, 3-25-97) 
Sec. 90-246. - Control authority. 
    Liquid waste haulers shall be subject to the conditions of a liquid waste hauler discharge permit as set forth herein. Administration of liquid waste hauler ordinances shall be the responsibility of the wastewater department. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-247. - Liquid waste haulers, discharge permit required. 
    Any liquid waste hauler desiring to discharge liquid waste into wastewater disposal facilities of the city shall be required to obtain a liquid waste discharge permit from the wastewater department for each vehicle owned or operated by the liquid waste hauler prior to discharge. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-248. - Liquid waste discharge permit application, application fee. 
    Applications for a liquid waste discharge permit shall be made to the wastewater department and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address, including business address of liquid waste hauler. 
(2)  Quantity, capacity, license plate number, and type of all vehicles operated by liquid waste hauler, for the purpose of hauling liquid waste. 
(3)  Types of materials pumped by liquid waste hauler including a waste characterization profile on each type of material. 
(4)  Proof of insurance in the following types and amounts: 
a.  Bodily injury, nonvehicular; $300,000.00 each occurrence. 
b.  Property damage, nonvehicular: $100,000.00 each occurrence. 
c.  Automobile insurance: $100,000.00 single occurrence, $300,000.00 aggregate, $50,000.00 property damage. 
(5)  Any other information deemed necessary by the superintendent in order to review the application. An application must be accompanied by the appropriate fee before it will be considered by the wastewater department. Permit application fees are as follows: 
a.  Payment of a $10.00 application fee (non-refundable), for those liquid waste haulers operating only within Finney County, shall accompany the application. 
b.  Payment of a $20.00 application fee (non-refundable), for any liquid waste hauler operating outside Finney County, shall accompany the application. 
(6)  Liquid waste hauler discharge permits shall not be transferred, assigned or sold. Application for renewal of a liquid waste hauler discharge permit shall be made to the wastewater department 60 days prior to the expiration date contained on the permit. 
(7)  The wastewater department may issue a liquid waste hauler discharge permit if after review of the application finds: 
a.  The liquid waste is domestic generated waste or commercial/food waste with the exception of grease trap waste; and 
b.  The liquid waste may be discharged into the wastewater treatment plant disposal facility without causing passthrough or interference; and 
c.  The liquid waste meets all applicable federal, state, and city requirements. Any liquid waste hauler discharge permit issued shall be valid for a period of one calendar year following issuance. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-249. - Permit, conditions, renewal. 
    Any liquid waste discharge permit may include conditions imposed by the wastewater department in order to assure compliance with federal pretreatment standards, applicable state regulations and city regulations. Conditions which may be imposed include, but are not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Liquid waste which violates any prohibited discharge standard of the general pretreatment regulations, 40 C.F.R. 403.5(b) or any local limit is prohibited. 
(2)  Liquid waste which contains hazardous waste is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-250. - Liquid waste discharge location, fees, manifest. 
(a)  The superintendent shall designate the disposal facility to receive permitted liquid waste. Disposal of liquid waste at any location or site other than the designated disposal facility is prohibited. The hours of operation of the disposal facility will be from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. After hour rates are double the normal rate. The disposal charge for liquid waste shall be calculated at a rate of $30.00/1,000 gallons or fraction thereof. 
(b)  Each liquid waste load which is presented for discharge shall be accompanied by a load manifest on forms prepared by the wastewater department which contains the following information: 
(1)  Permit holder name, permit number and truck license number. 
(2)  Originating location of liquid waste. 
(3)  Volume of liquid waste pumped. 
(4)  Liquid waste characterization (i.e. industrial/domestic waste, commercial). 
(5)  Signature and telephone number of a legal representative of the waste generator certifying to the above information. 
(6)  Signature of liquid waste hauler certifying the above information to be true and accurate. A manifest shall be prepared for each location where the hauler receives liquid waste. Failure to present the manifest to the wastewater treatment plant at the time of discharge shall be cause to deny access to the designated disposal facility. Manifest records shall be maintained by the liquid waste hauler for a period of three (3) years. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-251. - Holding tanks. 
    The contents from holding tanks of domestic waste shall only be allowed with the approval of the superintendent or designee, at a rate of $ 0.02 per one gallon discharged. Holding tank waste shall be accompanied by a manifest which has been signed by the generator. There shall be no mixing of holding tank wastewater with waste of any other type. A holding tank is defined as a non-discharging, storage structure for sanitary wastewater of domestic origin with no connection to a lateral field or any other type of discharge point from the storage tank. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-252. - Change in liquid waste profile. 
    A permitted liquid waste hauler shall notify the wastewater department at least seven days prior to any planned significant change in waste profile. In the event a liquid waste hauler desires to discharge industrial liquid waste then the liquid waste hauler shall contact the wastewater department for a separate permit and rate schedule. Any industrial waste shall meet categorical pretreatment standards, if applicable. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-253. - Rights of refusal. 
    Notwithstanding any provision to the contrary, the superintendent or designee of the superintendent may refuse any liquid waste load. Further, the superintendent may order the testing of the waste load by the liquid waste hauler prior to disposal. Designated staff of the wastewater department may also conduct sampling of any liquid waste to confirm compliance with the permit. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-254. - Enforcement. 
    Any liquid waste hauler discharge permit may be revoked by the superintendent upon the occurrence of any of the following: 
(1)  Failure to pay disposal charges for a period of 60 days. 
(2)  Failure to provide or maintain manifest records. 
(3)  Submission of inaccurate or false information concerning waste characterization. 
(4)  Attempted disposal or disposal of hazardous waste. 
(5)  Disposal of waste into the city's system at any site other than the designated site. 
(6)  Commission of any act by the liquid waste hauler that endangers the health, safety or welfare of any person or which constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-255. - Liquid waste hauler; regulatory penalty. 
    If any state or federal agency imposes or threatens to impose any penalty upon the wastewater department, the superintendent will immediately notify the person(s) or agency reasonably believed to be causing the wastewater department to be in violation by virtue of their discharge to the city system. If a penalty is subsequently assessed against the wastewater department, the person(s) or agency causing the wastewater department to be in violation shall be held liable for the penalty. All fines imposed as a result of a violation of this article shall be paid by the person(s) or agency causing the violation to the city and credited to the wastewater department. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Sec. 90-256. - Liquid waste hauler; cleaning, plugging, or damage to facilities. 
(a)  Cleaning. Drivers are responsible for hosing down the disposal site after completing their discharge. Washing the back of the vehicle is acceptable. Excessive or improper use of this water is not allowed. Drinking of water from this source is not allowed. 
(b)  Plugging. Any foreign matter that could cause plugging of the dump pit must be removed by the driver and placed in the barrel provided at the dump site. A minimum charge of $100.00 will be assessed to the liquid waste hauler's bill for unplugging the dump site. The site will remain closed until the plug has been cleared. 
(c)  Any liquid waste hauler causing damage to any city facility shall be liable to the city for the cost of repair or replacement of the damaged facility incurred by the city. Any person found to discharge at the Wastewater Department's disposal facility any waste not compatible with this ordinance shall be in violation of this article and guilty of a Class C violation. 
(Ord. No. 2118, § 2, 6-13-00) 
Secs. 90-257-90-265. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRIC UTILITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-266. - Penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, a violation of any of the provisions of this article is a class C offense, punishable as provided in section 1-8. 
Sec. 90-267. - Service connections. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
(1)  Point of delivery. 
a.  Overhead point of delivery is the point at which the service mast facilities connect to the service drop. 
b.  Underground point of delivery is the point at which the underground service conductors connect to the service terminals of the breakers, located on the service pedestal or transformers. 
(2)  Service conductors means the supply conductors that extend from the main line to the service mast facilities at the structure. 
(3)  Service drop means the overhead service conductors from the last pole or aerial support to the service mast facilities at the structure. 
(4)  Service mast facilities, overhead , means the service conductors between the terminals of the service equipment and a point outside the building, where connected to the service drop. 
(5)  Service entrance conductors, underground , means the service conductors between the terminal of the service equipment and the point of delivery 
(6)  Service equipment means the necessary equipment, consisting of circuit breaker or switch and fuses, and their accessories, located near the point of entrance of supply conductors to a building and intended to constitute the main control and means of cutoff for the supply to that building. 
(b)  General provisions. 
(1)  One service conductor set. A building or other premises served shall be supplied through only one set of service conductors except in conformity with exceptions specified in the National Electrical Code or as specified in this Code. 
(2)  Supply between buildings. The service conductors supplying each building or structure shall not pass through the inside of another building unless these buildings are under single occupancy or management. 
(3)  Metering equipment. 
a.  Meters. The city shall supply and install the proper electric meter for the application. 
b.  Meter sockets. When needed, meter sockets and related metering equipment will be issued by the electric utility. A copy of the approved building permit shall be submitted and kept on file with the electric utility before the equipment will be released. Meter sockets shall be rated for a minimum of 100 amps. The utility reserves the right not to energize an underrated or unapproved meter socket. Damaged meter sockets will be replaced and installed by the owner or agent at no expense to the utility. All meter sockets will be installed by the owner, located at eye level height outside of any structure and shall not be in an enclosed area of the yard. 
c.  The owner will be responsible for the special equipment required for service capacity in excess of 200 amps. 
1.  For loads exceeding 200 amps or 300 volts but less than 600 volts, meter sockets will be furnished by the utility and installed by the owner or agent. Metering will be instrument transformer rated with instrument transformers furnished by the utility. The owner or agent will furnish and install all necessary conduit from the meter socket to the instrument transformer location. 
2.  Instrument transformers and associated equipment such as enclosures, racks, poles, cable, terminators, insulators, etc., for primary metering will be furnished and installed by the utility at the expense of the customer on a nonrefundable basis. The owner or agent will install the meter socket (furnished by the utility), and will furnish and install all necessary conduit from the meter socket to the instrument transformer location. 
3.  The location of the meters shall allow access, at all times, by utility personnel for the purposes of reading meters and maintaining utility-owned equipment. The location shall be on the exterior unless otherwise approved by the utility. Each meter socket shall be plainly and permanently marked to indicate which unit is supplied therefrom. The marking is to be the same as the mailing address for each unit. The owner or developer will be responsible for electricity delivered through unmarked, illegible or incorrectly labeled meter sockets. All expenses incurred by the utility related to correcting improperly labeled meters will be billed to the developer or owner whose responsibility it shall be to pay such expenses within 30 days of receipt of such billing. 
d.  Multiple occupancy (apartments). Where service is provided to individual customers located in a structure designed for multiple occupancy, meters should be grouped for service from a single circuit secondary service. The location of the meters should be grouped for service from a single circuit secondary service. The location of the meters shall allow access, at all times, by utility personnel for the purposes of reading meters and maintaining utility-owned equipment. The location shall be on the exterior for multiple occupancy, unless otherwise approved by the utility. The owner will furnish and install utility approved multiple position meter sockets. Trenches for secondary services to apartment complexes are to be inspected by the building official. 
e.  Mobile home park. Electric facilities will generally be installed on rear lot lines (unless otherwise approved by the utility) to meter pedestals with breakers. The location of the meter shall allow access, at all times, by utility personnel for the purposes of reading meters and maintaining utility-owned equipment. 
f.  Streetlighting will be installed in accordance with the city's design criteria and standards for streets as determined by the engineering department. 
(c)  Residential service standards. 
(1)  Residential subdivision developments within the city will incorporate front-of-lot, or rear-of-lot, underground facilities. Individual building lots within areas within established overhead facilities and rural subdivision developments may incorporate either overhead or underground facilities. 
a.  Line extensions will begin at the closest suitable point of the electric distribution system, as determined by the city. 
b.  The extension will end at the customer's point of delivery and the responsibility for service facilities is: 
1.  Underground Residential Distribution (URD). The city will own, install, and maintain the primary voltage system including transformers and the secondary voltage system including the metering pedestal or the secondary junction vault. 
(a)  Pedestals. The customer will install, own and maintain the service facilities from the pedestal. These facilities shall be in accordance with the requirements of the National Electrical Code and the city building inspection department. 
(b)  Secondary junction vaults. Where secondary junction vaults have been installed in residential subdivisions in lieu of pedestals, the customer will install the secondary facilities to the home including the meter socket which must be placed on the side of the building within ten feet of the front providing full access to utility personnel. The service cable must be installed in a two-inch PVC conduit, meet the provisions of the National Electrical Code, and pass inspection by the city electric inspector. Upon completion, the city will accept ownership and maintenance of the secondary cable service to the line side of the meter housing. 
i.  If a secondary junction vault has been installed as a part of an individual underground service in an established subdivision with overhead facilities, the vault will serve as the connection point between the utility system and the customer-owned service facilities. 
ii.  The customer will install, own and maintain the service facilities from the secondary junction vault. 
iii.  These facilities shall comply with the requirements of the National Electrical Code and the city building inspection department. 
(c)  Overhead. The city will own, install and maintain the primary voltage system, transformers, and service wiring up to the service mast. The customer will be responsible for maintaining a clear path for the service conductors to pass free of vegetation or any other obstructions. The customer will own, install and maintain the service facilities including the mast, an attachment point for the secondary service wire drop that is secure and provides proper clearance, and associated wiring (and meter pole, if required). These facilities will be in accordance with National Electrical Code requirements. The city reserves the right at its option to remove or replace its property. 
(2)  Connections. 
(a)  Underground service. All connections to city-owned facilities will be made by city personnel. 
(b)  Overhead service. Under standard practice, city personnel will connect the city-owned service drop to the customer-owned mast wiring. 
(d)  Commercial Service Standards. 
(1)  Service standards. 
(a)  New commercial or industrial areas within the city will be constructed using underground electric facilities. Individual building lots within areas with established overhead facilities and areas outside the city limits may incorporate overhead or underground facilities. Underground installations will utilize pad mounted transformers. Overhead installations are limited to a maximum size of 150KVA. 
(b)  Under standard practice, commercial/industrial subdivision designs will incorporate a three-phase primary voltage system with associated tap points. Individual service installations may be either single or three-phase at the builder's option. Available three-phrase voltages will be 120/208 or 277/480 volts. Available single-phase voltage will be 120/240 volts. If supplied by a three-phase installation, 120/208 volts three-phase will be the service standard. 
(2)  Installation and ownership of facilities. 
(a)  Standard services. 
(1)  Underground. The city will own, install and maintain the primary voltage system including transformers. The customer will own, install and maintain the service facilities from the transformer secondary spades in accordance with National Electrical Code requirements. Additionally, the customer must furnish the concrete pad for the transformer per the electric utility specifications. This pad remains the ownership and maintenance responsibility of the customer. 
(2)  Overhead. The city will own, install and maintain the primary voltage system, transformers, and service wiring up to the service mast. The customer will own, install and maintain the service facilities including the mast, an attachment point for the clearance and associated wiring; these facilities will be in accordance with National Electrical Code requirements. 
(b)  Primary metering services. The city will own, install and maintain all primary voltage facilities up to and including the customer's metering point. The customer will own, install and maintain all facilities on the load side of the metering point. All customer facilities will be in accordance with National Electrical Code requirements. 
(c)  Duct rental. In public rights-of-way and easements where construction room is limited the city at its option will install, for rental, two-inch PVC duct. The rental fees will be annualized payment based on running footage. The governing body establishes the rental fee and will review and consider changes every third year from the initial date of January 1, 1995. The rental rate for the first term is $0.40 per foot. 
(3)  Connections of service facilities. 
(a)  Underground service. All connections to city-owned facilities will be made by city personnel. The total number of connections within a three-phase transformer will be limited to eight conductors per phase; within a single-phase transformer, the limit will be six conductors per phase. 
(1)  If more than the allowed number of conductors are required, a separate termination cabinet and associated facilities will be installed at the customer's expense. This cabinet will be owned, installed and maintained by the city and will be the point of attachment for the service. The city will own, install and maintain the wiring between the cabinet and transformer and make all associated connections. The customer will own, install, and maintain the facilities between the cabinet and the service entrance and will make all associated connections. 
(2)  Customer installation must be in accordance with local building codes. 
(b)  Overhead service. Under standard practice, city personnel will connect the city-owned service drop to the customer-owned mast wiring under the inspection provisions outlined in Section 90-268 Subsection (b)(3)d.v. of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2207, § 1, 10-8-02) 
Sec. 90-268. - Primary system standards. 
(a)  Definitions. 
(1)  A "developer" shall mean the last person or business entity who has sole ownership of the subdivision or section thereof for which URD facilities are to be installed under the provisions of this subsection. 
(2)  A "development" is any platted land four or more parcels or lots of real estate. 
(b)  Procedures. To initiate the design and cost estimating process for development, the following procedures will apply: 
(1)  Subdivision development. The developer will schedule a project coordination meeting with the electric utility and submit two copies of the city or county approved final plat and other pertinent maps and drawings as requested. 
(2)  Construction on a lot not served by meter pedestal or secondary junction vault. The builder will schedule a project coordination meeting with the electric utility and submit two copies of the approved site plan, or other drawings as requested. 
(3)  Construction on a lot served by an existing secondary junction vault or metering pedestal. No coordination with electric utility is required. 
a.  All project design and cost estimates will be scheduled by the electric utility based upon the date of submittal of project information and existing workload. 
b.  The customer must provide written easements to the city for all properties which the line extension will cross. The city will furnish the standard form for these easements and will designate width of easements and acceptable line routes. 
c.  All preceding procedures must be satisfied and all required fees paid before the project work order will be scheduled for construction. 
d.  The following site preparation must be completed prior to construction start: 
i.  Lot corners or other requested references must be marked by the customer. This may include locating associated electric easements granted for access to and construction within the project site. 
ii.  Final grade of construction area of route must be established and coordinated with electric utility personnel. 
iii.  Streets or access routes and construction areas must be open for safe equipment passage and operation. 
iv.  PVC conduit crossings of roadways and other physical barriers must be provided by the customer as requested by the electric utility. These installations must meet city specifications. 
v.  Customer-owned facilities must be inspected and approved by the appropriate governing agency prior to final connection to the city-owned facilities and/or system. 
(Ord. No. 2207, § 1, 10-8-02) 
Sec. 90-269. - Electric system connection fee. 
    Anyone who requires connection to the city's electrical distribution system with a disconnect size above 800 amperes in rating shall pay an electrical system connection fee. This electrical system connection fee is intended to be a contribution to the capital cost of providing electrical distribution services. In the case of an expansion of an existing service, the electrical system connection fee shall only be for the amount by which the service size is expanded from the existing service. The amount of the electrical system connection fee shall be adjusted by the city from time to time, taking into account the current cost of material, equipment, labor and overhead expenses. Effective June 1, 2012 the fee is calculated as follows: 
Electrical System Connection Fee Schedule 
In the case of multiple services per building, the service entrance size shall be based on total service disconnect sizing. The Electric System Connection Fee is based on the total service disconnect size for all service disconnect sizes above 800 amperes or above in rating. Fees are for each 100 amps of service disconnect rating. Example: Three phase 800 amperes disconnect at 277/480 volts. ($727.00 X 8 = $5,816.00) 
Voltage Fee for each 100 amps of service or part thereof Single Phase 120/240 Volts $175.00 120/208 Volts $180.00 Three Phase 120/240 Volts $280.00 120/208 Volts $315.00 277/480 Volts $727.00  
Costs for service voltages other than those shown above will be calculated on a $12.00 per required kVA basis by the city utility department. 
All electrical system connection fees shall be paid prior to the issuance of a building permit for a project or an electrical permit if no building permit is issued. Electrical system connection fees may not be transferred. 
(Ord. No. 2207, § 1, 10-8-02; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 5, 12-20-11) 
Sec. 90-272. - Electric service metered at primary voltage. 
    Electric service metered at primary voltage will be furnished, at the option of the city, under such terms and conditions as may be approved by the governing body and specifically contracted for. 
(Code 1968, § 29-112) 
Sec. 90-273. - Objectionable loads. 
    The city shall not be required to furnish or continue service to installations, the operation of which causes disturbances on the city's distribution system or is of such a character as to impair the satisfactory operation of the entire system or portion thereof. 
(Code 1968, § 29-113) 
Sec. 90-274. - Combined billing prohibited. 
    Where service for a customer is measured through more than one meter either at the same location or at two or more locations, the minimum monthly charge and billing for energy consumption shall be computed and billed for each meter separately. There shall be no combining of minimum charges or energy consumption for billing purposes; provided, that this section shall not apply to municipal departments of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 29-114) 
Sec. 90-275. - Special contracts. 
    This article shall not limit the right of the city to negotiate separate contracts for supplying electricity to its citizens and others, within and without the city, on such terms as may be deemed advisable and are approved by the governing body. 
(Code 1968, § 29-115) 
Sec. 90-276. - Service regulations. 
    Service under this article is subject to the service regulations of the city as established by this Code, and rules and regulations established for the conduct of the department of light and power of the city. 
(Code 1968, § 29-116) 
Secs. 90-277-90-300. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE SCHEDULES AND RATES 

Sec. 90-301. - Monthly electric rates. 
    The rates to be charged each billing month of approximately 30 days for electrical energy supplied by the municipal system are hereby fixed and determined and shall be as scheduled in this division. The unit of measurement shall be one kilowatt hour and shall be designated "kwh." 
(Code 1968, § 29-117) 
Sec. 90-302. - Residential service within corporate limits, schedule RE-1. 
(a)  Availability. Electric service under this schedule is available at points adjacent to the city's existing secondary voltage distribution facilities located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)  Application. Electric service under this schedule is applicable to individually metered domestic service units, including individually metered apartments for domestic purposes. This schedule is not applicable to service units accommodating two or more families, service units where more than three rooms are rented or available for rent to transient or permanent residents, or domestic service units whose premises are utilized for any professional, commercial business or other gainful enterprise including hotels, motels and apartments where service is received through a single meter and the occupant is charged a rental rate that includes electric service. Under such conditions the apartment service units will be served under the general service or other applicable rate. 
(c)  Character of service. The service coming under this section is alternating current, 60 hertz, single-phase at 120/240 volts. 
(d)  Monthly rate. The rates imposed under this section are as follows: 
Rate schedule, effective January 1, 2016: 
Customer charge, per month ..... $19.50 
Energy charge, per kwh ..... 0.1100 
(Code 1968, § 29-118; Ord. No. 1976, § 1, 9-24-96; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 6, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2580-2013, § 1, 2-5-13; Ord. No. 2716-2015, § 1, 12-29-15) 
Sec. 90-303. - Small general service within corporate limits. 
(a)  Availability. Electric service under this schedule is available at points adjacent to the city's existing distribution facilities located within the corporate limits of the city. Such service is not available for breakdown, standby, supplementary, or resale service. 
(b)  Application. Electric service under this schedule is applicable to individual metered nondomestic service units requiring standard electric service for nonresidential purposes or where the residential service is not separately metered. Residential complexes serviced through a single service connection, where such is not for the convenience and at the option of the city, shall be billed under this rate schedule. This schedule applies to any customer not qualifying for service under any other schedule whose metered demand does not exceed 17 kw in four billing cycles over 12 continuous billing cycles. 
(c)  Character of service. The service coming under this section is alternating current, 60 hertz, single- or three-phase, as available standard voltage. The character or service will be 400 amperes maximum. 
(d)  Net monthly rate. The rates imposed under this section are as follows: 
Rate schedule, effective February 15, 2013: 
Customer charge, per month ..... $40.00 
Energy charge, per kwh ..... $0.0690 
(Ord. No. 2294, § 1, 2-8-05; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 7, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2580-2013, § 2, 2-5-13) 
Sec. 90-304. - Large general service within corporate limits. 
(a)  Availability. Electric service under this schedule is available at points adjacent to the city's existing distribution facilities located within the corporate limits of the city. It is not available for breakdown, standby, or resale service. 
(b)  Application. Electrical service under this schedule is applicable to any nondomestic customer for all electric service supplied at one location and measured through one meter. A customer's billing demand shall normally exceed 17 kw for four or more billing cycles over 12 continuous billing cycles in order to qualify for this rate schedule, unless otherwise directed by the city manager and director of public utilities. 
(c)  Character of service. The service coming under this section is alternating current, 60 hertz, single- or three-phase, as available, at the available standard voltage. The character of service will be at the city's discretion. 
(d)  Net monthly rate. The rates imposed under this section are as follows: 
Rate schedule, effective February 15, 2013: 
Customer charge, per month ..... $85.00 
Demand charge ..... $11.86 
Energy charge, per kwh ..... $0.0690 
(e)  Billing demand. The billing demand shall be the highest measured 15-minute integrated demand during the current billing month. 
(f)  Power factor adjustment. The customer will, at all times, maintain at the city's point of delivery a power factor as near unity as practicable. If the power factor for the 15-minute period during which the billing demand is established is less than 95 percent, then the billing demand shall be calculated as the measured demand, multiplied by 0.95, and divided by the power factor at the time the monthly billing demand is established. 
    In the event the customer continually operates at a power factor of less than 0.75, or the customer's equipment causes excessive voltage fluctuations on city lines, the city reserves the right to install appropriate power factor correction equipment or other appropriate mitigation measures at the expense of the customer. If the city determines it is necessary to install power factor correction equipment because of a low recurring power factor or excessive voltage fluctuations, the city shall notify the customer of such need in writing and provide 30 days for customer to take corrective measures. If customer fails to take steps to correct the low power factor or excessive voltage fluctuations, city shall install the appropriate corrective measures at the customer's expense. 
(Ord. No. 2294, § 1, 2-8-05; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 8, 12-20-11; Ord. No. 2580-2013, § 3, 2-5-13; Ord. No. 2721-2016, § 1, 4-5-16) 
Sec. 90-305. - Churches within corporate limits. 
(a)  Rate schedule. Any church, synagogue, or other place used for the primary purpose of conducting group religious worship, and otherwise qualified for service under schedule LGS, large general service, will be billed at the following net monthly rate: 
June 1, 2012 to May 31, 2013 June 1, 2013 and thereafter Customer charge, per month $15.00 $15.00 Demand charge 9.45 11.86 Energy charge 0.04875 0.0690

Sec. 90-308. - Temporary short-term service within corporate limits. 
(a)  Availability. Electric service under this schedule is available at points adjacent to the city's existing distribution facilities located within the corporate limits of the city; provided, that this service will be supplied only under conditions approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Applicability. Service under this schedule is applicable to individually metered residential and nonresidential service units requiring standard electric service under conditions where a permanent service connection would be impractical or undesirable, including construction activities, shows, exhibits and camp meetings. 
(c)  Character of service. The service coming under this section is alternating current, 60 cycle, single- or three-phase, as available, at the available standard voltage. The character of service will be at the city's discretion. 
(d)  Net monthly rate. 
(1)  Residential temporary. Service rendered under terms of this schedule shall be billed according to the rates established under the residential rates. 
(2)  Commercial temporary. Service rendered under terms of this schedule shall be billed according to the rates established under the small general service rates until the demand meter reaches the minimum billing demand level as set forth in section 90-304; then service will be billed according to the rates established under the large general service rates. 
    The above-stated rates for all temporary service will remain in effect until a certificate of occupancy is issued by the city inspection department. 
(Code 1968, § 29-124; Ord. No. 1976, § 1, 9-24-96; Ord. No. 2533-2011, § 11, 12-20-11) 
Sec. 90-309. - Customer owned residential and commercial renewable energy generation facilities. 
    All policies, procedures, and regulations for interconnection and installation standards, metering, and a rate rider for parallel generation of customer-owned residential and commercial renewable energy generation facilities shall be established and governed by the Interconnection Standards for Installation and Parallel Operation of Customer-Owned Renewable Electric Generation Facilities 25 kW ac or Less for Residential Service and 200 kW ac or Less for Commercial Service adopted by the governing body and maintained by the department of public utilities. The Interconnection Standards for Installation and Parallel Operation of Customer-Owned Renewable Electric Generation Facilities 25 kW ac or Less for Residential Service and 200 kW ac or Less for Commercial Service is incorporated by reference, and the same may be amended from time to time as deemed appropriate by the department of public utilities. 
(Ord. No. 2641-2014, § 1, 2-18-14; Ord. No. 2807-2018, § 1, 10-16-18)
